					<div id="mw-content-text" class="mw-body-content"><div class="mw-subjectpageheader">
</div><div class="mw-content-ltr mw-parser-output" lang="en" dir="ltr"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Country in Northeast Africa and Southwest Asia</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1320445320">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}</style><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">This article is about the country. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Egypt_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Egypt (disambiguation)">Egypt (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

title="circa">c.</abbr> 973</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubid dynasty</a> inaugurated </div></th><td class="infobox-data"><abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1171</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Mamluk Egypt">Mamluk Egypt</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data"><abbr title="circa">c.</abbr> 1261</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_dynasty" title="Muhammad Ali dynasty">Alawiyya dynasty</a> inaugurated </div></th><td class="infobox-data">9 July 1805<sup id="cite&#95;ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Unilateral_Declaration_of_Egyptian_Independence" title="Unilateral Declaration of Egyptian Independence">Declaration of Independence</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data">28 February 1922</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/1952_Egyptian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="1952 Egyptian revolution">Revolution Day</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data">23 July 1952</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Declaration_of_the_Republic" title="Declaration of the Republic">Republic declared</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data">18 June 1953</td></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div style="text-indent:-0.9em;margin-left:1.2em;font-weight:normal;">•&#160;<a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Egypt" title="Constitution of Egypt">Current constitution</a> </div></th><td class="infobox-data">18 January 2014</td></tr><tr style="display:none"><td colspan="2">
</td></tr><tr class="mergedtoprow"><th colspan="2" class="infobox-header"><a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Egypt" title="Geography of Egypt">Area </a></th></tr><tr class="mergedrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">•&#160;Total</div></th><td class="infobox-data">1,010,408<sup id="cite&#95;ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>&#160;km<sup>2</sup> (390,121&#160;sq&#160;mi)&#32;(<a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_area" title="List of countries and dependencies by area">29th</a>)</td></tr><tr class="mergedbottomrow"><th scope="row" class="infobox-label"><div class="ib-country-fake-li">•&#160;Water&#160;(%)</div></th><td class="infobox-data">0.632</td></tr><tr class="infobox-data"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1126788409" /><div class="plainlist"><ul><li><a href="/wiki/.eg" title=".eg">.eg</a></li><li><span title="Arabic-language text"><span lang="ar" dir="rtl"><a href="/wiki/%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1." class="mw-redirect" title="مصر.">مصر.</a></span></span></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Egypt</b>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>e<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> officially the <b>Arab Republic of Egypt</b>, is a country spanning the <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Africa" title="Northeast Africa">northeast corner of Africa</a> and <a href="/wiki/Western_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Western Asia">southwest corner of Asia</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a>. It is bordered by the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a> to <a href="/wiki/Northern_coast_of_Egypt" title="Northern coast of Egypt">the north</a>, <a href="/wiki/Palestine" title="Palestine">Palestine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Israel" title="Israel">Israel</a> to <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_barrier" title="Egypt–Israel barrier">the northeast</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea" title="Red Sea">Red Sea</a> to the east, <a href="/wiki/Sudan" title="Sudan">Sudan</a> to <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Sudan_border" title="Egypt–Sudan border">the south</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Libya" title="Libya">Libya</a> to <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Libya_border" title="Egypt–Libya border">the west</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aqaba" title="Gulf of Aqaba">Gulf of Aqaba</a> in the northeast separates Egypt from <a href="/wiki/Jordan" title="Jordan">Jordan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Saudi_Arabia" title="Saudi Arabia">Saudi Arabia</a>. <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> is the capital, <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Egypt" title="List of cities and towns in Egypt">largest city</a>, and leading cultural centre, while <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> is the second-largest city and an important hub of industry and tourism.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-gov&#95;27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gov-27"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> With over 107 million inhabitants, Egypt is the <a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_population" title="List of African countries by population">third-most populous</a> country in Africa and <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_dependencies_by_population" title="List of countries and dependencies by population">15th-most populated in the world</a>.
</p><p>Egypt has one of the longest histories of any country, tracing its heritage along the <a href="/wiki/Nile_Delta" title="Nile Delta">Nile Delta</a> back to the 6th–4th millennia BCE. Considered a <a href="/wiki/Cradle_of_civilisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Cradle of civilisation">cradle of civilisation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a> saw some of the earliest developments of writing, agriculture, urbanisation, organised religion and central government.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt was an early and important <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Egypt" title="Christianity in Egypt">centre of Christianity</a>, later <a href="/wiki/Islamization_of_Egypt" title="Islamization of Egypt">adopting Islam</a> from the seventh century onwards. <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, Egypt's former capital and currently second largest city, was a hub of global knowledge through its <a href="/wiki/Library_of_Alexandria" title="Library of Alexandria">Library</a>. Cairo became the capital of the <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid Caliphate</a> in the tenth century and of the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate" title="Mamluk Sultanate">Mamluk Sultanate</a> in the 13th century. Egypt then became part of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> in 1517, until its local ruler <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Muhammad Ali</a> established modern Egypt as an autonomous <a href="/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt" title="Khedivate of Egypt">Khedivate</a> in 1867. The country was then <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_the_British" title="History of Egypt under the British">occupied</a> by the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">British Empire</a> along with <a href="/wiki/British_Sudan" class="mw-redirect" title="British Sudan">Sudan</a> and gained independence in 1922 as <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_dynasty" title="Muhammad Ali dynasty">a monarchy</a>.
</p><p>Following the <a href="/wiki/1952_Egyptian_revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="1952 Egyptian revolution">1952 revolution</a>, Egypt declared itself a <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Egypt_(1953%E2%80%9358)" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Egypt (1953–58)">republic</a>. Between 1958 and 1961, Egypt <a href="/wiki/Second_Syrian_Republic" title="Second Syrian Republic">merged with Syria</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Republic" title="United Arab Republic">United Arab Republic</a>. Egypt fought <a href="/wiki/Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_conflict" title="Arab–Israeli conflict">several armed conflicts</a> with Israel in <a href="/wiki/1948_Arab%E2%80%93Israeli_War" title="1948 Arab–Israeli War">1948</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">1956</a>, <a href="/wiki/Six-Day_War" title="Six-Day War">1967</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">1973</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Occupation_of_the_Gaza_Strip_by_the_United_Arab_Republic" title="Occupation of the Gaza Strip by the United Arab Republic">occupied</a> the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a> intermittently until 1967. In 1978, Egypt signed the <a href="/wiki/Camp_David_Accords" title="Camp David Accords">Camp David Accords</a>, which <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">recognised Israel</a> in exchange for its withdrawal from the occupied Sinai. After the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Spring" title="Arab Spring">Arab Spring</a>, which led to the <a href="/wiki/2011_Egyptian_revolution" title="2011 Egyptian revolution">2011 Egyptian revolution</a> and overthrow of <a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a>, the country faced a <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Crisis_(2011%E2%80%932014)" title="Egyptian Crisis (2011–2014)">protracted period of political unrest</a>; its first <a href="/wiki/2012_Egyptian_presidential_election" title="2012 Egyptian presidential election">democratic election in 2012</a> resulted in the short-lived, <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>-aligned government of <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi" title="Mohamed Morsi">Mohamed Morsi</a>, which was <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27etat" class="mw-redirect" title="2013 Egyptian coup d&#39;etat">overthrown</a> by the military after <a href="/wiki/June_2013_Egyptian_protests" title="June 2013 Egyptian protests">mass protests in 2013</a>. The current government is a <a href="/wiki/Semi-presidential_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Semi-presidential republic">semi-presidential republic</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a>, who was <a href="/wiki/2014_Egyptian_presidential_election" title="2014 Egyptian presidential election">elected in 2014</a> but is widely regarded as <a href="/wiki/Authoritarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Authoritarian">authoritarian</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-dictator&#95;29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-dictator-29"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt is a <a href="/wiki/Developing_country" title="Developing country">developing country</a> with the <a href="/wiki/List_of_African_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of African countries by GDP (nominal)">second-largest economy in Africa</a>. It is considered to be a <a href="/wiki/Regional_power" title="Regional power">regional power</a> in the Middle East, North Africa and the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Middle_power" title="Middle power">middle power</a> worldwide. <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> is the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">official religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Arabic" title="Arabic">Arabic</a> its official language. Egypt is a founding member of the United Nations, the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organisation_of_Islamic_Cooperation" title="Organisation of Islamic Cooperation">Organisation of Islamic Cooperation</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_Youth_Forum" title="World Youth Forum">World Youth Forum</a>, and a member of <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CoARE&#95;1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CoARE-1"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-IMFOCT2024&#95;31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFOCT2024-31"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc" />
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Names">Names</h2></div>
<p>Ancient Egypt had several names; one of them was <small>(<a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/%F0%93%86%8E" class="extiw" title="wikt:Special:Search/𓆎">𓆎</a> <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/%F0%93%85%93" class="extiw" title="wikt:Special:Search/𓅓">𓅓</a> <a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/%F0%93%8F%8F" class="extiw" title="wikt:Special:Search/𓏏">𓏏</a>𓊖)</small> <span title="Ancient Egyptian-language romanisation"><i lang="egy-Latn">km.t</i></span>, which means <a href="/wiki/Silt#Occurrence" title="Silt">black land</a><sup id="cite&#95;ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> likely referring to the <a href="/wiki/Soil_fertility" title="Soil fertility">fertile</a> black soils of the <a href="/wiki/Nile_flood" class="mw-redirect" title="Nile flood">Nile flood</a> plains, distinct from the <i>deshret</i> (<span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;<span title="Ancient Egyptian-language romanisation"><i lang="egy-Latn">dšṛt</i></span>&#x27e9;</span>), or "red land" of the <a href="/wiki/Desert" title="Desert">desert</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This name is commonly vocalised as <i>Kemet</i>, but was probably pronounced <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="und-Latn-fonipa" title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)">[kuːmat]</span> in ancient Egyptian.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The name is realised as <i><span title="Coptic-language romanisation"><i lang="cop-Latn">K(h)ēmə</i></span></i> (<a href="/wiki/Coptic_language#Dialects" title="Coptic language">Bohairic</a>: <span lang="cop">ⲭⲏⲙⲓ</span>, <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language#Dialects" title="Coptic language">Sahidic</a>: <span lang="cop">ⲕⲏⲙⲉ</span>) in <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Egyptian Coptic</a>, and appeared in <a href="/wiki/Greek_language" title="Greek language">Early Greek</a> as <span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Χημία</span></span> (<i><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language romanisation"><i lang="grc-Latn">Khēmía</i></span></i>).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Another name was <span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;<span title="Ancient Egyptian-language romanisation"><i lang="egy-Latn">tꜣ-mry</i></span>&#x27e9;</span> "land of the riverbank".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The names of <a href="/wiki/Upper_and_Lower_Egypt" title="Upper and Lower Egypt">Upper and Lower Egypt</a> were <i>Ta-Sheme'aw</i> (<span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;<span title="Ancient Egyptian-language romanisation"><i lang="egy-Latn">tꜣ-šmꜥw</i></span>&#x27e9;</span>) "sedgeland" and <i>Ta-Mehew</i> (<span class="nowrap">&#x27e8;<span title="Ancient Egyptian-language romanisation"><i lang="egy-Latn">tꜣ mḥw</i></span>&#x27e9;</span>) "northland", respectively. They were also collectively called "tꜣwy" (tāwy), meaning <a href="/wiki/Upper_and_Lower_Egypt#Structure" title="Upper and Lower Egypt">The Two Lands</a>, referring to both Lower Egypt and Upper Egypt after unification.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-TaWy&#95;39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TaWy-39"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The English name "Egypt" is derived from the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greek" title="Ancient Greek">Ancient Greek</a> "<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language romanisation"><i lang="grc-Latn">Aígyptos</i></span>" ("<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Αἴγυπτος</span></span>"), via <a href="/wiki/Middle_French" title="Middle French">Middle French</a> "Egypte" and <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> "<span title="Latin-language text"><i lang="la">Aegyptus</i></span>". It is reflected in early Greek <a href="/wiki/Linear_B" title="Linear B">Linear B</a> tablets as "a-ku-pi-ti-yo".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greece" title="Ancient Greece">ancient Greek</a> <a href="/wiki/Geographer" title="Geographer">geographer</a> <a href="/wiki/Strabo" title="Strabo">Strabo</a> provided a <a href="/wiki/Folk_etymology" title="Folk etymology">folk etymology</a> stating that "<i><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Αἴγυπτος</span></span></i>" (Aigýptios) had originally evolved as a <a href="/wiki/Compound_(linguistics)" title="Compound (linguistics)">compound</a> from "<i><span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language text"><span lang="grc">Aἰγαίου ὑπτίως</span></span></i>" (<span title="Ancient Greek (to 1453)-language romanisation"><i lang="grc-Latn">Aegaeou huptiōs</i></span>), meaning "<a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Below the Aegean</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Engsheden&#95;41-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Engsheden-41"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Another tradition claims that it was named after the legendary king <a href="/wiki/Aegyptus" title="Aegyptus">Aegyptus</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Jerome-Chronicon&#95;42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jerome-Chronicon-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The actual derivation is thought to be from <i><a href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/%E1%B8%A5wt-k%EA%9C%A3-pt%E1%B8%A5" class="extiw" title="wikt:ḥwt-kꜣ-ptḥ">ḥwt-kꜣ-ptḥ</a></i> (<i>Hutkaptah</i>, <a href="/wiki/Late_Egyptian" class="mw-redirect" title="Late Egyptian">Late Egyptian</a> pronunciation <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="egy-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA" title="Help:IPA">&#91;ħəjˌkojpəˈtaħ&#93;</a></span>), "<a href="/wiki/Egyptian_temple" title="Egyptian temple">Temple</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_conception_of_the_soul#Ka_(vital_essence)" title="Ancient Egyptian conception of the soul"><i>Ka</i></a> of <a href="/wiki/Ptah" title="Ptah">Ptah</a>," a term for the city of <a href="/wiki/Memphis,_Egypt" title="Memphis, Egypt">Memphis</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Greco-Roman writers report that Egypt was sometimes called Aeria (Ἀερία).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Jerome-Chronicon&#95;42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Jerome-Chronicon-42"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Stephanus&#95;of&#95;Byzantium-Aeria&#95;46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stephanus_of_Byzantium-Aeria-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-George&#95;W.&#95;Mooney&#95;47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-George_W._Mooney-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Stephanus_of_Byzantium" title="Stephanus of Byzantium">Stephanus of Byzantium</a> derives the name from aer (ἀήρ, "air"), explaining that Egypt was a "misty land". From this name, the ethnic form Aerioi (Ἀέριοι) is also recorded for its inhabitants.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Stephanus&#95;of&#95;Byzantium-Aeria&#95;46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stephanus_of_Byzantium-Aeria-46"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Thomas_George_Tucker" title="Thomas George Tucker">Thomas George Tucker</a> suggested that Aeria could derive not only from "misty" or "hazy air", but also be understood in the sense of "far-off" or "dimly seen".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-George&#95;W.&#95;Mooney&#95;47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-George_W._Mooney-47"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>"<span title="Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="ar-Latn">Miṣr</i></span>" (<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1177148991">.mw-parser-output .IPA-label-small{font-size:85%}.mw-parser-output .references .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .infobox .IPA-label-small,.mw-parser-output .navbox .IPA-label-small{font-size:100%}</style><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">Arabic pronunciation:</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="ar-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Arabic">&#91;misˤɾ&#93;</a></span>; "<span title="Arabic-language text"><span lang="ar" dir="rtl">مِصر</span></span>") is the <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Quranic Arabic</a> and modern official name of Egypt, while "<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="arz-Latn">Maṣr</i></span>" (<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1177148991" /><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">Egyptian Arabic pronunciation:</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="arz-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Egyptian Arabic">&#91;mɑsˤɾ&#93;</a></span>; <span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">مَصر</span></span>) is the local pronunciation in <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Egyptian Arabic">Egyptian Arabic</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  The current name of Egypt, Misr/Misir/Misru, stems from the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Semitic-speaking_peoples" title="Ancient Semitic-speaking peoples">Ancient</a> <a href="/wiki/Semitic_languages" title="Semitic languages">Semitic</a> name for it. The term originally connoted "<a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">Civilisation</a>" or "<a href="/wiki/Metropolis" title="Metropolis">Metropolis</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-AncientCivils&#95;49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AncientCivils-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Classical_Arabic" title="Classical Arabic">Classical Arabic</a> <i><span title="Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="ar-Latn">Miṣr</i></span></i> (Egyptian Arabic <i><span title="Egyptian Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="arz-Latn">Maṣr</i></span></i>) is directly cognate with the <a href="/wiki/Biblical_Hebrew_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Biblical Hebrew language">Biblical Hebrew</a> <i>Miṣráyīm</i> (מִצְרַיִם / מִצְרָיִם), meaning "the two straits", a reference to the predynastic separation of <a href="/wiki/Upper_and_Lower_Egypt" title="Upper and Lower Egypt">Upper and Lower Egypt</a>. Also mentioned in several Semitic languages as <i>Mesru</i>, <i>Misir</i> and <i>Masar</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-AncientCivils&#95;49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AncientCivils-49"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The oldest attestation of this name for Egypt is the <a href="/wiki/Akkadian_language" title="Akkadian language">Akkadian</a> "mi-iṣ-ru" ("miṣru")<sup id="cite&#95;ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> related to <i>miṣru/miṣirru/miṣaru</i>, meaning "border" or "frontier".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-akkadian&#95;52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-akkadian-52"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Neo-Assyrian_Empire" title="Neo-Assyrian Empire">Neo-Assyrian Empire</a> used the derived term <span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Rassam_cylinder_Mu-%E1%B9%A3ur.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Rassam_cylinder_Mu-%E1%B9%A3ur.jpg/60px-Rassam_cylinder_Mu-%E1%B9%A3ur.jpg" decoding="async" width="60" height="15" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Rassam_cylinder_Mu-%E1%B9%A3ur.jpg/120px-Rassam_cylinder_Mu-%E1%B9%A3ur.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="185" data-file-height="47" /></a></span>, <i>Mu-ṣur</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt" title="History of Egypt">History of Egypt</a></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Prehistoric_Egypt">Prehistoric Egypt</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Egypt" title="Prehistoric Egypt">Prehistoric Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Predynastic_collage.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Predynastic_collage.png/250px-Predynastic_collage.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="272" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Predynastic_collage.png/500px-Predynastic_collage.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1363" data-file-height="1485" /></a><figcaption><b>Clockwise</b>: a <a href="/wiki/Badarian_culture" title="Badarian culture">Badarian</a> mortuary figurine,  a <a href="/wiki/Naqada_culture" title="Naqada culture">Naqada</a> jar, a <a href="/wiki/Naqada_culture" title="Naqada culture">Naqada</a> statuette of the goddess <a href="/wiki/Bat_(goddess)" title="Bat (goddess)">Bat</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Cosmetic_palette" title="Cosmetic palette">Four dogs palette</a>,  the <a href="/wiki/Gebel_el-Arak_Knife" title="Gebel el-Arak Knife">Gebel el-Arak Knife</a>, and a <a href="/wiki/Naqada_culture" title="Naqada culture">Naqada</a> diorite vase.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Evidence of <a href="/wiki/Rock_carvings" class="mw-redirect" title="Rock carvings">rock carvings</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a> and in surrounding oases indicates early habitation. In the <a href="/wiki/10th_millennium_BCE" class="mw-redirect" title="10th millennium BCE">10th millennium BCE</a>, a culture of <a href="/wiki/Hunter-gatherer" title="Hunter-gatherer">hunter-gatherers</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fishing" title="Fishing">fishers</a> was replaced by a <a href="/wiki/Cereal" title="Cereal">grain</a>-grinding culture. Climate changes or <a href="/wiki/Overgrazing" title="Overgrazing">overgrazing</a> around 8000 <a href="/wiki/Before_common_era" class="mw-redirect" title="Before common era">BCE</a> began to desiccate the pastoral lands of Egypt, forming the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a>. Early <a href="/wiki/Tribal_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Tribal people">tribal peoples</a> migrated to the Nile River where they developed a settled agricultural <a href="/wiki/Economic_system" title="Economic system">economy</a> and more centralised society.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>By about 6000 BCE, a <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a> culture took root in the Nile Valley.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During the Neolithic era, several predynastic cultures developed independently in <a href="/wiki/Upper_and_Lower_Egypt" title="Upper and Lower Egypt">Upper and Lower Egypt</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Badarian" class="mw-redirect" title="Badarian">Badarian</a> culture and the successor <a href="/wiki/Naqada" title="Naqada">Naqada</a> series are generally regarded as precursors to <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">dynastic Egypt</a>. The earliest known Lower Egyptian site, Merimda, predates the Badarian by about seven hundred years. Contemporaneous Lower Egyptian communities coexisted with their southern counterparts for more than two thousand years, remaining culturally distinct, but maintaining frequent contact through trade. The earliest known evidence of <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_hieroglyphs" title="Egyptian hieroglyphs">Egyptian hieroglyphic</a> inscriptions appeared during the predynastic period on Naqada III pottery vessels, dated to about 3200 BCE.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ancient_Egypt_(3150_BCE–305_BCE)"><span id="Ancient_Egypt_.283150_BCE.E2.80.93305_BCE.29"></span>Ancient Egypt (3150 BCE–305 BCE)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Ancient Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg/250px-All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg/500px-All_Gizah_Pyramids.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4372" data-file-height="2906" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Giza_Necropolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Giza Necropolis">Giza Necropolis</a> is the oldest of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">ancient Wonders</a> and the only one still in existence.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Around <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;3150</span> BCE, King <a href="/wiki/Menes" title="Menes">Menes</a> unified Egypt, establishing a succession of <a href="/wiki/List_of_Egyptian_dynasties" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Egyptian dynasties">dynasties</a> that ruled for three millennia. <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Egypt" title="Culture of Egypt">Egyptian civilisation</a> thrived with distinctive achievements in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_religion" title="Ancient Egyptian religion">religion</a>, <a href="/wiki/Art_of_Ancient_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Art of Ancient Egypt">art</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_language" title="Egyptian language">writing</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Old_Kingdom" class="mw-redirect" title="Old Kingdom">Old Kingdom</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;2700–2200</span> BCE) saw the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_pyramids" title="Egyptian pyramids">pyramids</a>, including those at <a href="/wiki/Giza_Necropolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Giza Necropolis">Giza</a>. A brief <a href="/wiki/First_Intermediate_Period_of_Egypt" title="First Intermediate Period of Egypt">interregnum</a> followed, succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="Middle Kingdom of Egypt">Middle Kingdom</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;2040</span> BCE), a phase of renewed stability and prosperity under rulers such as <a href="/wiki/Amenemhat_III" title="Amenemhat III">Amenemhat III</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After the <a href="/wiki/Second_Intermediate_Period_of_Egypt" title="Second Intermediate Period of Egypt">Second Intermediate Period</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Hyksos" title="Hyksos">Hyksos</a> occupation, Egypt was reunified by <a href="/wiki/Ahmose_I" title="Ahmose I">Ahmose I</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Eighteenth_dynasty_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Eighteenth dynasty of Egypt">Eighteenth Dynasty</a> and the <a href="/wiki/New_Kingdom_of_Egypt" title="New Kingdom of Egypt">New Kingdom</a> (<abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1550–1070</span> BCE). This era marked Egypt's height as a major power in the region, extending influence into <a href="/wiki/Nubia" title="Nubia">Nubia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Levant" title="Levant">Levant</a>. It produced many of Egypt's most renowned <a href="/wiki/Pharaoh" title="Pharaoh">Pharaohs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hatshepsut" title="Hatshepsut">Hatshepsut</a>, <a href="/wiki/Thutmose_III" title="Thutmose III">Thutmose III</a>, <a href="/wiki/Akhenaten" title="Akhenaten">Akhenaten</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tutankhamun" title="Tutankhamun">Tutankhamun</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ramesses_II" title="Ramesses II">Ramesses II</a>, and witnessed the rise of <a href="/wiki/Atenism" title="Atenism">Atenism</a>, one of the earliest forms of <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheism</a>. Despite later invasions by <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Libya" title="Ancient Libya">Libyans</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Kush" title="Kingdom of Kush">Nubians</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Assyria" title="Assyria">Assyrians</a>, native dynasties eventually reasserted control.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:BD_Weighing_of_the_Heart.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/BD_Weighing_of_the_Heart.jpg/250px-BD_Weighing_of_the_Heart.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="129" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/BD_Weighing_of_the_Heart.jpg/500px-BD_Weighing_of_the_Heart.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3364" data-file-height="1732" /></a><figcaption>The Weighing of the Heart from the <i><a href="/wiki/Papyrus_of_Ani" title="Papyrus of Ani">Book of the Dead of Ani</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<p>In 525 BCE, <a href="/wiki/Cambyses_II_of_Persia" class="mw-redirect" title="Cambyses II of Persia">Cambyses II of Persia</a> conquered Egypt, beginning the <a href="/wiki/Achaemenid_Empire" title="Achaemenid Empire">Achaemenid</a> <a href="/wiki/Satrapy" class="mw-redirect" title="Satrapy">satrapy</a> period (the <a href="/wiki/Twenty-seventh_Dynasty_of_Egypt" title="Twenty-seventh Dynasty of Egypt">Twenty-seventh Dynasty</a>). Although several revolts occurred, Egypt remained under Persian control until briefly regaining independence before falling again in 343 BCE.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Thirtieth_dynasty_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Thirtieth dynasty of Egypt">Thirtieth Dynasty</a> was the last native royal house. Following renewed Persian domination, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_the_Great" title="Alexander the Great">Alexander the Great</a> conquered Egypt in 332 BCE, after which his general <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy_I_Soter" title="Ptolemy I Soter">Ptolemy I Soter</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_dynasty" title="Ptolemaic dynasty">Ptolemaic dynasty</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ptolemaic_and_Roman_Egypt_(305_BCE–641_CE)"><span id="Ptolemaic_and_Roman_Egypt_.28305_BCE.E2.80.93641_CE.29"></span>Ptolemaic and Roman Egypt (305 BCE–641 CE)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic Kingdom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Roman_Egypt" title="Roman Egypt">Roman Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg/250px-Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="236" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg/330px-Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg/410px-Denderah3_Cleopatra_Cesarion.jpg 2x" data-file-width="410" data-file-height="510" /></a><figcaption>The Ptolemaic Queen <a href="/wiki/Cleopatra_VII" class="mw-redirect" title="Cleopatra VII">Cleopatra VII</a> and her son by Julius Caesar, <a href="/wiki/Caesarion" title="Caesarion">Caesarion</a>, at the <a href="/wiki/Dendera_Temple_complex" title="Dendera Temple complex">Temple of Dendera</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic Kingdom</a> was a <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_civilization" class="mw-redirect" title="Hellenistic civilization">Hellenistic</a> state from southern Syria to <a href="/wiki/Cyrene,_Libya" title="Cyrene, Libya">Cyrene</a> and south to Nubia, with <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> as its capital and a centre of <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greek</a> culture and trade. The Ptolemies adopted pharaonic traditions to legitimise their rule, appearing on monuments in Egyptian style and participating in local religious life.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Lighthouse_of_Alexandria" title="Lighthouse of Alexandria">Lighthouse of Alexandria</a>, built c. 280 BCE, was one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a>, later destroyed by earthquakes. The last ruler, <a href="/wiki/Cleopatra_VII" class="mw-redirect" title="Cleopatra VII">Cleopatra VII</a>, committed suicide after <a href="/wiki/Octavian" class="mw-redirect" title="Octavian">Octavian</a> captured Alexandria, ending the dynasty and paving the way for Roman annexation. Native rebellions and dynastic disputes weakened the kingdom, facilitating its annexation by Rome.
</p><p>Egypt was a wealthy imperial province of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>, supplying grain and hosting the major city of Alexandria.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Governed with Roman administration and Hellenistic culture, its population primarily spoke <a href="/wiki/Koine_Greek" title="Koine Greek">Greek</a> in major cities and <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Coptic Egyptian</a> in rural areas.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-pop&#95;65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pop-65"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Christianity reached Egypt in the 1st century, brought by <a href="/wiki/Saint_Mark_the_Evangelist" class="mw-redirect" title="Saint Mark the Evangelist">Saint Mark the Evangelist</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-georgetown&#95;66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> During <a href="/wiki/Diocletian" title="Diocletian">Diocletian</a>'s reign (284–305 CE), the <a href="/wiki/New_Testament" title="New Testament">New Testament</a> had been translated into Egyptian and many Egyptian Christians were persecuted. By CE 451, a distinct <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria">Coptic Church</a> was firmly established.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Middle_Ages_(641–1517)"><span id="Middle_Ages_.28641.E2.80.931517.29"></span>Middle Ages (641–1517)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Egypt_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Egypt in the Middle Ages">Egypt in the Middle Ages</a></div><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti the oldest in Africa</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a in Cairo, of <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Ibn_Tulun" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmad Ibn Tulun">Ahmad Ibn Tulun</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg/250px-%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="105" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg/330px-%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg/500px-%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%80%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AD%D8%A7%D9%83%D9%85_%D8%A8%D8%A3%D9%85%D8%B1_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%84%D9%87_06.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5443" data-file-height="2866" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Al-Hakim_Mosque" title="Al-Hakim Mosque">Al-Hakim Mosque</a> in Cairo, of <a href="/wiki/Al-Hakim_bi-Amr_Allah" title="Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah">Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah</a>, the sixth <a href="/wiki/Fatimid" class="mw-redirect" title="Fatimid">Fatimid</a> caliph</div></div></div></div>
<p>The Byzantines regained control of Egypt after a brief <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanid Persian</a> invasion early in the 7th century, until 639–42, when the country was conquered by Arab Muslim forces under <a href="/wiki/Amr_ibn_al-As" title="Amr ibn al-As">Amr ibn al-As</a>. The Arabs defeated the Byzantine armies, bringing <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> to Egypt. Alexandria briefly returned to Byzantine control in 645 but fell again to the Arabs in 646. In 654, an invasion fleet sent by <a href="/wiki/Constans_II" title="Constans II">Constans II</a> was repulsed.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-georgetown&#95;66-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Arabs founded <a href="/wiki/Fustat" title="Fustat">Fustat</a>, later replaced by Cairo in 969.
</p><p>Under the <a href="/wiki/Abbasid" class="mw-redirect" title="Abbasid">Abbasid</a> caliphate, Egypt was governed through deputies residing in Baghdad. Revolts occurred frequently, including the Egyptian revolt of 828 and the uprising of 831 when Copts joined Muslims against the government. Semi-independent dynasties arose, including the <a href="/wiki/Tulunid_dynasty" class="mw-redirect" title="Tulunid dynasty">Tulunid dynasty</a> (868–905) and <a href="/wiki/Ikhshidid_dynasty" title="Ikhshidid dynasty">Ikhshidid dynasty</a> (935–969), which maintained Abbasid allegiance while exercising local authority.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Fatimid_Caliphate" title="Fatimid Caliphate">Fatimid Caliphate</a> ruled Egypt from the 10th century, with <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> as their capital. After the Fatimids, the <a href="/wiki/Ayyubid_dynasty" title="Ayyubid dynasty">Ayyubid dynasty</a> governed until 1250, when the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk" title="Mamluk">Mamluks</a>, a military caste of <a href="/wiki/Turkic_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Turkic people">Turco</a>-<a href="/wiki/Circassians" title="Circassians">Circassian</a> origin, took control. The Mamluks ruled Egypt for the next three centuries and maintained control over parts of the Levant. By the late 13th century, Egypt linked trade routes connecting the Red Sea with India, Malaya, and the East Indies.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Abu-Lughod&#95;68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abu-Lughod-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The mid-14th century <a href="/wiki/Black_Death" title="Black Death">Black Death</a> killed about 40% of Egypt's population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ottoman_Egypt_(1517–1867)"><span id="Ottoman_Egypt_.281517.E2.80.931867.29"></span>Ottoman Egypt (1517–1867)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Egypt_Eyalet" class="mw-redirect" title="Egypt Eyalet">Egypt Eyalet</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_the_Muhammad_Ali_dynasty" title="History of Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty">History of Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty</a></div>
<p>Egypt was conquered by the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turks" title="Ottoman Turks">Ottoman Turks</a> in 1517, following the defeat of the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk_Sultanate" title="Mamluk Sultanate">Mamluk Sultanate</a>, and became a province of the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. The Mamluks, who had dominated Egypt's military and political life for centuries, retained influence under Ottoman rule, creating a semi-autonomous power structure. The Ottomans faced repeated challenges in maintaining control, while plagues and famines weakened the economy and civil society. Between 1687 and 1731, Egypt experienced six major famines, including the 1784 famine that killed roughly one-sixth of the population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Abu-Lughod&#95;68-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Abu-Lughod-68"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Louis-Fran%C3%A7ois_Baron_Lejeune_001.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Louis-Fran%C3%A7ois_Baron_Lejeune_001.jpg/250px-Louis-Fran%C3%A7ois_Baron_Lejeune_001.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="100" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Louis-Fran%C3%A7ois_Baron_Lejeune_001.jpg/500px-Louis-Fran%C3%A7ois_Baron_Lejeune_001.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3000" data-file-height="1298" /></a><figcaption>Napoleon defeated the <a href="/wiki/Mamluk" title="Mamluk">Mamluk</a> troops in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Pyramids" title="Battle of the Pyramids">Battle of the Pyramids</a>, 21 July 1798, painted by <a href="/wiki/Louis-Fran%C3%A7ois,_Baron_Lejeune" class="mw-redirect" title="Louis-François, Baron Lejeune">Lejeune</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1798, <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_Bonaparte" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleon Bonaparte">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> invaded Egypt, defeating the Mamluks at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Pyramids" title="Battle of the Pyramids">Battle of the Pyramids</a>. The French occupation was short-lived, but it destabilised the region and set the stage for Muhammad Ali Pasha's rise. After the French were expelled, power struggles ensued between the Ottomans, the Mamluks, and Albanian mercenaries in Ottoman service, leaving Egypt politically fragmented.
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:ModernEgypt,_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder,_BAP_17996.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/ModernEgypt%2C_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder%2C_BAP_17996.jpg/250px-ModernEgypt%2C_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder%2C_BAP_17996.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="253" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/ModernEgypt%2C_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder%2C_BAP_17996.jpg/330px-ModernEgypt%2C_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder%2C_BAP_17996.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/ModernEgypt%2C_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder%2C_BAP_17996.jpg/500px-ModernEgypt%2C_Muhammad_Ali_by_Auguste_Couder%2C_BAP_17996.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4638" data-file-height="5862" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png/250px-Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="226" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png/330px-Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png/500px-Egypt_under_Muhammad_Ali_Dynasty_map_en.png 2x" data-file-width="1998" data-file-height="2253" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Muhammad Ali</a>, founder of the <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_dynasty" title="Muhammad Ali dynasty">Muhammad Ali dynasty</a>, and the extent of their realm.</div></div></div></div>
<p>In 1805, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Ali_of_Egypt" title="Muhammad Ali of Egypt">Muhammad Ali Pasha</a> seized power, massacring the remaining Mamluks and establishing a dynasty that would rule Egypt until 1952. He reorganised the army along European lines, introduced conscription, and developed a centralised administration. At the same time, he promoted cash-crop agriculture, especially long-staple cotton, to integrate Egypt into global markets.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Nejla&#95;M.&#95;Abu&#95;Izzeddin&#95;1973,&#95;p&#95;2&#95;71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Nejla_M._Abu_Izzeddin_1973,_p_2-71"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> His successors, including <a href="/wiki/Ibrahim_Pasha_of_Egypt" title="Ibrahim Pasha of Egypt">Ibrahim Pasha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abbas_I_of_Egypt" title="Abbas I of Egypt">Abbas I</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sa%27id_of_Egypt" title="Sa&#39;id of Egypt">Sa'id</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Isma%27il_Pasha_of_Egypt" title="Isma&#39;il Pasha of Egypt">Isma'il Pasha</a>, continued reforms in agriculture, science, and industry, and abolished slavery.
</p><p>Muhammad Ali expanded Egypt's control over <a href="/wiki/Northern_Sudan" class="mw-redirect" title="Northern Sudan">Northern Sudan</a> (1820–1824), <a href="/wiki/Syria" title="Syria">Syria</a> (1833), and parts of <a href="/wiki/Arabia" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabia">Arabia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Anatolia" title="Anatolia">Anatolia</a>, but European powers intervened in 1841, forcing him to relinquish most of his conquests. He modernised Egypt's infrastructure, built factories and irrigation networks, and strengthened the military, while broader education remained largely limited to military and technical training.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-auto&#95;72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-72"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The centralisation of power and focus on military and economic modernisation laid the foundation for Egypt's transformation into a regional power.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Monarchical_Egypt_(1867–1952)"><span id="Monarchical_Egypt_.281867.E2.80.931952.29"></span>Monarchical Egypt (1867–1952)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt" title="Khedivate of Egypt"> Khedivate of Egypt (1867–1914)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Egypt" title="Sultanate of Egypt"> Sultanate of Egypt (1914–1922)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Egypt_(1922%E2%80%931953)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Egypt (1922–1953)">Kingdom of Egypt (1922–1953)</a></div>
<p>In 1867, Egypt was formally granted autonomous status as a <a href="/wiki/Khedivate_of_Egypt" title="Khedivate of Egypt">vassal state</a> of the Ottoman Empire. The <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>, completed in 1869 with French assistance, became a key strategic and commercial asset. Financial mismanagement and mounting debts led Isma'il Pasha to sell Egypt's shares in the canal to Britain in 1875, increasing European influence. Rising discontent culminated in the <a href="/wiki/Urabi_revolt" title="Urabi revolt">Urabi revolt</a>, after which Britain occupied Egypt in 1882, establishing a de facto protectorate while maintaining nominal Ottoman sovereignty.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Anglo-Egyptian Condominium Agreement of 1899 placed Sudan under joint Egyptian and British administration, though Britain retained real control. Incidents such as the <a href="/wiki/Denshawai_incident" title="Denshawai incident">Denshawai incident</a> in 1906 intensified nationalist sentiment, laying the groundwork for political movements that challenged both Ottoman and European dominance.
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg/250px-Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="304" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg/330px-Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg/500px-Cairo-Demonstrations1919.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1170" data-file-height="1875" /></a><figcaption>Female nationalists demonstrating in <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>, 1919</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1914, as the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> joined World War I alongside the Central Powers, Khedive <a href="/wiki/Abbas_II_of_Egypt" title="Abbas II of Egypt">Abbas II</a> declared support for the Ottoman side. In response, the British deposed him and installed his brother <a href="/wiki/Hussein_Kamel_of_Egypt" title="Hussein Kamel of Egypt">Hussein Kamel</a>, who assumed the title of <a href="/wiki/Sultanate_of_Egypt" title="Sultanate of Egypt">Sultan of Egypt</a>. Egypt was formally declared independent from the Ottoman Empire but remained under British protection.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>After <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, nationalist sentiments surged. <a href="/wiki/Saad_Zaghlul" class="mw-redirect" title="Saad Zaghlul">Saad Zaghlul</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Wafd_Party" title="Wafd Party">Wafd Party</a> secured popular support, but the British exiled Zaghlul and his colleagues to Malta on 8 March 1919, prompting the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_revolution_of_1919" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian revolution of 1919">first modern revolution</a>. This uprising pressured the UK to issue a <a href="/wiki/Unilateral_Declaration_of_Egyptian_Independence" title="Unilateral Declaration of Egyptian Independence">declaration of independence</a> on 22 February 1922.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-jankowski-112&#95;78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jankowski-112-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Sultan <a href="/wiki/Fuad_I_of_Egypt" title="Fuad I of Egypt">Fuad I</a> then assumed the title of King of Egypt. Despite nominal independence, Britain retained military presence and political influence.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-jankowski-112&#95;78-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-jankowski-112-78"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Fuad_I_of_Egypt,_Edward_VIII,_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Fuad_I_of_Egypt%2C_Edward_VIII%2C_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg/250px-Fuad_I_of_Egypt%2C_Edward_VIII%2C_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="223" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Fuad_I_of_Egypt%2C_Edward_VIII%2C_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg/330px-Fuad_I_of_Egypt%2C_Edward_VIII%2C_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Fuad_I_of_Egypt%2C_Edward_VIII%2C_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg/500px-Fuad_I_of_Egypt%2C_Edward_VIII%2C_%26_Mohamed_Sa%27id_Pa%C5%9Fa.jpg 2x" data-file-width="564" data-file-height="628" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Fuad_I_of_Egypt" title="Fuad I of Egypt">Fuad I of Egypt</a> with <a href="/wiki/Edward_VIII" title="Edward VIII">Edward, Prince of Wales</a>, 1932</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1923, a new constitution established a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> government. The Wafd Party won a decisive victory in the 1923–24 elections, with <a href="/wiki/Saad_Zaghloul" title="Saad Zaghloul">Saad Zaghloul</a> becoming prime minister. The <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Treaty_of_1936" class="mw-redirect" title="Anglo-Egyptian Treaty of 1936">1936 treaty</a> led to British troop withdrawal from most of Egypt, except the Suez Canal. The treaty left the status of <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Sudan" title="Anglo-Egyptian Sudan">Sudan</a> unresolved, as real control remained with Britain.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ModernSudan&#95;79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ModernSudan-79"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, Egypt served as a strategic base for <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_II" title="Allies of World War II">Allied</a> operations, particularly in <a href="/wiki/North_Africa" title="North Africa">North Africa</a>. Although Egypt declared martial law and severed diplomatic relations with <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a>, the Egyptian army did not engage directly. Political tensions persisted, highlighted by the 1942 <a href="/wiki/Abdeen_Palace_Incident_of_1942" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdeen Palace Incident of 1942">Abdeen Palace Incident</a>, in which British forces pressured King Farouk to install a Wafd-coalition government.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Britro&#95;80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Britro-80"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg/250px-1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="198" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg/330px-1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg/500px-1stAlameinBritDefense.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="1290" /></a><figcaption>British infantry near <a href="/wiki/First_Battle_of_El_Alamein" title="First Battle of El Alamein">El Alamein</a>, 17 July 1942</figcaption></figure>
<p>After the war, nationalist and anti-British sentiments intensified. British troops largely withdrew in 1947, leaving a residual presence around the Suez Canal. Egypt's defeat in the <a href="/wiki/First_Arab-Israeli_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First Arab-Israeli War">First Arab-Israeli War</a> fuelled anti-monarchy feeling. The Wafd Party's 1950 election victory forced King Farouk to appoint <a href="/wiki/Mostafa_El-Nahas" class="mw-redirect" title="Mostafa El-Nahas">Mostafa El-Nahas</a> as prime minister. In 1951, Egypt unilaterally renounced the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_treaty_of_1936" title="Anglo-Egyptian treaty of 1936">1936 treaty</a> and demanded British troop withdrawal. The situation around the Suez Canal escalated, culminating in violent confrontations that led to the killing of 43 Egyptian policemen in 1952 by British troops. The Ismailia incident outraged Egypt and led to the subsequent <a href="/wiki/Cairo_fire" title="Cairo fire">Black Saturday</a> anti-British riots, which saw widespread destruction in Cairo.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-factbook-his&#95;81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-his-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>These events precipitated the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Revolution_of_1952" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Revolution of 1952">Free Officers Movement coup</a> on 22–23 July 1952, led by <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Naguib" class="mw-redirect" title="Muhammad Naguib">Muhammad Naguib</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a>. King Farouk abdicated in favour of his infant son, <a href="/wiki/Fuad_II_of_Egypt" title="Fuad II of Egypt">Fuad II</a>, but real power rested with the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Revolutionary_Command_Council" title="Egyptian Revolutionary Command Council">Egyptian Revolutionary Command Council</a>. By 18 June 1953, the monarchy was formally abolished, the 1923 constitution suspended, and Egypt was declared a republic, with Naguib as president and Nasser as prime minister.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-factbook-his&#95;81-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-his-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Republican_Egypt_under_Nasser_(1952–1970)"><span id="Republican_Egypt_under_Nasser_.281952.E2.80.931970.29"></span>Republican Egypt under Nasser (1952–1970)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_republican_Egypt" title="History of republican Egypt">History of republican Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="History of Egypt under Gamal Abdel Nasser">History of Egypt under Gamal Abdel Nasser</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Port_Said_from_air.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Port_Said_from_air.jpg/250px-Port_Said_from_air.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="184" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Port_Said_from_air.jpg/500px-Port_Said_from_air.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1300" data-file-height="956" /></a><figcaption>Smoke rises from oil tanks beside the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a> hit during the initial <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Anglo-French assault</a> on Egypt, 5 November 1956.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Following the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_revolution_of_1952" title="Egyptian revolution of 1952">1952 Revolution</a> led by the <a href="/wiki/Free_Officers_Movement_(Egypt)" class="mw-redirect" title="Free Officers Movement (Egypt)">Free Officers Movement</a>, Egypt came under military control, and all political parties were banned. On 18 June 1953, the <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Egypt_(1953%E2%80%931958)" title="Republic of Egypt (1953–1958)">Republic of Egypt</a> was officially declared, with <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Naguib" class="mw-redirect" title="Muhammad Naguib">Muhammad Naguib</a> serving as the first President. His presidency lasted less than a year and a half, as <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Pan-Arabist" class="mw-redirect" title="Pan-Arabist">Pan-Arabist</a> and the principal architect of the 1952 movement, gradually consolidated power. Naguib was forced to resign in 1954 and placed under <a href="/wiki/House_arrest" title="House arrest">house arrest</a>. The presidency remained vacant until Nasser was formally elected in 1956.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In October 1954, Egypt and the United Kingdom agreed to end the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Egyptian_Sudan" title="Anglo-Egyptian Sudan">Anglo-Egyptian Condominium Agreement</a> of 1899, granting Sudan full independence, which came into effect on 1 January 1956. In June 1956, Nasser assumed the presidency and immediately became the central figure in Egypt's domestic and foreign policy. British forces completed their withdrawal from the Suez Canal Zone on 13 June 1956. Later that year, on 26 July, Nasser <a href="/wiki/Nationalised" class="mw-redirect" title="Nationalised">nationalised</a> the Suez Canal, provoking the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Crisis" title="Suez Crisis">Suez Crisis</a> when Israel, with support from France and the United Kingdom, invaded the Sinai Peninsula and targeted the Canal. The conflict ended following diplomatic pressure from the United States and the Soviet Union, restoring the pre-war status quo.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Nasser_in_Mansoura,_1960.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Nasser_in_Mansoura%2C_1960.jpg/250px-Nasser_in_Mansoura%2C_1960.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="161" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Nasser_in_Mansoura%2C_1960.jpg/500px-Nasser_in_Mansoura%2C_1960.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="698" data-file-height="450" /></a><figcaption>Egyptian President <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> in <a href="/wiki/Mansoura,_Egypt" title="Mansoura, Egypt">Mansoura</a>, 1960</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1958, Egypt formed a political union with Syria, creating the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Republic" title="United Arab Republic">United Arab Republic</a>. The union, also loosely connected with <a href="/wiki/Mutawakkilite_Kingdom_of_Yemen" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutawakkilite Kingdom of Yemen">North Yemen</a> in the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_States" title="United Arab States">United Arab States</a>, was short-lived; Syria seceded in 1961. During this period, Egypt became heavily involved in the <a href="/wiki/North_Yemen_Civil_War" class="mw-redirect" title="North Yemen Civil War">North Yemen Civil War</a>, with military interventions and peace conferences ultimately leading to a prolonged stalemate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
In May 1967, tensions with Israel escalated after warnings from the Soviet Union, deployment of Egyptian forces to Sinai, expulsion of UN peacekeepers, and closure of the <a href="/wiki/Straits_of_Tiran" title="Straits of Tiran">Straits of Tiran</a>. These measures precipitated the <a href="/wiki/Third_Arab-Israeli_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Third Arab-Israeli War">Six-Day War</a>, during which Israel captured the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gaza_Strip" title="Gaza Strip">Gaza Strip</a>. In response to the conflict, an <a href="/wiki/Emergency_law_in_Egypt" title="Emergency law in Egypt">Emergency Law</a> was enacted, greatly expanding police powers, restricting constitutional rights, and legalising censorship; it remained in force until 2012, except for a brief break in 1980–81.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Socially and economically, Nasser's policies transformed Egypt. At the time of the monarchy's fall, less than half a million Egyptians were considered upper class, four million were middle class, and seventeen million were lower class or poor.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Tarek&#95;Osman&#95;2010,&#95;p.&#95;120&#95;86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarek_Osman_2010,_p._120-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Education was expanded, with school enrolment more than doubling from 1953 to 1966. Land reforms, industrial support, and growth in public-sector employment created a larger middle class, including doctors, engineers, teachers, lawyers, and journalists. However, by the late 1960s, the Egyptian economy faced stagnation, political freedoms had declined, and Nasser's personal popularity began to wane.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Tarek&#95;Osman&#95;2010,&#95;p.&#95;120&#95;86-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tarek_Osman_2010,_p._120-86"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Egypt_under_Sadat_and_Mubarak_(1971–2011)"><span id="Egypt_under_Sadat_and_Mubarak_.281971.E2.80.932011.29"></span>Egypt under Sadat and Mubarak (1971–2011)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_Anwar_Sadat" title="History of Egypt under Anwar Sadat">History of Egypt under Anwar Sadat</a> and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_Hosni_Mubarak" title="History of Egypt under Hosni Mubarak">History of Egypt under Hosni Mubarak</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egyptian_Armor.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Egyptian_Armor.jpg/250px-Egyptian_Armor.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="96" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/Egyptian_Armor.jpg/500px-Egyptian_Armor.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1131" data-file-height="434" /></a><figcaption>Egyptian tanks advancing in the Sinai desert during the <a href="/wiki/Yom_Kippur_War" title="Yom Kippur War">Yom Kippur War</a>, 1973</figcaption></figure>
<p>After the death of <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a> in 1970, <a href="/wiki/Anwar_Sadat" title="Anwar Sadat">Anwar Sadat</a> assumed the presidency of Egypt. Sadat consolidated his power by marginalising Nasserist and leftist factions, while controlling opposition both secular and religious. He shifted Egypt's Cold War alignment from the Soviet Union to the United States, expelling Soviet advisors in 1972, and renamed the country the Arab Republic of Egypt in 1971. Sadat launched the <a href="/wiki/Infitah" title="Infitah">Infitah</a> ("open door") economic reforms.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Some measures of this economic liberalisation caused social tensions, most notably the removal of food subsidies in 1977 which sparked widespread <a href="/wiki/1977_Egyptian_bread_riots" title="1977 Egyptian bread riots">bread riots</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Begin,_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Begin%2C_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg/250px-Begin%2C_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Begin%2C_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg/500px-Begin%2C_Carter_and_Sadat_at_Camp_David_1978.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2904" data-file-height="1936" /></a><figcaption>Celebrating the signing of the 1978 <a href="/wiki/Camp_David_Accords" title="Camp David Accords">Camp David Accords</a>: <a href="/wiki/Menachem_Begin" title="Menachem Begin">Menachem Begin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anwar_Sadat" title="Anwar Sadat">Anwar Sadat</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1973, Sadat coordinated with Syria in the <a href="/wiki/Fourth_Arab-Israeli_War" class="mw-redirect" title="Fourth Arab-Israeli War">Fourth Arab-Israeli War</a> to reclaim the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a> from Israeli occupation. Though militarily mixed, the war restored Arab morale and strengthened Sadat's domestic legitimacy.
