His historic 1977 visit to Jerusalem led to the 1979 <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">Egypt-Israel peace treaty</a>, with Israel withdrawing from Sinai and Egypt recognising Israel as a sovereign state. This initiative provoked widespread controversy across the Arab world, resulting in Egypt's temporary expulsion from the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, but remained popular domestically.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Sadat was assassinated in 1981 by an Islamic extremist opposed to his domestic policies and peace initiative.
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG/250px-Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG" decoding="async" width="170" height="222" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG/330px-Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG/392px-Hosni_Mubarak_-_Official_Photo.JPG 2x" data-file-width="392" data-file-height="512" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a>, president of Egypt from 1981 to 2011</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a> succeeded Sadat in a 1981 referendum in which he was the sole candidate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nytimes.com&#95;90-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nytimes.com-90"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> He maintained Egypt's peace treaty with Israel and improved relations with Arab neighbours. Domestically, he faced widespread poverty, high unemployment, and urban overcrowding. The 1986 Security Police riots, sparked by reports of extended military service, led to violent protests, destruction of businesses, and 107 deaths.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Terrorist attacks, particularly by Islamist groups like <a href="/wiki/Al-Gama%27a_al-Islamiyya" class="mw-redirect" title="Al-Gama&#39;a al-Islamiyya">Al-Gama'a al-Islamiyya</a>, targeted government officials, foreigners, and Christian <a href="/wiki/Copts" title="Copts">Copts</a>, devastating tourism, Egypt's primary source of hard currency.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The political scene was dominated by the <a href="/wiki/National_Democratic_Party_(Egypt)" title="National Democratic Party (Egypt)">NDP</a>, which curtailed freedoms of association, expression, and political participation through laws such as the 1993 Syndicates Law, 1995 Press Law, and 1999 NGOs Law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Cairo_north.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Cairo_north.JPG/250px-Cairo_north.JPG" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Cairo_north.JPG/500px-Cairo_north.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="3872" data-file-height="2592" /></a><figcaption>Cairo grew into a <a href="/wiki/Metropolitan_area" title="Metropolitan area">metropolitan area</a> with a population of over 22 million.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-citypopulation2025&#95;95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-citypopulation2025-95"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>In 1997, the <a href="/wiki/Luxor_massacre" title="Luxor massacre">Luxor massacre</a> left 62 dead, mostly tourists, highlighting the continuing threat to security and the economy. In 2005, limited reforms allowed multi-candidate presidential elections, but restrictions on candidates and alleged government interference ensured Mubarak's easy reelection. Voter turnout was less than 25%, and opposition leader <a href="/wiki/Ayman_Nour" title="Ayman Nour">Ayman Nour</a> was subsequently imprisoned.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Human_Rights_Watch" title="Human Rights Watch">Human Rights Watch</a> and <a href="/wiki/Amnesty_International" title="Amnesty International">Amnesty International</a> reported widespread human rights abuses, including torture, arbitrary detention, and the use of Egypt as an international "torture hub" in the context of the <a href="/wiki/War_on_terror" title="War on terror">war on terror</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-HRW&#95;97-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HRW-97"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Constitutional changes in 2007 further expanded presidential powers, restricted religious parties, and broadened police authority. Egypt remained under strong military influence, described by officials as a "pharaonic" system, with democracy as a distant aspiration.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Contemporary_(2011–present)"><span id="Contemporary_.282011.E2.80.93present.29"></span>Contemporary (2011–present)</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/2011_Egyptian_revolution" title="2011 Egyptian revolution">2011 Egyptian revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Crisis_(2011%E2%80%932014)" title="Egyptian Crisis (2011–2014)">Egyptian Crisis (2011–2014)</a>, <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_protests" class="mw-redirect" title="2013 Egyptian protests">2013 Egyptian protests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d&#39;état">2013 Egyptian coup d'état</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png/250px-Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png" decoding="async" width="200" height="128" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png/330px-Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png/500px-Tahrir_Square_on_February11.png 2x" data-file-width="720" data-file-height="462" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg/250px-TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="134" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg/330px-TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5b/TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg/500px-TahrirSquareAgainstMorsi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="686" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><b>Top:</b> Celebrations in <a href="/wiki/Tahrir_Square" title="Tahrir Square">Tahrir Square</a> after the announcement of <a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a>'s resignation, 2011.<br /><b>Bottom:</b> Protests in Tahrir Square against <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi" title="Mohamed Morsi">Morsi</a>, 2012.</div></div></div></div>
<p>On 25 January 2011, <a href="/wiki/2011_Egyptian_revolution" title="2011 Egyptian revolution">widespread protests</a> erupted against President Hosni Mubarak's government, triggered by demands for political freedom, social justice, and the end of long-standing corruption. Demonstrations rapidly spread across major cities, particularly in <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Tahrir_Square" title="Tahrir Square">Tahrir Square</a>, capturing global attention.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After 18 days of escalating unrest, Mubarak resigned on 11 February 2011 and fled Cairo. The <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_military" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian military">Egyptian military</a> assumed control, with <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Hussein_Tantawi" class="mw-redirect" title="Mohamed Hussein Tantawi">Mohamed Hussein Tantawi</a>, chairman of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Council_of_the_Armed_Forces" title="Supreme Council of the Armed Forces">Supreme Council of the Armed Forces</a>, acting as interim head of state.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> On 13 February, the military dissolved parliament and suspended the constitution.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A constitutional referendum followed on 19 March 2011.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Later that year, Egypt held its first parliamentary elections since the previous regime, with high voter turnout and no major reported irregularities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi" title="Mohamed Morsi">Mohamed Morsi</a>, affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a>, won the <a href="/wiki/2012_Egyptian_presidential_election" title="2012 Egyptian presidential election">presidency</a> on 24 June 2012 and was sworn in on 30 June.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> His cabinet, announced in August 2012, included significant representation from the Muslim Brotherhood, prompting liberal and secular groups to withdraw from the <a href="/wiki/Constituent_Assembly_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Constituent Assembly of Egypt">Constituent Assembly of Egypt</a> over concerns of imposing strict Islamic law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In November 2012, Morsi issued a decree granting immunity to his decisions and protecting the constituent assembly's work, sparking <a href="/wiki/2012%E2%80%932013_Egyptian_protests" title="2012–2013 Egyptian protests">mass protests and violent clashes</a> across the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Tensions escalated, with the largest confrontations between Islamist supporters and opponents since the 2011 revolution occurring on 5 December 2012.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Morsi refused to cancel the December 2012 <a href="/wiki/2012_Egyptian_constitutional_referendum" title="2012 Egyptian constitutional referendum">constitutional referendum</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following growing public discontent, the <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d&#39;état">military removed Morsi</a> on 3 July 2013, dissolved the <a href="/wiki/Senate_(Egypt)" title="Senate (Egypt)">Shura Council</a>, and installed <a href="/wiki/Adly_Mansour" title="Adly Mansour">Adly Mansour</a>, chief justice of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Constitutional_Court_(Egypt)" title="Supreme Constitutional Court (Egypt)">Supreme Constitutional Court</a>, as interim president.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Authorities cracked down on the Muslim Brotherhood, jailing thousands and conducting mass trials. Violence during <a href="/wiki/Rabaa_massacre" title="Rabaa massacre">dispersals of pro-Morsi camps</a> left hundreds dead.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A new <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Egypt" title="Constitution of Egypt">constitution</a> was approved by referendum on 18 January 2014 with 98.1% voting in favour.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a> won the <a href="/wiki/2014_Egyptian_presidential_election" title="2014 Egyptian presidential election">presidential elections</a> in June 2014 with 96.1% of the vote and was sworn in on 8 June. Under his rule, Egypt intensified security on the Gaza border, dismantled tunnels between Sinai and Gaza, and consolidated political power. Presidential terms were extended to six years in 2019, allowing El-Sisi to run for a third term in 2024. Parliamentary elections in 2020 confirmed a pro-El-Sisi majority for the <a href="/wiki/Nation%27s_Future_Party" title="Nation&#39;s Future Party">Mostaqbal Watan Party</a>. The constitutional reforms and strengthened military authority under El-Sisi have been described as a return to authoritarianism.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In December 2023, El-Sisi won the elections that gave him a third six-year term.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Geography">Geography</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Egypt" title="Geography of Egypt">Geography of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egypt_Topography.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Egypt_Topography.png/250px-Egypt_Topography.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="241" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Egypt_Topography.png/384px-Egypt_Topography.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8b/Egypt_Topography.png 2x" data-file-width="384" data-file-height="370" /></a><figcaption>Egypt's topography</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt lies primarily between latitudes <a href="/wiki/22nd_parallel_north" class="mw-redirect" title="22nd parallel north">22°</a> and <a href="/wiki/32nd_parallel_north" class="mw-redirect" title="32nd parallel north">32°N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/25th_meridian_east" title="25th meridian east">25°</a> and <a href="/wiki/35th_meridian_east" title="35th meridian east">35°E</a>. At 1,001,450 square kilometres (386,660&#160;sq&#160;mi), it is the world's 29th largest country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Due to the extreme aridity of Egypt's climate, population centres are concentrated along the narrow Nile Valley and Delta, meaning that about 99% of the population uses about 5.5% of the total land area.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> 98% of Egyptians live on 3% of the territory.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Sand_Dunes_(Qattara_Depression).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Sand_Dunes_%28Qattara_Depression%29.jpg/250px-Sand_Dunes_%28Qattara_Depression%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Sand_Dunes_%28Qattara_Depression%29.jpg/500px-Sand_Dunes_%28Qattara_Depression%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3888" data-file-height="2592" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Qattara_Depression" title="Qattara Depression">Qattara Depression</a> in Egypt's north west</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt is bordered by Libya to the west, the Sudan to the south, and the Gaza Strip and Israel to the east. A <a href="/wiki/Transcontinental_nation" class="mw-redirect" title="Transcontinental nation">transcontinental nation</a>, it possesses a land bridge (the Isthmus of Suez) between Africa and Asia, traversed by a navigable waterway (the <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>) that <a href="/wiki/Indo-Mediterranean" title="Indo-Mediterranean">connects the Mediterranean Sea with the Indian Ocean</a> by way of the Red Sea.
</p><p>Apart from the Nile Valley, the majority of Egypt's landscape is desert, with a few <a href="/wiki/Oasis" title="Oasis">oases</a> scattered about. Winds create prolific <a href="/wiki/Dune" title="Dune">sand dunes</a> that peak at more than 30 metres (100&#160;ft) high. Egypt includes parts of the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a> desert and of the <a href="/wiki/Libyan_Desert" title="Libyan Desert">Libyan Desert</a>.
</p><p>Sinai peninsula hosts the highest mountain in Egypt, <a href="/wiki/Mount_Catherine" title="Mount Catherine">Mount Catherine</a> at 2,642 metres. The <a href="/wiki/Red_Sea_Riviera" title="Red Sea Riviera">Red Sea Riviera</a>, on the east of the peninsula, is renowned for its wealth of coral reefs and marine life.
</p><p>Towns and cities include <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, the second largest city; <a href="/wiki/Aswan" title="Aswan">Aswan</a>; <a href="/wiki/Asyut" title="Asyut">Asyut</a>; <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>, the modern Egyptian capital and largest city; <a href="/wiki/El_Mahalla_El_Kubra" title="El Mahalla El Kubra">El Mahalla El Kubra</a>; <a href="/wiki/Giza" title="Giza">Giza</a>, the site of the Pyramid of Khufu; <a href="/wiki/Hurghada" title="Hurghada">Hurghada</a>; <a href="/wiki/Luxor" title="Luxor">Luxor</a>; <a href="/wiki/Kom_Ombo" title="Kom Ombo">Kom Ombo</a>; <a href="/wiki/Port_Safaga" class="mw-redirect" title="Port Safaga">Port Safaga</a>; <a href="/wiki/Port_Said" title="Port Said">Port Said</a>; <a href="/wiki/Sharm_El_Sheikh" title="Sharm El Sheikh">Sharm El Sheikh</a>; <a href="/wiki/Suez" title="Suez">Suez</a>, where the south end of the Suez Canal is located; <a href="/wiki/Zagazig" title="Zagazig">Zagazig</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Minya,_Egypt" title="Minya, Egypt">Minya</a>. <a href="/wiki/Oasis" title="Oasis">Oases</a> include <a href="/wiki/Bahariya_Oasis" title="Bahariya Oasis">Bahariya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dakhla_Oasis" title="Dakhla Oasis">Dakhla</a>, <a href="/wiki/Farafra,_Egypt" title="Farafra, Egypt">Farafra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kharga_Oasis" title="Kharga Oasis">Kharga</a> and <a href="/wiki/Siwa_Oasis" title="Siwa Oasis">Siwa</a>. <a href="/wiki/Protectorates" class="mw-redirect" title="Protectorates">Protectorates</a> include Ras Mohamed National Park, Zaranik Protectorate and Siwa.
</p><p>On 13 March 2015, plans for a <a href="/wiki/Proposed_new_capital_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Proposed new capital of Egypt">proposed new capital of Egypt</a> were announced.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Climate">Climate</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Egypt" title="Climate of Egypt">Climate of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Temperature_Bar_Chart_Africa-Egypt--1901-2020--2021-07-13.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Temperature_Bar_Chart_Africa-Egypt--1901-2020--2021-07-13.png/250px-Temperature_Bar_Chart_Africa-Egypt--1901-2020--2021-07-13.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="141" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/68/Temperature_Bar_Chart_Africa-Egypt--1901-2020--2021-07-13.png/500px-Temperature_Bar_Chart_Africa-Egypt--1901-2020--2021-07-13.png 1.5x" data-file-width="3780" data-file-height="2126" /></a><figcaption>Graphic of the increase in temperature in Egypt overtime</figcaption></figure>
<p>Most of Egypt's rain falls in the winter months.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> South of Cairo, rainfall averages only around 2 to 5&#160;mm (0.1 to 0.2&#160;in) per year and at intervals of many years. On a very thin strip of the northern coast the rainfall can be as high as 410&#160;mm (16.1&#160;in),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> mostly between October and March. Snow falls on Sinai's mountains and some of the north coastal cities such as <a href="/wiki/Damietta" title="Damietta">Damietta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baltim" title="Baltim">Baltim</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sidi_Barrani" title="Sidi Barrani">Sidi Barrani</a>, and rarely in Alexandria. A very small amount of snow fell on Cairo on 13 December 2013, the first time in many decades.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Frost" title="Frost">Frost</a> is also known in mid-Sinai and mid-Egypt.
</p><p>Egypt has an unusually hot, sunny and dry climate. Average high temperatures are high in the north but very to extremely high in the rest of the country during summer. The cooler Mediterranean winds consistently blow over the northern sea coast, which helps to get more moderated temperatures, especially at the height of the summertime. The <a href="/wiki/Khamaseen" class="mw-redirect" title="Khamaseen">Khamaseen</a> is a hot, dry wind that originates from the vast deserts in the south and blows in the spring or in the early summer. It brings scorching sand and dust particles, and usually brings daytime temperatures over 40&#160;°C (104&#160;°F) and sometimes over 50&#160;°C (122&#160;°F) in the interior, while the relative humidity can drop to 5% or even less.
</p><p>Prior to the construction of the <a href="/wiki/Aswan_Dam" title="Aswan Dam">Aswan Dam</a>, the Nile flooded annually, replenishing Egypt's soil. This gave Egypt a consistent harvest throughout the years.
</p><p>Egypt's hot and arid climate is increasingly strained by climate change, leading to extreme temperatures, droughts, floods, and rising sea levels.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As a highly vulnerable nation, these environmental shifts threaten food security, water availability, public health, and economic stability.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Biodiversity">Biodiversity</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Wildlife_of_Egypt" title="Wildlife of Egypt">Wildlife of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Eastern_Imperial_Eagle_cr.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Eastern_Imperial_Eagle_cr.jpg/250px-Eastern_Imperial_Eagle_cr.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="241" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Eastern_Imperial_Eagle_cr.jpg/500px-Eastern_Imperial_Eagle_cr.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="660" data-file-height="636" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Imperial_Eagle" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Imperial Eagle">Eastern Imperial Eagle</a> is the national animal of Egypt.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt signed the Rio <a href="/wiki/Convention_on_Biological_Diversity" title="Convention on Biological Diversity">Convention on Biological Diversity</a> on 9 June 1992, and became a party to the convention on 2 June 1994.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It has subsequently produced a <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_Action_Plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Biodiversity Action Plan">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plan</a>, which was received by the convention on 31 July 1998.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Where many <a href="/wiki/Center_for_Biological_Diversity" title="Center for Biological Diversity">CBD</a> <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity_Action_Plan" class="mw-redirect" title="Biodiversity Action Plan">National Biodiversity Strategy and Action Plans</a> neglect biological kingdoms apart from animals and plants,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The plan stated that the following numbers of species of different groups had been recorded from Egypt: algae (1483 species), animals (about 15,000 species of which more than 10,000 were insects), fungi (more than 627 species), monera (319 species), plants (2426 species), protozoans (371 species). For some major groups, for example lichen-forming fungi and nematode worms, the number was not known. Apart from small and well-studied groups like amphibians, birds, fish, mammals and reptiles, the many of those numbers are likely to increase as further species are recorded from Egypt. For the fungi, including lichen-forming species, for example, subsequent work has shown that over 2200 species have been recorded from Egypt, and the final figure of all fungi actually occurring in the country is expected to be much higher.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> For the grasses, 284 native and naturalised species have been identified and recorded in Egypt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Government">Government</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Egypt" title="Politics of Egypt">Politics of Egypt</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:156px;max-width:156px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:AbdelFattah_Elsisi_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/AbdelFattah_Elsisi_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-AbdelFattah_Elsisi_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="154" height="194" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/AbdelFattah_Elsisi_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-AbdelFattah_Elsisi_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="703" data-file-height="885" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/President_of_Egypt" title="President of Egypt">President</a> </small></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:132px;max-width:132px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:194px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Mostafa_Madbouly_(2023).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Mostafa_Madbouly_%282023%29.jpg/250px-Mostafa_Madbouly_%282023%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="130" height="195" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Mostafa_Madbouly_%282023%29.jpg/330px-Mostafa_Madbouly_%282023%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2667" data-file-height="4000" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Mostafa_Madbouly" title="Mostafa Madbouly">Mostafa Madbouly</a><br /><small><a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Egypt" title="Prime Minister of Egypt">Prime Minister</a> </small></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/House_of_Representatives_(Egypt)" title="House of Representatives (Egypt)">House of Representatives</a>, whose members are elected to serve five-year terms, specialises in legislation. <a href="/wiki/Elections_in_Egypt" title="Elections in Egypt">Elections</a> were held between <a href="/wiki/2011%E2%80%9312_Egyptian_parliamentary_election" title="2011–12 Egyptian parliamentary election">November 2011 and January 2012</a>, which were later dissolved.
</p><p>After a wave of public discontent with the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> government of President <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Morsi" title="Mohamed Morsi">Mohamed Morsi</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-morsi-think-again&#95;135-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-morsi-think-again-135"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> on 3 July 2013 then-<a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Army_ranks" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Army ranks">General</a> <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a> announced the removal of Morsi from office and the suspension of the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Constitution_of_2012" title="Egyptian Constitution of 2012">constitution</a>. A 50-member constitution committee was formed for modifying <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Constitution_of_2014" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Constitution of 2014">the constitution</a>, which was later published for <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_constitutional_referendum,_2014" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2014">public voting</a> and was adopted on 18 January 2014.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Egyptian_parliamentary_election,_2015" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian parliamentary election, 2015">The next parliamentary election</a> was announced to be held within 6 months of the constitution's ratification on 18 January 2014, and were held in two phases, from 17 October to 2 December 2015.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ao30aug&#95;137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ao30aug-137"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Originally, the parliament was to be formed before the president was elected, but interim president <a href="/wiki/Adly_Mansour" title="Adly Mansour">Adly Mansour</a> pushed the date.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2014_Egyptian_presidential_election" title="2014 Egyptian presidential election">2014 Egyptian presidential election</a> took place on 26–28 May. Official figures showed a turnout of 25,578,233 or 47.5%, with <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a> winning with 23.78 million votes, or 96.9% compared to 757,511 (3.1%) for <a href="/wiki/Hamdeen_Sabahi" title="Hamdeen Sabahi">Hamdeen Sabahi</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2024, as part of its <a href="/wiki/Freedom_in_the_World" title="Freedom in the World">Freedom in the World</a> report, <a href="/wiki/Freedom_House" title="Freedom House">Freedom House</a> rated <a href="/wiki/Political_rights" class="mw-redirect" title="Political rights">political rights</a> in Egypt at 6 (with 40 representing the most free and 0 the least), and <a href="/wiki/Civil_liberties" title="Civil liberties">civil liberties</a> at 12 (with 60 being the highest score and 0 the lowest), which gave it the freedom rating of "Not Free".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> According to the 2023 <a href="/wiki/V-Dem_Democracy_indices" class="mw-redirect" title="V-Dem Democracy indices">V-Dem Democracy indices</a> Egypt is the eighth least <a href="/wiki/Democracy_in_Africa" title="Democracy in Africa">democratic country in Africa</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-vdem&#95;dataset&#95;141-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vdem_dataset-141"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The 2023 edition of <a href="/wiki/The_Economist_Democracy_Index" title="The Economist Democracy Index">The Economist Democracy Index</a> categorises Egypt as an "authoritarian regime", with a score of 2.93.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt has the oldest continuous parliamentary tradition in the Arab world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-pogar&#95;143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pogar-143"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The first popular assembly was established in 1866. It was disbanded as a result of the British occupation of 1882, and the British allowed only a consultative body to sit. In 1923, however, after the country's independence was declared, a new constitution provided for a parliamentary monarchy.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-pogar&#95;143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pogar-143"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Egypt" title="Foreign relations of Egypt">Foreign relations of Egypt</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:189px;max-width:189px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:187px;max-width:187px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg/250px-Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg" decoding="async" width="185" height="112" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg/330px-Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg/500px-Hosni_Mubarak_with_George_W._Bush.jpg 2x" data-file-width="515" data-file-height="313" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:187px;max-width:187px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_(1).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_%281%29.jpg/250px-Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="185" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_%281%29.jpg/330px-Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_%281%29.jpg/500px-Sisi_and_Putin_meeting_on_16_August_2014_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="650" data-file-height="434" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">Top: Former President <a href="/wiki/Hosni_Mubarak" title="Hosni Mubarak">Hosni Mubarak</a> with former US President <a href="/wiki/George_W._Bush" title="George W. Bush">George W. Bush</a> at Camp David in 2002.<br />Bottom: President <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a> and Russian President <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Putin" title="Vladimir Putin">Vladimir Putin</a> in Sochi, August 2014.</div></div></div></div>
<p>Egypt's foreign policy is shaped by its strategic geographical position, historical legacy, and diplomatic influence in Africa, the Mediterranean, and Southwest Asia. As a founding member of the <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> and the United Nations, Egypt has maintained a non-aligned stance while playing a pivotal role in regional diplomacy. Cairo, historically a crossroads of commerce and culture, remains a centre of intellectual and political influence in the region.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93United_States_relations" title="Egypt–United States relations">United States</a> has been a key partner, providing Egypt with US$1.3 billion in annual military assistance as of 2015.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1989, Egypt was designated a <a href="/wiki/Major_non-NATO_ally" title="Major non-NATO ally">major non-NATO ally</a>, but relations soured following the <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d&#39;état">2013 Egyptian coup d'état</a>, as the <a href="/wiki/Obama_administration" class="mw-redirect" title="Obama administration">Obama administration</a> criticised Egypt's crackdown on the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_Brotherhood" title="Muslim Brotherhood">Muslim Brotherhood</a> and suspended joint military exercises.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under President <a href="/wiki/Donald_Trump" title="Donald Trump">Donald Trump</a>, relations improved, with <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Fattah_el-Sisi" title="Abdel Fattah el-Sisi">Abdel Fattah el-Sisi</a>'s 2017 visit to the White House marking the first by an Egyptian president in eight years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Relations with <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Russia_relations" title="Egypt–Russia relations">Russia</a> strengthened after Morsi's removal, with both nations expanding military cooperation<sup id="cite&#95;ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and trade relations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Similarly, <a href="/wiki/China%E2%80%93Egypt_relations" title="China–Egypt relations">relations with China</a> have deepened, culminating in the establishment of a "comprehensive strategic partnership" in 2014.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2024, Egypt and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> elevated their relationship to a "strategic and comprehensive partnership", emphasising political cooperation, and economic collaboration. Additionally, both sides are working on deepening trade relations under the Association Agreement, supporting Egypt's economic stability, and strengthening counterterrorism efforts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt remains an influential mediator in Middle Eastern conflicts, particularly in brokering ceasefires in Gaza and facilitating the <a href="/wiki/Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian_peace_process" title="Israeli–Palestinian peace process">Israeli–Palestinian peace process</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is also a Member State of the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, hosting the Arab League headquarters in Cairo. The Arab League temporarily moved to Tunis in 1978 in protest of the <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Israel_peace_treaty" title="Egypt–Israel peace treaty">Egypt–Israel peace treaty</a>, but returned to Cairo in 1989. Egypt has also cultivated strong economic ties with Gulf nations such as <a href="/wiki/Egypt%E2%80%93Saudi_Arabia_relations" title="Egypt–Saudi Arabia relations">Saudi Arabia</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates" title="United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a>, both of which have provided billions of dollars in financial assistance.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Military">Military</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Armed_Forces" title="Egyptian Armed Forces">Egyptian Armed Forces</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Military_industry_of_Egypt" title="Military industry of Egypt">Military industry of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Defense.gov_photo_essay_090421-N-0696M-106.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Defense.gov_photo_essay_090421-N-0696M-106.jpg/250px-Defense.gov_photo_essay_090421-N-0696M-106.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="171" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Defense.gov_photo_essay_090421-N-0696M-106.jpg/500px-Defense.gov_photo_essay_090421-N-0696M-106.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2100" data-file-height="1433" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Republican_Guard" title="Egyptian Republican Guard">Egyptian honour guard soldiers</a> in 2009</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Armed_Forces" title="Egyptian Armed Forces">Egyptian Armed Forces</a> constitute Egypt's military establishment, comprising the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Army" title="Egyptian Army">Egyptian Army</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Navy" title="Egyptian Navy">Navy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Air_Force" title="Egyptian Air Force">Air Force</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Air_Defence_Forces" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Air Defence Forces">Air Defense Forces</a> under the direct supervision of the Chief of Staff,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with their headquarters at the <a href="/wiki/The_Octagon_(Egypt)" title="The Octagon (Egypt)">State Strategic Command Center</a>, commonly known as the Octagon, in the <a href="/wiki/New_Administrative_Capital" class="mw-redirect" title="New Administrative Capital">New Administrative Capital</a>. The military primarily oversees external defence but also plays a domestic role, assisting police in protecting vital infrastructure during emergencies and counterterrorism operations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-NYT&#95;2011&#95;154-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_2011-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> They also participate in foreign peacekeeping missions and engage in bilateral and multinational military exercises.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIA-military&#95;155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-military-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The military wields significant political influence, operating autonomously and remaining exempt from many civilian laws.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-NYT&#95;2011&#95;154-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_2011-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A significant amount of military information is not made publicly available, including budget information, the names of the general officers and the military's size (which is considered a state secret).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-NYT&#95;2011&#95;154-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT_2011-154"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In addition, the military is a major driver of Egypt's economic landscape, engaging in infrastructure development, consumer goods production, and real estate holdings through the <a href="/wiki/National_Service_Products_Organization" title="National Service Products Organization">National Service Projects Organization</a>.
</p><p>With an active personnel strength of 438,500 and 479,000 reservists,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> it is one of the largest and best-equipped militaries in the region.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIA-military&#95;155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-military-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Conscription is mandatory for men aged 18–30, with service obligations ranging from 14 to 36 months, depending on educational level, followed by a nine-year reserve duty. Voluntary enlistment is possible from age 16 for men and 17 for women.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIA-military&#95;155-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-military-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The military operates a diverse arsenal sourced primarily from China, France, Germany, Italy, Russia, and the United States. Recent efforts have focused on modernisation and procurement of advanced weaponry.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIA-military&#95;155-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-military-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The domestic defence industry is also well-established, manufacturing small arms, armoured vehicles, and naval vessels, while maintaining licensed production agreements with countries such as <a href="/wiki/Germany" title="Germany">Germany</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-CIA-military&#95;155-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CIA-military-155"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt is one of few countries in the region to possess spy satellites, launching <a href="/wiki/EgyptSat_1" title="EgyptSat 1">EgyptSat 1</a> in 2007,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/EgyptSat_2" title="EgyptSat 2">EgyptSat 2</a> in 2014.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2019, Egypt launched MisrSat-A, an observation satellite,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> followed later that year by Tiba-1, a civilian and military communications satellite.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, Egypt launched Horus-1 and Horus-2, about a month apart. The country also placed MisrSat-2 into orbit later that year. All three of them are high-resolution observation satellites.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>157<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>158<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>159<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, two months after MisrSat-2's launch, the country successfully completed the initial operational phase of NEXSAT-1, its first experimental Earth observation satellite, achieving milestones such as developing indigenous onboard software, advanced attitude-control systems, and independently capturing and processing satellite imagery, all of which marked a major step forward in Egypt's national space capabilities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>160<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Law">Law</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Civil_Code" title="Egyptian Civil Code">Egyptian Civil Code</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg/330px-Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="174" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg/500px-Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/63/Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg/960px-Egyptian_High_Court_of_Justice.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3712" data-file-height="2088" /></a><figcaption>The High Court of Justice in <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Cairo" title="Downtown Cairo">Downtown Cairo</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The legal system is based on <a href="/wiki/Sharia_law" class="mw-redirect" title="Sharia law">Islamic</a> and civil law (particularly the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Code" title="Napoleonic Code">Napoleonic Code</a>); and judicial review by a Supreme Court, which accepts compulsory <a href="/wiki/International_Court_of_Justice" title="International Court of Justice">International Court of Justice</a> jurisdiction only with reservations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-factbook-his&#95;81-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-his-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The highest judicial authority of Egypt is the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Constitutional_Court_(Egypt)" title="Supreme Constitutional Court (Egypt)">Supreme Constitutional Court</a>, located in the <a href="/wiki/Maadi" title="Maadi">Maadi</a> district of Cairo.
</p><p>Islamic jurisprudence is the principal source of legislation. Sharia courts and qadis are run and licensed by the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Justice_(Egypt)" title="Ministry of Justice (Egypt)">Ministry of Justice</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>161<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The personal status law that regulates matters such as marriage, divorce and child custody is governed by Sharia. In a family court, a woman's testimony is worth half of a man's testimony.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>162<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On 26 December 2012, the Muslim Brotherhood attempted to institutionalise a controversial new constitution. It was approved by the public in a <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_constitutional_referendum,_2012" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian constitutional referendum, 2012">referendum</a> held 15–22 December 2012 with 64% support, but with only 33% electorate participation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>163<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It replaced the <a href="/wiki/2011_Provisional_Constitution_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="2011 Provisional Constitution of Egypt">2011 Provisional Constitution of Egypt</a>, adopted following the revolution.
</p><p>The Penal code was unique as it contains a "<a href="/wiki/Blasphemy_law_in_Egypt" title="Blasphemy law in Egypt">Blasphemy Law</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>164<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The present court system allows a death penalty including against an absent individual <a href="/wiki/Tried_in_absentia" class="mw-redirect" title="Tried in absentia">tried <i>in absentia</i></a>. Several Americans and Canadians were sentenced to death in 2012.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>165<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On 18 January 2014, the interim government successfully institutionalised a more <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Constitution_of_2014" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Constitution of 2014">secular constitution</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BBC&#95;171-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The president is elected to a four-year term and may serve 2 terms.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BBC&#95;171-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The parliament may impeach the president.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BBC&#95;171-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under the constitution, there is a guarantee of gender equality and absolute <a href="/wiki/Freedom_of_Religion" class="mw-redirect" title="Freedom of Religion">freedom of thought</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BBC&#95;171-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The military retains the ability to appoint the national Minister of Defence for the next two full presidential terms since the constitution took effect.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BBC&#95;171-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under the constitution, political parties may not be based on "religion, race, gender or geography".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-BBC&#95;171-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-171"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>166<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Human_rights">Human rights</h4></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Human_rights_in_Egypt" title="Human rights in Egypt">Human rights in Egypt</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/August_2013_Rabaa_massacre" class="mw-redirect" title="August 2013 Rabaa massacre">August 2013 Rabaa massacre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Copts" title="Persecution of Copts">Persecution of Copts</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Neither_Morsi_nor_the_military_-_Egypt%27s_Third_Square_Movement_seeks_an_alternative_vision_for_the_future.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Neither_Morsi_nor_the_military_-_Egypt%27s_Third_Square_Movement_seeks_an_alternative_vision_for_the_future.jpg/250px-Neither_Morsi_nor_the_military_-_Egypt%27s_Third_Square_Movement_seeks_an_alternative_vision_for_the_future.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Neither_Morsi_nor_the_military_-_Egypt%27s_Third_Square_Movement_seeks_an_alternative_vision_for_the_future.jpg/500px-Neither_Morsi_nor_the_military_-_Egypt%27s_Third_Square_Movement_seeks_an_alternative_vision_for_the_future.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1224" data-file-height="816" /></a><figcaption>Protesters from the Third Square movement, which supported neither the former Morsi government nor the Armed Forces, 31 July 2013</figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/National_Council_for_Human_Rights" title="National Council for Human Rights">National Council for Human Rights</a> was established in 2003, but it has faced criticism from activists who argue it serves as a government propaganda tool to justify human rights violations and repressive laws such as the Emergency Law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>167<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>168<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>169<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt has been ranked among the worst countries for religious freedom, with widespread discrimination against minorities such as <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Christians" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Christians">Coptic Christians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%ADs" class="mw-redirect" title="Baháʼís">Baháʼís</a>, and other Muslim sects. A 2009 report by <a href="/wiki/Pew_Forum_on_Religion_%26_Public_Life" class="mw-redirect" title="Pew Forum on Religion &amp; Public Life">Pew Forum on Religion &amp; Public Life</a> ranked Egypt fifth worst globally for religious freedom,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>170<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Commission_on_International_Religious_Freedom" title="United States Commission on International Religious Freedom">United States Commission on International Religious Freedom</a> has placed Egypt on its watch list due to state-tolerated violations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>171<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A 2010 <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew</a> survey found that 84% of Egyptians supported the death penalty for <a href="/wiki/Apostasy_in_Islam" title="Apostasy in Islam">apostasy</a>, 77% backed amputations for theft, and 82% endorsed stoning for <a href="/wiki/Adultery" title="Adultery">adultery</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>172<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since the <a href="/wiki/2013_Egyptian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat" title="2013 Egyptian coup d&#39;état">2013 Egyptian coup d'état</a>, political repression has intensified, with mass arrests and harsh crackdowns on dissent. During the <a href="/wiki/August_2013_Egyptian_raids" class="mw-redirect" title="August 2013 Egyptian raids">August 2013 sit-in dispersal</a>, 595 protesters were killed, making 14 August 2013 the deadliest day in Egypt's modern history.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>173<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>174<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since then, an estimated 60,000 <a href="/wiki/Political_prisoners_in_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Political prisoners in Egypt">political prisoners</a> remain behind bars.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>175<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt has also drawn international condemnation for mass death sentences, including a 2014 ruling sentencing 529 people to death in a single hearing.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>176<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">United Nations</a> and human rights groups have condemned these trials as gross violations of <a href="/wiki/International_law" title="International law">international law</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>177<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/LGBT_rights_in_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="LGBT rights in Egypt">Homosexuality</a> remains <a href="/wiki/De_facto" title="De facto">de facto</a> criminalised, with 95% of Egyptians opposing its acceptance, according to a 2013 <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew</a> survey.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-pewglobal.org&#95;183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pewglobal.org-183"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>178<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A poll by the <a href="/wiki/Thomson_Reuters_Foundation" title="Thomson Reuters Foundation">Thomson Reuters Foundation</a>, based on assessments from specialists in women's rights, ranked Cairo as the worst megacity for women, evaluating cities on sexual harassment, healthcare access, harmful cultural practices, and economic opportunities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>179<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Freedom_of_the_press">Freedom of the press</h4></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a> ranked Egypt in their 2017 <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="Press Freedom Index">World Press Freedom Index</a> at <abbr title="Number">No.</abbr> 160 out of 180 nations. At least 18 journalists were imprisoned in Egypt, as of August&#160;2015<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Egypt&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>. A new anti-terror law was enacted in August 2015 that threatens members of the media with fines ranging from about US$25,000 to $60,000 for the distribution of wrong information on acts of terror inside the country "that differ from official declarations of the Egyptian Department of Defence".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>180<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_Egypt" title="Subdivisions of Egypt">Subdivisions of Egypt</a></div>
<p>Egypt is divided into 27 governorates. The governorates are further divided into regions. The regions contain towns and villages. Each governorate has a capital, sometimes carrying the same name as the governorate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Beckouche2017&#95;186-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Beckouche2017-186"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-center" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egypt_-_Administrative_Divisions_-_Nmbrs_-_colored.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Egypt_-_Administrative_Divisions_-_Nmbrs_-_colored.png/500px-Egypt_-_Administrative_Divisions_-_Nmbrs_-_colored.png" decoding="async" width="500" height="461" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Egypt_-_Administrative_Divisions_-_Nmbrs_-_colored.png/800px-Egypt_-_Administrative_Divisions_-_Nmbrs_-_colored.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/21/Egypt_-_Administrative_Divisions_-_Nmbrs_-_colored.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="738" /></a><figcaption>Governorates of Egypt: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1184024115">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 17em;column-count:2"> <div><ol><li><a href="/wiki/Matrouh_Governorate" title="Matrouh Governorate">Matrouh</a> <span class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Frameless"><a href="/wiki/Matrouh_Governorate" title="Matrouh Governorate"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Matrouh_Governorate-logo.PNG/40px-Matrouh_Governorate-logo.PNG" decoding="async" width="30" height="16" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Matrouh_Governorate-logo.PNG/60px-Matrouh_Governorate-logo.PNG 1.5x" data-file-width="380" data-file-height="200" /></a></span></li><li><a href="/wiki/Alexandria_Governorate" title="Alexandria Governorate">Alexandria</a> <span class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Frameless"><a href="/wiki/Alexandria_Governorate" title="Alexandria Governorate"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e6/Flag_of_Alexandria.svg/40px-Flag_of_Alexandria.svg.png" decoding="async" width="30" height="20" class="mw-file-element" /></a></span></li></ol></div> </div></figcaption></figure>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Economy">Economy</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Egypt" title="Economy of Egypt">Economy of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:GDP_per_capita_development_of_Egypt.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/GDP_per_capita_development_of_Egypt.svg/250px-GDP_per_capita_development_of_Egypt.svg.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="176" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/GDP_per_capita_development_of_Egypt.svg/500px-GDP_per_capita_development_of_Egypt.svg.png 1.5x" data-file-width="850" data-file-height="600" /></a><figcaption>Change in per capita GDP of Egypt, 1820–2018. Figures are inflation-adjusted to 2011 International dollars.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The economy of Egypt is the second-largest in <a href="/wiki/Africa" title="Africa">Africa</a> and ranks <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_GDP_(nominal)" title="List of countries by GDP (nominal)">44th worldwide</a> as of 2025.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IMFAPR2025&#95;21-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IMFAPR2025-21"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is a major <a href="/wiki/Emerging_market" title="Emerging market">emerging market</a> economy, marked by its membership in organisations like the <a href="/wiki/African_Union" title="African Union">African Union</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arab_League" title="Arab League">Arab League</a>, <a href="/wiki/BRICS" title="BRICS">BRICS</a>, and its participation in the <a href="/wiki/African_Continental_Free_Trade_Area" title="African Continental Free Trade Area">African Continental Free Trade Area</a> (AfCFTA).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-intro1&#95;187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-intro1-187"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Egyptian economy has evolved significantly since the early 2000s, transitioning toward a market-oriented system through fiscal and monetary reforms, privatisation efforts, and foreign investment incentives. These measures have contributed to macroeconomic stability and improved unemployment and poverty rates.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:2&#95;188-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-188"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>183<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Despite waves of privatisation and fiscal reforms, the government remains one of the country's largest employers, and state contracts continue to stimulate activity in other sectors of the still partly <a href="/wiki/Socialist_economics" title="Socialist economics">socialised economy</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-britannica-economy&#95;190-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-economy-190"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Construction, particularly large-scale <a href="/wiki/Public_works" title="Public works">public works</a>, has remained a major source of employment and public expenditure.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-britannica-economy&#95;190-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-britannica-economy-190"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, as part of an $8 billion <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a> programme launched in 2024, Egypt has committed to rationalising such spending.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As a result, private investments rose to 47.5% of total executed investments in FY 2024/25, up from 39.6%, while public investment fell to 43.3%. This marks the highest private share in five years and represents a clear shift in Egypt's investment landscape.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
 <figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Central_business_district_2,_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Central_business_district_2%2C_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg/330px-Central_business_district_2%2C_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="169" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Central_business_district_2%2C_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg/500px-Central_business_district_2%2C_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Central_business_district_2%2C_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg/960px-Central_business_district_2%2C_New_Administrative_Capital.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1155" /></a><figcaption>The central business district in Egypt's <a href="/wiki/New_Administrative_Capital" class="mw-redirect" title="New Administrative Capital">new capital</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt is among the world's top five recipients of <a href="/wiki/Remittances" class="mw-redirect" title="Remittances">remittances</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-remittances-dne&#95;193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-remittances-dne-193"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> which have more than doubled over the past decade, rising from $17.1 billion in FY 2015/2016 to a record $36.5 billion in FY 2024/2025, according to data from the <a href="/wiki/Central_Bank_of_Egypt" title="Central Bank of Egypt">Central Bank of Egypt</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> These inflows are crucial for Egypt's foreign reserves and household incomes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-egypt.iom.int&#95;195-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-egypt.iom.int-195"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>International trade is a key component of Egypt's economy, accounting for 40% of GDP according to the <a href="/wiki/World_Bank" class="mw-redirect" title="World Bank">World Bank</a>. The country has pursued broader economic integration through free trade agreements, including the EU-Egypt Association Agreement and <a href="/wiki/African_Continental_Free_Trade_Area" title="African Continental Free Trade Area">AfCFTA</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-trade-lloyd&#95;196-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-trade-lloyd-196"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt's exports have seen significant growth in the past years,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-OEC2023&#95;197-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-OEC2023-197"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the government aims to raise them to $145 billion by 2030.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
