</p><p>Since 1979, Egypt has received substantial <a href="/wiki/United_States_foreign_aid" title="United States foreign aid">United States foreign aid</a>, averaging $1.5 billion annually, with approximately $200 million allocated to economic assistance and the remainder directed toward military aid for procuring weapon systems from American suppliers.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Manufacturing">Manufacturing</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Egypt" title="Automotive industry in Egypt">Automotive industry in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:MCV_C127_EV,_Busworld_Europe_2023,_Brussels_(P1140238).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/MCV_C127_EV%2C_Busworld_Europe_2023%2C_Brussels_%28P1140238%29.jpg/250px-MCV_C127_EV%2C_Busworld_Europe_2023%2C_Brussels_%28P1140238%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/MCV_C127_EV%2C_Busworld_Europe_2023%2C_Brussels_%28P1140238%29.jpg/500px-MCV_C127_EV%2C_Busworld_Europe_2023%2C_Brussels_%28P1140238%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption>The fully electric <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_Commercial_Vehicles" title="Manufacturing Commercial Vehicles">MCV</a> C127 EV, made in Egypt for the German market</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt has the largest manufacturing sector in Africa, accounting for approximately 22% of the continent's total manufacturing value.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under <a href="/wiki/Egypt_Vision_2030" title="Egypt Vision 2030">Egypt Vision 2030</a> and its related development plans, the country has relied on <a href="/wiki/Industrial_parks" class="mw-redirect" title="Industrial parks">industrial parks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Free-trade_zone" title="Free-trade zone">free zones</a> and <a href="/wiki/Special_economic_zones" class="mw-redirect" title="Special economic zones">special economic zones</a> to boost industrialisation and manufacturing.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The industrial base is diverse, spanning <a href="/wiki/Chemical_products" class="mw-redirect" title="Chemical products">chemicals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronics" title="Electronics">electronics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Automotive_manufacturing" class="mw-redirect" title="Automotive manufacturing">automotive manufacturing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pharmaceuticals" class="mw-redirect" title="Pharmaceuticals">pharmaceuticals</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Textiles" class="mw-redirect" title="Textiles">textiles</a>. The chemical industry, one of the largest, includes <a href="/wiki/Plastics" class="mw-redirect" title="Plastics">plastics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rubber" class="mw-redirect" title="Rubber">rubber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Detergents" class="mw-redirect" title="Detergents">detergents</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fertilizers" class="mw-redirect" title="Fertilizers">fertilisers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Glass" title="Glass">glass</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Petrochemicals" class="mw-redirect" title="Petrochemicals">petrochemicals</a> alone contributing about 12% of industrial output, while total sector exports are projected to reach $9 billion in 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Light manufacturing is a pillar of Egypt's industrial base, with several government-led programmes aiming to accelerate its growth.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <i>Egypt Makes Electronics</i> initiative has attracted factories from international firms, including <a href="/wiki/Vivo_(technology_company)" title="Vivo (technology company)">Vivo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Infinix" class="mw-redirect" title="Infinix">Infinix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oppo" title="Oppo">Oppo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Xiaomi" title="Xiaomi">Xiaomi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nokia" title="Nokia">Nokia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electrolux" title="Electrolux">Electrolux</a>, <a href="/wiki/Samsung" title="Samsung">Samsung</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hisense" title="Hisense">Hisense</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beko" title="Beko">Beko</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Haier" title="Haier">Haier</a>, contributing to Egypt's emergence as a regional hub for electronics and home appliance production.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-electronics&#95;205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-electronics-205"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-appliances&#95;206-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-appliances-206"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  The <a href="/wiki/Textile_industry" title="Textile industry">textile industry</a> is also a cornerstone of Egypt's economy, contributing around 12% of export earnings and employing 2.5 million people. It spans the entire production chain from cotton cultivation to finished garments and is globally recognised for its premium <a href="/wiki/Gossypium_barbadense#Egyptian" title="Gossypium barbadense">Giza cotton</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to light manufacturing, heavy industry plays a major role. Egypt is Africa's leading <a href="/wiki/Steel" title="Steel">steel</a> producer and ranks 20th globally, with 9.8 million tons in 2022.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-steel&#95;209-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-steel-209"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egyptian steel company <a href="/wiki/EZDK" class="mw-redirect" title="EZDK">EZDK</a> is the largest in the region, ranked 77th globally in 2020.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The country's <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Egypt" title="Automotive industry in Egypt">automotive industry</a>, led by <a href="/wiki/El_Nasr_Automotive_Manufacturing_Company" title="El Nasr Automotive Manufacturing Company">Nasr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghabbour_Group" class="mw-redirect" title="Ghabbour Group">Ghabbour</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Manufacturing_Commercial_Vehicles" title="Manufacturing Commercial Vehicles">MCV</a>, is expanding through partnerships with global manufacturers under the government's <i>2024–2030 National Automotive Industry Development Strategy</i>, which targets 500,000 vehicles annually and promotes local <a href="/wiki/Electric_vehicle" title="Electric vehicle">electric vehicle</a> production.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-automobiles&#95;211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-automobiles-211"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Retail_and_services">Retail and services</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:National_Bank_of_Egypt-2020.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Bank_of_Egypt-2020.jpg/250px-National_Bank_of_Egypt-2020.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="180" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/National_Bank_of_Egypt-2020.jpg/500px-National_Bank_of_Egypt-2020.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="958" data-file-height="690" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Egypt" title="National Bank of Egypt">National Bank of Egypt</a> towers in <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt's retail and services sector has expanded steadily in recent years, driven by population growth, rising incomes, and urbanisation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oxford-retail&#95;212-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-retail-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As of 2020 the country's retail market, encompassing shopping malls, supermarkets, convenience stores, and e-commerce platforms, was worth around $200 billion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oxford-retail&#95;212-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-retail-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The retail food and grocery sector is still largely dominated by traditional, family-run stores and <a href="/wiki/Wet_markets" class="mw-redirect" title="Wet markets">wet markets</a>, although supermarket and convenience store chains expanded in both size and popularity between 2015 and 2020.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oxford-retail&#95;212-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-retail-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hypermarkets" class="mw-redirect" title="Hypermarkets">Hypermarkets</a> and <a href="/wiki/Discount_store" title="Discount store">wholesale discounters</a> recorded the highest growth rates over this period, at 153% and 162% respectively, accounting for 26% of the sector's sales.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oxford-retail&#95;212-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-retail-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The country has also seen significant growth in <a href="/wiki/Shopping_malls" class="mw-redirect" title="Shopping malls">shopping malls</a>. With over 20 operating malls, <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> has the highest number in the country, while smaller cities such as <a href="/wiki/Mansoura,_Egypt" title="Mansoura, Egypt">Mansoura</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tanta" title="Tanta">Tanta</a> have seen the opening of their first commercial malls in recent years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oxford-retail&#95;212-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oxford-retail-212"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Egyptian government plays a major role in the telecommunications sector through its majority ownership of <a href="/wiki/Telecom_Egypt" title="Telecom Egypt">Telecom Egypt</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Between 2019 and 2022, mobile internet subscriptions in Egypt grew 77.9%, from 39 million to 69.4 million, with total mobile subscriptions reaching 106.2 million by December 2023.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Internet penetration reached 72.2% in early 2024, with 82 million users.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Since 2022 Egypt has the fastest internet speeds in Africa.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-digitalegy&#95;216-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-digitalegy-216"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egyptian banks are among the largest and most dynamic in the region. Most Egyptian lenders are adopting new technologies to expand into nonbanking financial services.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Fintech" class="mw-redirect" title="Fintech">fintech</a> sector has grown 5.5-fold since 2020, with 177 startups, ranking Egypt 10th among emerging markets.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-fintech&#95;218-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-fintech-218"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The banking sector is dominated by four state-owned commercial banks, the <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Egypt" title="National Bank of Egypt">National Bank of Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banque_Misr" title="Banque Misr">Banque Misr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Banque_du_Caire" title="Banque du Caire">Banque du Caire</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_Alexandria" title="Bank of Alexandria">Bank of Alexandria</a>, which together account for about 55% of total banking assets.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Commercial_International_Bank" title="Commercial International Bank">CIB</a> is the country's largest private bank and the third-largest overall.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Hydrocarbons_and_mining">Hydrocarbons and mining</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Mining_industry_of_Egypt" title="Mining industry of Egypt">Mining industry of Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Egypt" title="Energy in Egypt">Energy in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Darfeel_plat.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Darfeel_plat.png/250px-Darfeel_plat.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="202" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Darfeel_plat.png/500px-Darfeel_plat.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1026" data-file-height="830" /></a><figcaption>An offshore platform in the Darfeel Gas Field</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt's oil production is concentrated in the Western Desert, the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Suez" title="Gulf of Suez">Gulf of Suez</a>, and the Nile Delta, with peak crude oil output reaching approximately 941,000&#160;bbl/d (149,600&#160;m<sup>3</sup>/d) in 1993 before declining to 630,000&#160;bbl/d (100,000&#160;m<sup>3</sup>/d) by 2008.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-The&#95;World&#95;Factbook&#95;221-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_World_Factbook-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This decline transformed Egypt into a net oil importer by 2008–2009, prompting a strategic shift toward natural gas.
</p><p>Natural gas has since become central to Egypt's economy, drawing major foreign investment.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-The&#95;World&#95;Factbook&#95;221-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_World_Factbook-221"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Zohr_gas_field" class="mw-redirect" title="Zohr gas field">Zohr gas field</a>, discovered by <a href="/wiki/Eni" title="Eni">Eni</a> in 2015, is the Mediterranean's largest reserve, containing about 30 trillion cubic feet of gas. Production began in 2017 and reached 2.7 billion cubic feet per day (bcf/d) by 2019,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> greatly enhancing Egypt's energy outlook, though recent technical issues have reduced output; new drilling is planned to restore capacity.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/BP" title="BP">BP</a> has made major investments, including a $12 billion commitment in 2015 to the West Nile Delta project, along with other developments such as Atoll, North Damietta, and Qattameya, which began production in 2020.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt possesses substantial mineral wealth, with deposits of <a href="/wiki/Gold" title="Gold">gold</a>, <a href="/wiki/Copper" title="Copper">copper</a>, <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Phosphate" title="Phosphate">phosphate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Uranium" title="Uranium">uranium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tantalum" title="Tantalum">tantalum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Manganese" title="Manganese">manganese</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chromium" title="Chromium">chromium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coal" title="Coal">coal</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lead" title="Lead">lead</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tin" title="Tin">tin</a>, and black sand minerals such as <a href="/wiki/Ilmenite" title="Ilmenite">ilmenite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zircon" title="Zircon">zircon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rutile" title="Rutile">rutile</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Magnetite" title="Magnetite">magnetite</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-minerals&#95;226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-minerals-226"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It also produces abundant industrial materials like <a href="/wiki/Granite" title="Granite">granite</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marble" title="Marble">marble</a>, <a href="/wiki/Limestone" title="Limestone">limestone</a>, white sand, <a href="/wiki/Kaolin" class="mw-redirect" title="Kaolin">kaolin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Feldspar" title="Feldspar">feldspar</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-minerals&#95;226-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-minerals-226"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Gold_mining" title="Gold mining">gold mining</a> sector has grown rapidly following investment reforms and exploration bids involving <a href="/wiki/AngloGold_Ashanti" title="AngloGold Ashanti">AngloGold Ashanti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Nubia_International" class="mw-redirect" title="Alexander Nubia International">Alexander Nubia International</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Sukari_mine" title="Sukari mine">Sukari mine</a> remains the core operation, with the sector's GDP share expected to reach 5–6% by 2030.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Gold exports doubled to $2.17 billion in 2024, with Egypt aiming to join the world's top ten exporters by 2027.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-gold-xin&#95;229-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gold-xin-229"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Agriculture">Agriculture</h3></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egyptian_Countryside_R02.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Egyptian_Countryside_R02.jpg/250px-Egyptian_Countryside_R02.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="164" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/Egyptian_Countryside_R02.jpg/500px-Egyptian_Countryside_R02.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3952" data-file-height="2599" /></a><figcaption>Farmland in the Egyptian countryside</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt's agricultural sector remains essential to its economy, though its share of GDP and employment has declined over time. Egypt produces substantial quantities of <a href="/wiki/Wheat" title="Wheat">wheat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maize" title="Maize">maize</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugarcane" title="Sugarcane">sugarcane</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fruits" class="mw-redirect" title="Fruits">fruits</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vegetables" class="mw-redirect" title="Vegetables">vegetables</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fodder" title="Fodder">fodder</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, yet remains reliant on wheat and maize imports, primarily from Ukraine and Russia, despite yield improvements since 1970.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IbrahimIbrahim2003&#95;230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IbrahimIbrahim2003-230"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  This dependency stems from high domestic demand, driven by subsidies and a <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_cuisine#Bread" title="Egyptian cuisine">culinary preference for bread</a>, as well as Egypt's limited arable land and its emphasis on high-value export crops.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IbrahimIbrahim2003&#95;230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IbrahimIbrahim2003-230"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2024, Egypt exported $4.1 billion in agricultural goods<sup id="cite&#95;ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and roughly $6.1 billion in food industry products.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The country has achieved self-sufficiency in several key agricultural products, including <a href="/wiki/Vegetables" class="mw-redirect" title="Vegetables">vegetables</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fruits" class="mw-redirect" title="Fruits">fruits</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">poultry</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dairy" title="Dairy">dairy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eggs_as_food" title="Eggs as food">eggs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rice" title="Rice">rice</a>, while nearing full self-sufficiency in <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fish" title="Fish">fish</a>, with production reaching approximately 90% of demand.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Self-sufficiency ratios are lower for <a href="/wiki/Red_meat" title="Red meat">red meat</a> (60%),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Cereals" class="mw-redirect" title="Cereals">cereals</a> (58%), <a href="/wiki/Vegetable_oils" class="mw-redirect" title="Vegetable oils">vegetable oils</a> (26%), and <a href="/wiki/Food_oil" class="mw-redirect" title="Food oil">oil crops</a> (35%). Consequently, Egypt relies on imports for roughly 45% of its domestic food demand.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Aswan_High_Dam" class="mw-redirect" title="Aswan High Dam">Aswan High Dam</a>, completed in 1971, significantly improved irrigation stability.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2010, 3.6 million hectares were cultivated, with the government targeting 4.8 million hectares by 2030.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-faoun&#95;238-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-faoun-238"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Major initiatives include the New Delta and <a href="/wiki/Toshka_Project" class="mw-redirect" title="Toshka Project">Toshka Project</a>, designed to convert desert areas into farmland using advanced irrigation techniques, <a href="/wiki/Wastewater_treatment" title="Wastewater treatment">wastewater treatment</a>, <a href="/wiki/Groundwater" title="Groundwater">groundwater</a> and water <a href="/wiki/Desalination" title="Desalination">desalination</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Efforts to deregulate agriculture have improved price alignment with global markets, but climate change and water scarcity continue to pose long-term challenges.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tourism">Tourism</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Egypt" title="Tourism in Egypt">Tourism in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Camel_and_the_pyramids.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Camel_and_the_pyramids.jpg/250px-Camel_and_the_pyramids.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Camel_and_the_pyramids.jpg/500px-Camel_and_the_pyramids.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3300" data-file-height="2200" /></a><figcaption>Tourists riding a <a href="/wiki/Arabian_camel" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabian camel">camel</a> in front of <a href="/wiki/Pyramid_of_Khafre" title="Pyramid of Khafre">Pyramid of Khafre</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Giza_Necropolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Giza Necropolis">Giza Necropolis</a> is one of Egypt's main tourist attractions.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Tourism is one of the most important sectors in Egypt's economy. 2024 saw a record 15.7 million tourists, surpassing 14.9 million in 2023. This growth, driven by government efforts to enhance security and tourism support, reflects a strong recovery from the pandemic-induced decline of 2020. Tourism revenues have also surged, reaching $14.1 billion, reflecting steady improvement over previous years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-tourism&#95;240-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tourism-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt's tourism strategy aims to attract 30 million tourists by 2028, with a focus on infrastructure improvements, high-profile projects like the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Egyptian_Museum" title="Grand Egyptian Museum">Grand Egyptian Museum</a>, and enhancing visitor experiences. In 2024, the country's top tourism markets included Germany, Russia, and Saudi Arabia.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-tourism&#95;240-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tourism-240"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
The <a href="/wiki/Giza_Necropolis" class="mw-redirect" title="Giza Necropolis">Giza Necropolis</a> is one of Egypt's best-known tourist attractions; it is the only one of the <a href="/wiki/Seven_Wonders_of_the_Ancient_World" title="Seven Wonders of the Ancient World">Seven Wonders of the Ancient World</a> still in existence.
</p><p>Egypt's beaches on the Mediterranean and the Red Sea, which extend to over 3,000 kilometres (1,900 miles), are also popular tourist destinations; the <a href="/wiki/Gulf_of_Aqaba" title="Gulf of Aqaba">Gulf of Aqaba</a> beaches, <a href="/wiki/Safaga" title="Safaga">Safaga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sharm_el-Sheikh" class="mw-redirect" title="Sharm el-Sheikh">Sharm el-Sheikh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hurghada" title="Hurghada">Hurghada</a>, <a href="/wiki/Luxor" title="Luxor">Luxor</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dahab" title="Dahab">Dahab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ras_Sidr" class="mw-redirect" title="Ras Sidr">Ras Sidr</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marsa_Alam" title="Marsa Alam">Marsa Alam</a> are popular sites.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Infrastructure">Infrastructure</h2></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Energy">Energy</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Egypt" title="Energy in Egypt">Energy in Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Electricity_sector_in_Egypt" title="Electricity sector in Egypt">Electricity sector in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Aswan_Dam.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Aswan_Dam.jpg/250px-Aswan_Dam.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="166" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Aswan_Dam.jpg/500px-Aswan_Dam.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="603" data-file-height="400" /></a><figcaption>Power plant of the <a href="/wiki/Aswan_High_Dam" class="mw-redirect" title="Aswan High Dam">Aswan High Dam</a>, with the dam itself in the background</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt's electricity sector has shifted from full state control to a more diversified energy mix that includes <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuel_power_station" title="Fossil fuel power station">natural gas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewables</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nuclear_power" title="Nuclear power">nuclear power</a>, with growing private sector participation and regional interconnections. <a href="/wiki/Fossil_fuels" class="mw-redirect" title="Fossil fuels">Fossil fuels</a> still dominate, generating 88% of electricity in 2023, while hydropower provides 7% and wind and solar together 5%, up from 1% in 2015 but still below the global average of 13% and Africa's 6%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Egypt&#95;241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Egypt-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt remains Africa's largest producer of gas-fired electricity, accounting for 45% of the continent's total in 2022, yet its per capita carbon emissions remain below the global average.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Egypt&#95;241-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Egypt-241"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The government undertook a series of rapid reforms in response to <a href="/wiki/Power_outage" title="Power outage">blackouts</a> during the summer of 2014 that lasted for up to six hours per day, cutting energy subsidies, and quickly developing the <a href="/wiki/Zohr_gas_field" class="mw-redirect" title="Zohr gas field">Zohr gas field</a> in the Mediterranean, which was discovered in 2015. The country now has an oversupply of electricity and aims to source 20% of its electricity from <a href="/wiki/Renewable_energy" title="Renewable energy">renewables</a> by 2022 and 55% by 2050.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> As part of its renewable energy strategy, Egypt has undertaken large-scale projects like the <a href="/wiki/Benban_Solar_Park" title="Benban Solar Park">Benban Solar Park</a> and the Gabal El Zeit wind farm. Benban, located near Aswan, has a total capacity of 1650 MW and generates about 3.8 TWh annually, making it the fourth-largest solar power plant globally.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-One&#95;243-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-One-243"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Additionally, the Gabal El Zeit wind farm, costing €340 million, spans 100 square kilometres with 300 turbines, generating 580 MW of electricity.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt is currently constructing its first nuclear power facility, the <a href="/wiki/El_Dabaa_Nuclear_Power_Plant" title="El Dabaa Nuclear Power Plant">El Dabaa Nuclear Power Plant</a>, in the northern coastal region.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt and <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a> are considering implementing the proposed <a href="/wiki/EuroAfrica_Interconnector" title="EuroAfrica Interconnector">EuroAfrica Interconnector</a> project.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-EA&#95;247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EA-247"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This consists of laying a 2 GW <a href="/wiki/High-voltage_direct_current" title="High-voltage direct current">HVDC</a> <a href="/wiki/Submarine_power_cable" title="Submarine power cable">undersea power cable</a> between them and between Cyprus and Greece, thus connecting Egypt to the greater European power grid.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The interconnector will make Egypt an electricity hub between Europe and Africa.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The president of Egypt and the prime minister of Cyprus met in <a href="/wiki/Nicosia" title="Nicosia">Nicosia</a> on 21 November 2017 and showed their full support for the EuroAfrica Interconnector pointing out its importance for their energy security.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Transport">Transport</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Egypt" title="Transport in Egypt">Transport in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B1%D9%88_%D9%85%D9%86_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%89.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B1%D9%88_%D9%85%D9%86_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%89.jpg/250px-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B1%D9%88_%D9%85%D9%86_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%89.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="222" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B1%D9%88_%D9%85%D9%86_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%89.jpg/500px-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%B1%D9%88_%D9%85%D9%86_%D8%AC%D9%87%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%89.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="960" data-file-height="854" /></a><figcaption>The Cairo Metro (line 3)</figcaption></figure>
<p>Transport in Egypt is primarily concentrated around Cairo, following the Nile River's settlement patterns. The country's 4,800-kilometre (3,000&#160;mi) railway network is operated by <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_National_Railways" title="Egyptian National Railways">Egyptian National Railways</a>, with its main line running from <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> to <a href="/wiki/Aswan" title="Aswan">Aswan</a>. In 2021, Egypt launched a $4.5 billion <a href="/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_Egypt" title="High-speed rail in Egypt">high-speed rail project</a> to connect <a href="/wiki/Ain_Sokhna" title="Ain Sokhna">Ain Sokhna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mersa_Matruh" class="mw-redirect" title="Mersa Matruh">Mersa Matruh</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, later expanding to include routes linking <a href="/wiki/Greater_Cairo" title="Greater Cairo">Greater Cairo</a> to <a href="/wiki/Aswan" title="Aswan">Aswan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Luxor" title="Luxor">Luxor</a> to <a href="/wiki/Hurghada" title="Hurghada">Hurghada</a> and <a href="/wiki/Safaga" title="Safaga">Safaga</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-2022-05-30-rt&#95;253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2022-05-30-rt-253"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Metro" title="Cairo Metro">Cairo Metro</a> operates three lines, with a fourth line under construction and plans for additional expansions in the future. Meanwhile, two <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Monorail" title="Cairo Monorail">monorail lines</a> are also being built in the city, along with a <a href="/wiki/Alexandria_Metro" title="Alexandria Metro">metro system</a> in <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt has undertaken major road infrastructure expansion through the <a href="/wiki/National_Roads_Project" title="National Roads Project">National Roads Project</a>, increasing the total length of main roads by nearly 30% from 23,500&#160;km in 2014 to 30,500&#160;km in 2024. Alongside constructing new highways, thousands of kilometres of roads have been upgraded, leading to improvements in Egypt's Road Quality Index, which rose from 118th place in 2015 to 18th place in 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt's aviation sector is led by <a href="/wiki/EgyptAir" title="EgyptAir">EgyptAir</a>, the country's <a href="/wiki/Flag_carrier" title="Flag carrier">flag carrier</a> and largest airline, founded in 1932 by <a href="/wiki/Talaat_Harb" title="Talaat Harb">Talaat Harb</a>. Now state-owned, EgyptAir operates from its <a href="/wiki/Cairo_International_Airport" title="Cairo International Airport">Cairo International Airport</a> hub, with scheduled passenger and cargo services to over 75 destinations across the Middle East, Europe, Africa, Asia, and the Americas. The airline's current fleet consists of 80 aircraft.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B6_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B1%D8%AC_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%87.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B6_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B1%D8%AC_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%87.jpg/250px-%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B6_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B1%D8%AC_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%87.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="167" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B6_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B1%D8%AC_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%87.jpg/500px-%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%B6_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%81%D8%B1%D8%AC_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%82%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%B1%D9%87.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="5027" data-file-height="3351" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Rod_El_Farag_Axis_Bridge" title="Rod El Farag Axis Bridge">Rod El Farag Axis Bridge</a></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG/250px-Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG/500px-Capesize_bulk_carrier_at_Suez_Canal_Bridge.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="2592" data-file-height="1944" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal_Bridge" title="Suez Canal Bridge">Suez Canal Bridge</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Suez_Canal" title="Suez Canal">Suez Canal</a>, an artificial sea-level waterway, connects the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea, enabling direct shipping between Europe and Asia without navigating around Africa. In 2023 it generated a record $9.4 billion in revenue for Egypt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Opened in November 1869, the <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1154941027">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);clip-path:polygon(0px 0px,0px 0px,0px 0px);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style>193.30&#160;km (<span class="frac">120<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>&#8260;<span class="den">8</span></span>&#160;mi) canal runs from <a href="/wiki/Port_Said" title="Port Said">Port Said</a> in the north to <a href="/wiki/Port_Tawfiq" class="mw-redirect" title="Port Tawfiq">Port Tawfiq</a> in the south, with <a href="/wiki/Ismailia" title="Ismailia">Ismailia</a> situated <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1154941027" />3 kilometres (<span class="frac">1<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">7</span>&#8260;<span class="den">8</span></span> miles) west of its midpoint.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-SuezExpansion&#95;257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SuezExpansion-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The canal is 24 metres (79 feet) deep and 205&#160;m (673&#160;ft) wide as of 2010<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Egypt&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>, consisting of a 22&#160;km (14&#160;mi) northern access channel, a <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1154941027" />162.25&#160;km (<span class="frac">100<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">7</span>&#8260;<span class="den">8</span></span>&#160;mi) main section, and a <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1154941027" />9&#160;km (<span class="frac">5<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>&#8260;<span class="den">2</span></span>&#160;mi) southern access channel. The Ballah By-Pass and the Great Bitter Lake provide passing points along the canal, which operates without locks, allowing seawater to flow freely. <a href="/wiki/New_Suez_Canal" class="mw-redirect" title="New Suez Canal">Expansions</a> completed in 2015 increased its daily capacity from 49 to 97 ships, reducing transit times and boosting global maritime trade.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-SuezExpansion&#95;257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SuezExpansion-257"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Water_supply_and_sanitation">Water supply and sanitation</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Water_supply_and_sanitation_in_Egypt" title="Water supply and sanitation in Egypt">Water supply and sanitation in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egypt_sat.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Egypt_sat.png/250px-Egypt_sat.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="232" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Egypt_sat.png/500px-Egypt_sat.png 1.5x" data-file-width="1265" data-file-height="1173" /></a><figcaption>Green irrigated land along the Nile amidst the desert and in the <a href="/wiki/Nile_Delta" title="Nile Delta">Nile Delta</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt's <a href="/wiki/Water_supply" title="Water supply">water supply</a> is heavily dependent on the <a href="/wiki/Nile_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Nile River">Nile River</a>, which provides approximately 90% of the country's total water resources, with an annual share of 55 billion cubic metres, unchanged since 1954. An additional 0.5 billion cubic metres comes from non-renewable groundwater sources. However, national demand exceeds 90 billion cubic metres annually, creating a persistent water deficit. As a result, Egypt's per capita water share fell to 570 cubic metres in 2018, well below the 1,000 cubic metre international water scarcity threshold. To address this, the government has prioritised efficient water management, particularly in response to population growth and agricultural expansion.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-sanitation&#95;260-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sanitation-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Despite these challenges, water access has significantly improved. Between 1990 and 2010, piped water coverage rose from 89% to 100% in urban areas and from 39% to 93% in rural areas, eliminating <a href="/wiki/Open_defecation" title="Open defecation">open defecation</a> in rural regions and achieving near-universal access to an <a href="/wiki/Improved_water_source" title="Improved water source">improved water source</a>. By 2015, 90% of the population had access to safely managed drinking water, increasing to 96.9% by 2019. Similarly, proper sanitation coverage expanded from 50% in 2015 to 66.2% in 2019, while the percentage of treated wastewater relative to total wastewater rose from 50% to 68.7% in the same period, reaching 74% in 2022.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> However, gaps in sanitation infrastructure have historically led to health concerns, with a 2007 report estimating 17,000 child deaths annually from diarrhoeal diseases linked to poor sanitation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IDRC&#95;262-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IDRC-262"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt has made significant investments in wastewater treatment infrastructure as part of its broader water management strategy. In 2021, the Bahr El Baqar Wastewater Treatment Plant was completed, becoming the largest in the world at the time, with a capacity of 5 million cubic metres per day. The treated water from this facility is allocated to irrigating 342,000 acres under the Sinai Peninsula Development Plan.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-sanitation&#95;260-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sanitation-260"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, Egypt inaugurated the <a href="/wiki/New_Delta_Wastewater_Treatment_Plant" title="New Delta Wastewater Treatment Plant">New Delta Wastewater Treatment Plant</a>, surpassing Bahr El Baqar as the largest wastewater facility globally, with a capacity of 7.5 million cubic metres per day.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-treatmentplant&#95;263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-treatmentplant-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> A key component of Egypt's agricultural expansion strategy, the plant supports the New Delta reclamation project while also reducing pollution in <a href="/wiki/Lake_Mariout" title="Lake Mariout">Lake Mariout</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-treatmentplant&#95;263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-treatmentplant-263"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Given Egypt's arid climate and lack of appreciable rainfall, agriculture is entirely dependent on irrigation. The Nile River, regulated by the <a href="/wiki/Aswan_High_Dam" class="mw-redirect" title="Aswan High Dam">Aswan High Dam</a>, releases an annual average of 55 billion cubic metres, of which 46 billion cubic metres are diverted into irrigation canals.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ewup&#95;264-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ewup-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This irrigation sustains 33,600 square kilometres (13,000 square miles) of agricultural land in the Nile Valley and Nile Delta, producing an average of 1.8 crops per year.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ewup&#95;264-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ewup-264"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Demographics">Demographics</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Egypt" title="Demographics of Egypt">Demographics of Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptians</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egypt_2010_population_density1.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Egypt_2010_population_density1.png/250px-Egypt_2010_population_density1.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="229" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Egypt_2010_population_density1.png/500px-Egypt_2010_population_density1.png 1.5x" data-file-width="654" data-file-height="600" /></a><figcaption>Egypt's population density (people per km<sup>2</sup>)</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt is the most populated country in the Arab world and the third most populous on the <a href="/wiki/African_continent" class="mw-redirect" title="African continent">African continent</a>, with about 95 million inhabitants as of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Egypt&amp;action=edit">&#91;update&#93;</a></sup>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-popclock&#95;265-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popclock-265"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its population grew rapidly from 1970 to 2010 due to <a href="/wiki/History_of_medicine#Late_modern_medicine" title="History of medicine">medical advances</a> and increases in agricultural productivity<sup id="cite&#95;ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> enabled by the <a href="/wiki/Green_Revolution" title="Green Revolution">Green Revolution</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt's population was estimated at 3 million when <a href="/wiki/Napoleon_I_of_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Napoleon I of France">Napoleon</a> invaded the country in 1798.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The great majority of its people live near the banks of the <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a> River, an area of about 40,000 square kilometres (15,000&#160;sq&#160;mi), where the only <a href="/wiki/Arable_land" title="Arable land">arable land</a> is found. The large regions of the <a href="/wiki/Sahara" title="Sahara">Sahara</a> desert, which constitute most of Egypt's territory, are sparsely inhabited. About 43% of Egypt's residents live across the country's urban areas,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with most spread across the densely populated centres of greater Cairo, Alexandria and other major cities in the Nile Delta.
</p><p>Egypt's people are highly urbanised, being concentrated along the Nile (notably Cairo and Alexandria), in the Delta and near the Suez Canal. Egyptians are divided demographically into those who live in the major urban centres and the <a href="/wiki/Fellah" title="Fellah">fellahin</a>, or farmers, that reside in rural villages. The total inhabited area constitutes <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://citypopulation.de/Egypt-Cities.html">only 77,041 km<sup>2</sup></a>, putting the <a href="/wiki/Physiological_density" title="Physiological density">physiological density</a> at over 1,200 people per km<sup>2</sup>, similar to Bangladesh.
</p><p>While emigration was restricted under Nasser, thousands of Egyptian professionals were dispatched abroad in the context of the <a href="/wiki/Arab_Cold_War" title="Arab Cold War">Arab Cold War</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egyptian emigration was liberalised in 1971, under President Sadat, reaching record numbers after the 1973 oil crisis.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An estimated 2.7 million Egyptians live abroad. Approximately 70% of Egyptian migrants live in Arab countries (923,600 in Saudi Arabia, 332,600 in Libya, 226,850 in Jordan, 190,550 in Kuwait with the rest elsewhere in the region) and the remaining 30% reside mostly in Europe and North America (318,000 in the United States, 110,000 in Canada and 90,000 in Italy).<sup id="cite&#95;ref-IOMEgypt&#95;272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-IOMEgypt-272"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The process of emigrating to non-Arab states has been ongoing since the 1950s.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Ethnic_groups">Ethnic groups</h3></div>
<p>Ethnic <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptians</a> are by far the largest ethnic group in the country, constituting 99.7% of the total population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-factbook-his&#95;81-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-factbook-his-81"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Ethnic minorities include the <a href="/wiki/Abaza_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Abaza people">Abazas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Turkish_people" title="Turkish people">Turks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bedouin" title="Bedouin">Bedouin</a> Arab tribes living in the eastern deserts and the <a href="/wiki/Sinai_Peninsula" title="Sinai Peninsula">Sinai Peninsula</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Berber_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Berber language">Berber</a>-speaking <a href="/wiki/Siwis" class="mw-redirect" title="Siwis">Siwis</a> (<a href="/wiki/Berber_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Berber people">Amazigh</a>) of the <a href="/wiki/Siwa_Oasis" title="Siwa Oasis">Siwa Oasis</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Nubian_people" class="mw-redirect" title="Nubian people">Nubian</a> communities clustered along the Nile. There are also tribal <a href="/wiki/Beja_people" title="Beja people">Beja</a> communities concentrated in the southeasternmost corner of the country, and a number of <a href="/wiki/Dom_people" title="Dom people">Dom</a> clans mostly in the Nile Delta and <a href="/wiki/Faiyum" title="Faiyum">Faiyum</a> who are progressively becoming assimilated as urbanisation increases.
</p><p>Egypt hosts a migrant population of over 9 million, constituting 8.7% of the country's total population, according to the International Organization for Migration. These migrants originate from 133 countries, with the largest groups being <a href="/wiki/Sudanese" class="mw-redirect" title="Sudanese">Sudanese</a> (4 million), <a href="/wiki/Syrians" title="Syrians">Syrians</a> (1.5 million), <a href="/wiki/Yemenis" title="Yemenis">Yemenis</a> (1 million), and <a href="/wiki/Libyans" class="mw-redirect" title="Libyans">Libyans</a> (1 million), collectively making up 80% of all international migrants in Egypt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Languages">Languages</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Egypt" title="Languages of Egypt">Languages of Egypt</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Official_language" title="Official language">official language</a> of Egypt is <a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Literary Arabic</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Spoken_language" title="Spoken language">spoken languages</a> are: <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Egyptian Arabic">Egyptian Arabic</a> (68%), <a href="/wiki/Sa%27idi_Arabic" class="mw-redirect" title="Sa&#39;idi Arabic">Sa'idi Arabic</a> (29%), <a href="/wiki/Bedawi_Arabic" class="mw-redirect" title="Bedawi Arabic">Eastern Egyptian Bedawi Arabic</a> (1.6%), <a href="/wiki/Sudanese_Arabic" title="Sudanese Arabic">Sudanese Arabic</a> (0.6%), <a href="/wiki/Domari_language" title="Domari language">Domari</a> (0.3%), <a href="/wiki/Nobiin_language" title="Nobiin language">Nobiin</a> (0.3%),<sup id="cite&#95;ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Beja_language" title="Beja language">Beja</a> (0.1%), <a href="/wiki/Siwi_language" title="Siwi language">Siwi</a> and others.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">&#91;<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (October 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>&#93;</sup> Additionally, Greek, <a href="/wiki/Armenian_language" title="Armenian language">Armenian</a> and Italian, and more recently, African languages like <a href="/wiki/Amharic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Amharic language">Amharic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tigrinya_language" title="Tigrinya language">Tigrigna</a> are the main languages of immigrants.
</p><p>The main foreign languages taught in schools, by order of popularity, are English, French, German and Italian.
</p><p>Historically <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_language" title="Egyptian language">Egyptian</a> was spoken, the latest stage of which is <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Coptic Egyptian</a>. Spoken Coptic was mostly extinct by the 17th century but may have survived in isolated pockets in <a href="/wiki/Upper_Egypt" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a> as late as the 19th century. It remains in use as the liturgical language of the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria">Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-extinct&#95;277-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-extinct-277"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Daily&#95;Star&#95;Egypt&#95;278-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Daily_Star_Egypt-278"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It forms a separate branch among the family of <a href="/wiki/Afroasiatic_languages" title="Afroasiatic languages">Afroasiatic languages</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Religion">Religion</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Egypt" title="Religion in Egypt">Religion in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_(4).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_%284%29.jpg/250px-Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_%284%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="285" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_%284%29.jpg/330px-Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_%284%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_%284%29.jpg/500px-Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan_%284%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3456" data-file-height="5184" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Mosque-Madrassa_of_Sultan_Hassan" class="mw-redirect" title="Mosque-Madrassa of Sultan Hassan">Madrasa-Mosque of Sultan Hassan</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Islam is the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> of Egypt. Egypt has the largest Muslim population in the <a href="/wiki/Arab_world" title="Arab world">Arab world</a> and the world's <a href="/wiki/Islam_by_country" title="Islam by country">sixth largest Muslim population</a>, accounting for five percent of all Muslims worldwide.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-PewDec2012&#95;279-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PewDec2012-279"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt also has the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_the_Middle_East" title="Christianity in the Middle East">largest Christian population</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_East_and_North_Africa" title="Middle East and North Africa">Middle East and North Africa</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Global&#95;Christianity&#95;280-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Global_Christianity-280"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Official data about religion is lacking due to social and political sensitivities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> An estimated 85–90% are identified as Muslim, 10–15% as <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Christians" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Christians">Coptic Christians</a>, and 1% as other Christian denominations; other estimates place the Christian population as high as 15–20%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>f<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt was an early and leading centre of Christianity into <a href="/wiki/Late_antiquity" title="Late antiquity">late antiquity</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Orthodox_Church_of_Alexandria" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria">Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria</a> was founded in the first century and remains the largest church in Egypt. With the arrival of Islam in the seventh century, Egypt was gradually Islamised into a majority-Muslim country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is unknown when Muslims reached a majority, variously estimated from <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;">&#8201;1000 CE</span> to as late as the 14th century. Egypt emerged as a centre of politics and culture in the <a href="/wiki/Muslim_world" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslim world">Muslim world</a>. Under <a href="/wiki/Anwar_Sadat" title="Anwar Sadat">Anwar Sadat</a>, Islam became the official <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sharia" title="Sharia">Sharia</a> the main source of law.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-georgetown&#95;66-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-georgetown-66"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:StMarkCathAlex.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/StMarkCathAlex.jpg/250px-StMarkCathAlex.jpg" decoding="async" width="190" height="288" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/StMarkCathAlex.jpg/330px-StMarkCathAlex.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/75/StMarkCathAlex.jpg 2x" data-file-width="378" data-file-height="573" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Saint_Mark%27s_Coptic_Orthodox_Cathedral_(Alexandria)" title="Saint Mark&#39;s Coptic Orthodox Cathedral (Alexandria)">St. Mark Coptic Cathedral in Alexandria</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The majority of Egyptian Muslims adhere to the <a href="/wiki/Sunni_Islam" title="Sunni Islam">Sunni branch of Islam</a>. <a href="/wiki/Non-denominational_Muslims" class="mw-redirect" title="Non-denominational Muslims">Nondenominational Muslims</a> form roughly 12% of the population.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-churches-deleg&#95;5-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-churches-deleg-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> There is also a <a href="/wiki/Shi%27a" class="mw-redirect" title="Shi&#39;a">Shi'a</a> minority. The <a href="/wiki/Jerusalem_Center_for_Public_Affairs" class="mw-redirect" title="Jerusalem Center for Public Affairs">Jerusalem Centre for Public Affairs</a> estimates the Shia population at 1 to 2.2 million<sup id="cite&#95;ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and could measure as much as 3 million.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> population is estimated at less than 50,000,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> whereas the <a href="/wiki/Salafi" class="mw-redirect" title="Salafi">Salafi</a> (ultra-conservative Sunni) population is estimated at five to six million.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>288<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> is famous for its numerous mosque <a href="/wiki/Minaret" title="Minaret">minarets</a> and has been dubbed "The City of 1,000 Minarets".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>289<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The city also hosts <a href="/wiki/Al-Azhar_University" title="Al-Azhar University">Al-Azhar University</a>, which is considered the preeminent institution of Islamic higher learning and jurisprudence.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>290<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Founded in the late tenth century, it is by some measures the second oldest continuously operating university in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>291<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>It is estimated that 15 million Egyptians follow native Sufi <a href="/wiki/Tariqah" class="mw-redirect" title="Tariqah">orders</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>292<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-HuffPost15Million&#95;299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HuffPost15Million-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>294<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with <a href="/wiki/Sufism" title="Sufism">Sufi</a> leadership asserting that the numbers are much greater, as many Egyptian Sufis are not officially registered with a Sufi order.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-HuffPost15Million&#95;299-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-HuffPost15Million-299"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>293<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At least 305 people were killed during a <a href="/wiki/2017_Sinai_mosque_attack" title="2017 Sinai mosque attack">November 2017 attack</a> on a Sufi mosque in Sinai.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>295<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Of the <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Egypt" title="Christianity in Egypt">Christian population in Egypt</a> over 90% belong to the native Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria, an <a href="/wiki/Oriental_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Oriental Orthodox">Oriental Orthodox</a> Christian Church.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>296<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other native Egyptian Christians are adherents of the <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Catholic_Church" title="Coptic Catholic Church">Coptic Catholic Church</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Evangelical_Church_of_Egypt_(Synod_of_the_Nile)" title="Evangelical Church of Egypt (Synod of the Nile)">Evangelical Church of Egypt</a> and various other <a href="/wiki/Protestant" class="mw-redirect" title="Protestant">Protestant</a> denominations. Non-native Christian communities are largely found in the urban regions of Cairo and Alexandria, such as the <a href="/wiki/Syro-Lebanese_in_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Syro-Lebanese in Egypt">Syro-Lebanese</a>, who belong to <a href="/wiki/Melkite_Greek_Catholic_Church" title="Melkite Greek Catholic Church">Greek Catholic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greek_Orthodox" class="mw-redirect" title="Greek Orthodox">Greek Orthodox</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Maronite_Catholic" class="mw-redirect" title="Maronite Catholic">Maronite Catholic</a> denominations.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>297<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The Egyptian government recognises only three religions: Islam, Christianity, and Judaism. Other faiths and minority Muslim sects, such as the small <a href="/wiki/Bah%C3%A1%CA%BC%C3%AD_Faith" title="Baháʼí Faith">Baháʼí Faith</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ahmadiyya" title="Ahmadiyya">Ahmadiyya</a> communities, are not recognised by the state and face persecution by the government, which labels these groups a threat to Egypt's national security.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>298<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>299<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Individuals, particularly Baháʼís and atheists, wishing to include their religion (or lack thereof) on their mandatory state issued identification cards <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_identification_card_controversy" title="Egyptian identification card controversy">are denied this ability</a>, and were put in the position of either not obtaining required identification or lying about their faith. A 2008 court ruling allowed members of unrecognised faiths to obtain identification and leave the religion field blank.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-International&#95;Religious&#95;Freedom&#95;Report&#95;2008&#95;306-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-International_Religious_Freedom_Report_2008-306"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>300<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-reuters&#95;307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-reuters-307"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>301<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Education">Education</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Egypt" title="Education in Egypt">Education in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:UIS_Literacy_Rate_Egypt_population_plus15_1980_2015.png" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Egypt_population_plus15_1980_2015.png/250px-UIS_Literacy_Rate_Egypt_population_plus15_1980_2015.png" decoding="async" width="250" height="198" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Egypt_population_plus15_1980_2015.png/398px-UIS_Literacy_Rate_Egypt_population_plus15_1980_2015.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/fa/UIS_Literacy_Rate_Egypt_population_plus15_1980_2015.png 2x" data-file-width="398" data-file-height="316" /></a><figcaption>Egyptian literacy rate among the population aged 15 years and older by UNESCO Institute of Statistics</figcaption></figure>
<p>In 2022, Egypt's adult literacy rate was 74.5%, compared to 71.1% in 2017.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>302<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Literacy is lowest among those over 65 years of age, at 32.9% in 2021,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>303<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and highest among youth between 15 and 24 years of age, at 92.2% in 2022.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>304<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:CairoUniv.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/CairoUniv.jpg/250px-CairoUniv.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="182" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/CairoUniv.jpg/500px-CairoUniv.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1104" data-file-height="804" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Cairo_University" title="Cairo University">Cairo University</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>A European-style education system was first introduced in Egypt by the Ottomans in the early 19th century to nurture a class of loyal bureaucrats and army officers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-edu-chatham&#95;311-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-chatham-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Under British occupation, investment in education was curbed drastically, and
secular public schools, which had previously been free, began to charge fees.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-edu-chatham&#95;311-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-chatham-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1950s, President Nasser phased in free education for all Egyptians.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-edu-chatham&#95;311-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-chatham-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Egyptian curriculum influenced other Arab education systems, which often employed Egyptian-trained teachers.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-edu-chatham&#95;311-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-chatham-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Demand soon outstripped the level of available state resources, causing the quality of public education to deteriorate.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-edu-chatham&#95;311-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-chatham-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Today this trend has culminated in poor teacher–student ratios (often around one to fifty) and persistent gender inequality.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-edu-chatham&#95;311-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-edu-chatham-311"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>305<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
