</p><p>Basic education, which includes six years of primary and three years of preparatory school, is a right for Egyptian children from the age of six.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oecd-edu&#95;312-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-edu-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> After grade 9, students are tracked into one of two strands of secondary education: general or technical schools. General secondary education prepares students for further education, and graduates of this track normally join higher education institutes based on the results of the <a href="/wiki/Thanaweya_Amma" title="Thanaweya Amma">Thanaweya Amma</a>, the leaving exam.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oecd-edu&#95;312-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-edu-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2025 Egypt introduced a new Baccalaureate Certificate System which will replace the <a href="/wiki/Thanaweya_Amma" title="Thanaweya Amma">Thanaweya Amma</a> starting 2026.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>307<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Technical secondary education has two strands, one lasting three years and a more advanced education lasting five. Graduates of these schools may have access to higher education based on their results on the final exam, but this is generally uncommon.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-oecd-edu&#95;312-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-oecd-edu-312"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>306<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/QS_World_University_Rankings" title="QS World University Rankings">QS World University Rankings</a> 2025 includes 15 Egyptian universities, with <a href="/wiki/Cairo_University" title="Cairo University">Cairo University</a> ranked highest among them. The <a href="/wiki/American_University_in_Cairo" title="American University in Cairo">American University in Cairo</a> follows, improving its position to 410th place. Several Egyptian universities have advanced in rankings compared to the previous year, reflecting ongoing improvements in higher education.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>308<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The country is currently opening new research institutes with the aim of modernising scientific research and development; the most recent example is <a href="/wiki/Zewail_City_of_Science_and_Technology" class="mw-redirect" title="Zewail City of Science and Technology">Zewail City of Science and Technology</a>. Egypt was ranked 86th in the <a href="/wiki/Global_Innovation_Index" title="Global Innovation Index">Global Innovation Index</a> in 2025.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>309<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>310<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Health">Health</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Health_in_Egypt" title="Health in Egypt">Health in Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Egypt" title="Healthcare in Egypt">Healthcare in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%81%D8%A7%D9%84_57357.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%81%D8%A7%D9%84_57357.jpg/250px-%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%81%D8%A7%D9%84_57357.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%81%D8%A7%D9%84_57357.jpg/500px-%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B4%D9%81%D9%89_%D8%B3%D8%B1%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%86_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%B7%D9%81%D8%A7%D9%84_57357.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3456" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Children%27s_Cancer_Hospital_Egypt" title="Children&#39;s Cancer Hospital Egypt">Egypt's children cancer hospital</a> known as <i> 57357 hospital</i></figcaption></figure>
<p>As of 2024, Egypt's average life expectancy stands at 75 years, with 73.8 years for males and 76.2 years for females.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia-health&#95;317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-health-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Healthcare access has significantly improved in both urban and rural areas, with immunisation programmes now covering 98% of the population. Life expectancy has risen from 45 years in the 1960s to its current level, reflecting advancements in medical services and disease prevention. The infant mortality rate has also declined sharply, dropping from 101 to 132 deaths per 1,000 live births in the 1970s and 1980s to 50–60 per 1,000 in 2000, and further to 16–18 per 1,000 in 2024.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>312<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-cia-health&#95;317-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia-health-317"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>311<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_and_Population_(Egypt)" title="Ministry of Health and Population (Egypt)">Ministry of Health and Population</a> oversees most public hospitals, while the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Higher_Education_and_Scientific_Research_(Egypt)" title="Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research (Egypt)">Ministry of Higher Education and Scientific Research</a> manages university hospitals, offering free medical services. Other ministries operate hospitals for employees, and the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Egypt)" class="mw-redirect" title="Ministry of Defence (Egypt)">Ministry of Defence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Interior_(Egypt)" title="Ministry of Interior (Egypt)">Ministry of Interior</a> run facilities that require out-of-pocket payments for non-service members.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-healthcare1&#95;319-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-healthcare1-319"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>313<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The private sector provides about 60% of healthcare services, including for-profit and nonprofit organisations, private hospitals, pharmacies, and independent practitioners. Numerous <a href="/wiki/Nongovernmental_organizations" class="mw-redirect" title="Nongovernmental organizations">nongovernmental organisations</a> also offer healthcare, including religious and charitable institutions. As of 2021, Egypt had 1,145 private hospitals, a 23.69% increase since 2011.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>314<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Private healthcare facilities in Egypt are generally of high quality.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>315<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt grants refugees and asylum-seekers access to public healthcare on equal terms with citizens, allowing them to receive care at primary health facilities either free or at low cost.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>316<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A 2008 report by the <a href="/wiki/World_Health_Organization" title="World Health Organization">World Health Organisation</a> estimated that 91.1% of Egypt's girls and women aged 15 to 49 have been subjected to <a href="/wiki/Female_genital_mutilation" title="Female genital mutilation">genital mutilation</a>. Government measures have reduced the practice among younger generations. By 2014, rates had dropped to 10.4% in urban areas and 15.9% in rural areas among girls aged 1–14. In June 2025 the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Social_Solidarity" title="Ministry of Social Solidarity">Minister of Social Solidarity</a> announced that the percentage of girls aged 15 to 17 who had undergone the practice dropped to 37 percent in 2021, compared to 61 percent in 2014. Public support for FGM has also fallen, with the proportion of women endorsing the practice decreasing from 75 percent in 2000 to 30 percent in 2021.
Legislative reforms, awareness campaigns, and stricter law enforcement contributed to this decline. In 2016, penalties for performing the practice were increased, with prison sentences of up to 15 years for practitioners and up to 3 years for <a href="/wiki/Legal_guardian#Guardianship_for_minors" title="Legal guardian">guardians</a> who facilitate the procedure.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>317<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>318<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>319<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Largest_cities">Largest cities</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Egypt" title="List of cities and towns in Egypt">List of cities and towns in Egypt</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1219497266">.mw-parser-output .largestCities-table-background{background:#f9f9f9;color:#222}.mw-parser-output .largestCities-cell-background{background:#f0f0f0;color:#222}</style>

<tr>
<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">1</td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a></td>
<td style="text-align:left;"><a href="/wiki/Cairo_Governorate" title="Cairo Governorate">Cairo</a></td>
<td style="text-align:right;">9,801,536</td>
<td class="largestCities-cell-background" style="text-align:center;">11</td>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Culture">Culture</h2></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Egypt" title="Culture of Egypt">Culture of Egypt</a></div>
<p>Egypt is a recognised cultural trendsetter of the Arabic-speaking world. Contemporary Arabic and Middle-Eastern culture is heavily influenced by Egyptian literature, music, film and television. Egypt gained a regional leadership role during the 1950s and 1960s, giving a further enduring boost to the standing of Egyptian culture in the Arabic-speaking world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>320<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%82%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%B1_%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%82%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%B1_%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89.jpg/250px-%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%82%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%B1_%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%82%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%B1_%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89.jpg/500px-%D8%AD%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%82%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A3%D8%B2%D9%87%D8%B1_%D9%88%D9%85%D8%B3%D8%AC%D8%AF_%D9%85%D8%AD%D9%85%D8%AF_%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2484" data-file-height="1236" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Al-Azhar_Park" title="Al-Azhar Park">Al-Azhar Park</a> is listed as one of the world's sixty great public spaces by the <a href="/wiki/Project_for_Public_Spaces" title="Project for Public Spaces">Project for Public Spaces</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egyptian identity evolved in the span of a long period of occupation to accommodate <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>, Christianity and Judaism; and a new language, <a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>, and its spoken descendant, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Egyptian Arabic">Egyptian Arabic</a>, which has a significant <a href="/wiki/Coptic_language" title="Coptic language">Coptic-Egyptian</a> <a href="/wiki/Stratum_(linguistics)" title="Stratum (linguistics)">substrate</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>321<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The work of early 19th century scholar <a href="/wiki/Rifa%27a_al-Tahtawi" class="mw-redirect" title="Rifa&#39;a al-Tahtawi">Rifa'a al-Tahtawi</a> renewed interest in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">Egyptian antiquity</a> and exposed Egyptian society to <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Enlightenment</a> principles. Tahtawi co-founded with education reformer <a href="/wiki/Ali_Mubarak" class="mw-redirect" title="Ali Mubarak">Ali Mubarak</a> a native <a href="/wiki/Egyptology" title="Egyptology">Egyptology</a> school that looked for inspiration to medieval Egyptian scholars, such as <a href="/wiki/Suyuti" class="mw-redirect" title="Suyuti">Suyuti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maqrizi" class="mw-redirect" title="Maqrizi">Maqrizi</a>, who themselves studied the <a href="/wiki/History_of_ancient_Egypt" title="History of ancient Egypt">history</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_language" title="Egyptian language">language</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_architecture" title="Ancient Egyptian architecture">antiquities</a> of Egypt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>322<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt's renaissance peaked in the late 19th and early 20th centuries through the work of people like <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Abduh" title="Muhammad Abduh">Muhammad Abduh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Lutfi_el-Sayed" title="Ahmed Lutfi el-Sayed">Ahmed Lutfi el-Sayed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Loutfi_Goumah" title="Muhammad Loutfi Goumah">Muhammad Loutfi Goumah</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tawfiq_el-Hakim" class="mw-redirect" title="Tawfiq el-Hakim">Tawfiq el-Hakim</a>, <a href="/wiki/Louis_Awad" title="Louis Awad">Louis Awad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Qasim_Amin" title="Qasim Amin">Qasim Amin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salama_Moussa" title="Salama Moussa">Salama Moussa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Taha_Hussein" title="Taha Hussein">Taha Hussein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Mokhtar" title="Mahmoud Mokhtar">Mahmoud Mokhtar</a>. They forged a liberal path for Egypt expressed as a commitment to personal freedom, <a href="/wiki/Secularism" title="Secularism">secularism</a> and faith in science to bring progress.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>323<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Arts">Arts</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Contemporary_art_in_Egypt" title="Contemporary art in Egypt">Contemporary art in Egypt</a> and <a href="/wiki/Art_of_ancient_Egypt" title="Art of ancient Egypt">Art of ancient Egypt</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Architecture_of_Egypt" title="Architecture of Egypt">Architecture of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg/330px-The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg" decoding="async" width="310" height="141" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg/500px-The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg/960px-The_judgement_of_the_dead_in_the_presence_of_Osiris.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2446" data-file-height="1112" /></a><figcaption>The "weighing of the heart" scene from the <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_the_Dead" title="Book of the Dead">Book of the Dead</a></i></figcaption></figure>
<p>The Egyptians were one of the first major civilisations to codify design elements in art and <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egyptian_architecture" title="Ancient Egyptian architecture">architecture</a>. <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_blue" title="Egyptian blue">Egyptian blue</a>, also known as calcium copper silicate, is a pigment used by Egyptians for thousands of years. It is considered to be the first synthetic pigment. The wall paintings done in the service of the <a href="/wiki/Pharaoh" title="Pharaoh">Pharaohs</a> followed a rigid code of visual rules and meanings. Egyptian civilisation is renowned for its colossal <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_pyramids" title="Egyptian pyramids">pyramids</a>, <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_temple" title="Egyptian temple">temples</a> and monumental tombs. Well-known examples are the <a href="/wiki/Pyramid_of_Djoser" title="Pyramid of Djoser">Pyramid of Djoser</a> designed by ancient architect and engineer <a href="/wiki/Imhotep" title="Imhotep">Imhotep</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sphinx" title="Sphinx">Sphinx</a>, and the temple of <a href="/wiki/Abu_Simbel" title="Abu Simbel">Abu Simbel</a>.
</p><p>Modern and contemporary Egyptian art spans a wide range of disciplines, ranging from the vernacular architecture of <a href="/wiki/Hassan_Fathy" title="Hassan Fathy">Hassan Fathy</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ramses_Wissa_Wassef" title="Ramses Wissa Wassef">Ramses Wissa Wassef</a> to the iconic sculptures of <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Mokhtar" title="Mahmoud Mokhtar">Mahmoud Mokhtar</a> and the distinctive <a href="/wiki/Coptic_art" title="Coptic art">Coptic iconography</a> of <a href="/wiki/Isaac_Fanous" title="Isaac Fanous">Isaac Fanous</a>. Its development in the twentieth century reflected a complex dialogue between national identity, global artistic trends, and social change. Early modern Egyptian artists sought to reconnect with their national heritage through Neo-Pharaonic styles in architecture, sculpture, and painting, with artists such as <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Mokhtar" title="Mahmoud Mokhtar">Mahmoud Mokhtar</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahmoud_Sa%27id" title="Mahmoud Sa&#39;id">Mahmoud Sa'id</a> incorporating symbolic references to ancient Egypt and rural life.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-met-mikdadi&#95;330-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-met-mikdadi-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Engelstad&#95;331-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Engelstad-331"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>325<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Later generations embraced international movements like <a href="/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism">Surrealism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cubism" title="Cubism">Cubism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dadaism" class="mw-redirect" title="Dadaism">Dadaism</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Abstract_art" title="Abstract art">abstraction</a>, while the <a href="/wiki/Art_et_Libert%C3%A9" title="Art et Liberté">Art et Liberté</a> group, including <a href="/wiki/Ramses_Younan" title="Ramses Younan">Ramses Younan</a>, promoted individual expression and antifascist ideals.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-met-mikdadi&#95;330-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-met-mikdadi-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Contemporary Art Group, with artists such as <a href="/wiki/Gazbia_Sirry" title="Gazbia Sirry">Gazbia Sirry</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Hadi_Al_Gazzar" title="Abdel Hadi Al Gazzar">Abdel Hadi Al Gazzar</a>, explored social realism and the quest for the Egyptian soul, while experimental painters and sculptors like Munir Canaan and Salah Abdel Kerim explored <a href="/wiki/Abstract_Expressionism" class="mw-redirect" title="Abstract Expressionism">Abstract Expressionism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Assemblage_(art)" title="Assemblage (art)">assemblage</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-met-mikdadi&#95;330-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-met-mikdadi-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the latter half of the century, artists responded to political and cultural shifts with Islamic-inspired calligraphy and geometric abstraction, exemplified by the Calligraphic School of Art.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-met-mikdadi&#95;330-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-met-mikdadi-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  Other notable artists from this era include <a href="/wiki/Inji_Efflatoun" class="mw-redirect" title="Inji Efflatoun">Inji Efflatoun</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kamal_Amin" title="Kamal Amin">Kamal Amin</a>.
</p><p>The launch of institutions such as the <a href="/wiki/Townhouse_Gallery" class="mw-redirect" title="Townhouse Gallery">Townhouse Gallery</a> in 1998 democratised art access and introduced new media forms like video and installation art,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>326<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> providing a platform for younger artists such as <a href="/wiki/Fathi_Hassan" title="Fathi Hassan">Fathi Hassan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ghada_Amer" title="Ghada Amer">Ghada Amer</a>, Medhat Shafik, <a href="/wiki/Moataz_Nasr" title="Moataz Nasr">Moataz Nasr</a>, and Mona Marzouk to experiment with installation, video, and photography.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-met-mikdadi&#95;330-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-met-mikdadi-330"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>324<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/2011_Egyptian_revolution" title="2011 Egyptian revolution">2011 Egyptian revolution</a> ushered in a new era of politically and socially engaged art. <a href="/wiki/Graffiti" title="Graffiti">Graffiti</a> emerged as a prominent medium to document protests and communicate revolutionary messages,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>327<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with artists like <a href="/wiki/Bahia_Shehab" title="Bahia Shehab">Bahia Shehab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alaa_Awad" title="Alaa Awad">Alaa Awad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aya_Tarek" title="Aya Tarek">Aya Tarek</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ganzeer" title="Ganzeer">Ganzeer</a> creating works that memorialised martyrs, critiqued political figures, and reclaimed public spaces.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>328<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:248px;max-width:248px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:122px;max-width:122px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Khayamiya-7.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Khayamiya-7.jpg/120px-Khayamiya-7.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="213" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/Khayamiya-7.jpg/250px-Khayamiya-7.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2160" data-file-height="3840" /></a></span></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:122px;max-width:122px"><div class="thumbimage"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Khayamiya-3.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Khayamiya-3.jpg/120px-Khayamiya-3.jpg" decoding="async" width="120" height="213" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Khayamiya-3.jpg/250px-Khayamiya-3.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2160" data-file-height="3840" /></a></span></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption"><i>Khayamiya</i> design motives.</div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Khayamiya" title="Khayamiya">Khayamiya</a> is a traditional Egyptian appliqué textile art primarily made in Cairo's historic <i>ShareʿEl Khayamiya</i> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">شارع الخيامية</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic" title="Romanization of Arabic">romanised</a>:&#160;</small><span title="Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="ar-Latn">Shāriʿ al-Khayāmiyya</i></span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a>&#8201;</small><span class="gloss-quot">'</span><span class="gloss-text">Street of the Tentmakers</span><span class="gloss-quot">'</span>), also known as the Tentmakers Market. The craft, thought to date back to <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>, involves a labour-intensive hand-stitching process that can take weeks to complete, with designs ranging from geometric motifs to scenes drawn from Egyptian history and folklore. It was originally associated with decorated tents, but today it is also used for quilts, cushion covers, and wall hangings.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>329<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Opera_House" title="Cairo Opera House">Cairo Opera House</a> is Egypt's main performing arts venue, with the <a href="/wiki/Alexandria_Opera_House" title="Alexandria Opera House">Sayed Darwish Theatre</a> in <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Port_Said_Opera_House" class="mw-redirect" title="Port Said Opera House">Port Said Opera House</a> in <a href="/wiki/Port_Said" title="Port Said">Port Said</a> serving their respective cities. In 2012 the <a href="/wiki/Downtown_Contemporary_Arts_Festival" title="Downtown Contemporary Arts Festival">Downtown Contemporary Arts Festival</a> (D-CAF) was launched to revitalise Cairo's cultural scene and to provide an inclusive platform for contemporary arts. It is an annual arts festival held in Cairo, Egypt, presenting a range of performances, exhibitions, and workshops in theatre, dance, and visual arts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>330<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Literature">Literature</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_literature" title="Egyptian literature">Egyptian literature</a></div>
<p>The literary tradition of Egypt began in <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>, making it among the earliest in human history. Writing was first used by Egyptians to record texts on materials such as papyrus and carved inscriptions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-337" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-337"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>331<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Story_of_Sinuhe" title="Story of Sinuhe">Story of Sinuhe</a></i> is perhaps its best-known work;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-338" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-338"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>332<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and the autobiography has been called the earliest form of Egyptian literature.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>333<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By the eighth century Egypt became part of the Muslim Arab world. Literature and libraries thrived under the new order, papyrus was replaced by paper, and calligraphy became central.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>334<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 13th century, <a href="/wiki/Ibn_al-Nafis" title="Ibn al-Nafis">Ibn al-Nafis</a> wrote <i><a href="/wiki/Theologus_Autodidactus" title="Theologus Autodidactus">Theologus Autodidactus</a></i>, a theological novel with proto-science fiction elements.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Roubi&#95;341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Roubi-341"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>335<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Literary practices such as the <i>taqriz</i> (commendatory blurbs) appeared in 14th-century Egypt,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>336<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and Egyptian folklore contributed to <i><a href="/wiki/One_Thousand_and_One_Nights" title="One Thousand and One Nights">One Thousand and One Nights</a></i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Burton-1991&#95;343-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Burton-1991-343"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>337<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Egypt was central to the <i><a href="/wiki/Nahda" title="Nahda">Nahda</a></i>, the Arab cultural renaissance.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>338<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Abduh" title="Muhammad Abduh">Muhammad Abduh</a>, a leading figure of Islamic modernism,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Meisami&#95;1998&#95;345-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Meisami_1998-345"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>339<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> co-founded the revolutionary journal <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Urwah_al-Wuthqa" title="Al-Urwah al-Wuthqa">Al-Urwah al-Wuthqa</a></i> with <a href="/wiki/Jamal_al-Din_al-Afghani" title="Jamal al-Din al-Afghani">Jamal al-Din al-Afghani</a> in 1884; though quickly banned by the British, it circulated widely across the Arab world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>340<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-:02&#95;347-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-347"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>341<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>342<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>343<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ahmad_Shawqi" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmad Shawqi">Ahmad Shawqi</a> pioneered the expansion of the classical <a href="/wiki/Qasida" title="Qasida">qasida</a> form, though his work remained firmly rooted in neo-classical style. Following him, poets such as <a href="/wiki/Hafez_Ibrahim" title="Hafez Ibrahim">Hafez Ibrahim</a> began addressing themes of <a href="/wiki/Anti-imperialism" title="Anti-imperialism">anticolonialism</a> alongside traditional poetic subjects.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ansari-literature&#95;350-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ansari-literature-350"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Husayn_Haykal" class="mw-redirect" title="Muhammad Husayn Haykal">Muhammad Husayn Haykal</a>'s <i><a href="/wiki/Zaynab_(novel)" title="Zaynab (novel)">Zaynab</a></i> is considered the first modern Egyptian novel.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>345<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This novel started a movement of modernising Arabic fiction.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ansari-literature&#95;350-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ansari-literature-350"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>344<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Poetry remained vibrant, with figures such as <a href="/wiki/Aziz_Pasha_Abaza" class="mw-redirect" title="Aziz Pasha Abaza">Aziz Pasha Abaza</a> contributing classical-style verse with <a href="/wiki/Pan-Arabism" title="Pan-Arabism">Pan-Arabism</a> themes. The Abaza family produced several notable literary figures, including <a href="/wiki/Fekry_Pasha_Abaza" class="mw-redirect" title="Fekry Pasha Abaza">Fekry Pasha Abaza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tharwat_Abaza" title="Tharwat Abaza">Tharwat Abaza</a>, and Desouky Pasha Abaza.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>346<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>347<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Nagib_Mahfouz.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Nagib_Mahfouz.jpg/250px-Nagib_Mahfouz.jpg" decoding="async" width="180" height="253" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Nagib_Mahfouz.jpg/285px-Nagib_Mahfouz.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/6/66/Nagib_Mahfouz.jpg 2x" data-file-width="285" data-file-height="400" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Naguib_Mahfouz" title="Naguib Mahfouz">Naguib Mahfouz</a>, the first Arabic-language writer to win the Nobel Prize in Literature</figcaption></figure>
<p>In the 20th century, modernist movements shaped Egyptian literature. <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Madrasa_al-%E1%B8%A4ad%C4%ABtha" title="Al-Madrasa al-Ḥadītha">Al-Madrasa al-Ḥadītha</a></i> focused on the short story,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>348<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> while two of the most prominent figures were <a href="/wiki/Taha_Hussein" title="Taha Hussein">Taha Hussein</a> and <a href="/wiki/Naguib_Mahfouz" title="Naguib Mahfouz">Naguib Mahfouz</a>, the latter the first Egyptian  and Arabic-language writer to receive the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a>. Avant-garde literary activity emerged through magazines like <i><a href="/wiki/Galerie_68" title="Galerie 68">Galerie 68</a></i>, founded by <a href="/wiki/Edwar_al-Kharrat" title="Edwar al-Kharrat">Edwar al-Kharrat</a>, giving voice to Egypt's 1960s generation.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>349<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the 1990s, Egyptian literature responded to socio-economic changes such as urbanisation and rising living costs, focusing on isolated individuals in a changing society, exemplified by Mustafa Zikri, <a href="/wiki/Nura_Amin" title="Nura Amin">Nura Amin</a>, and <a href="/wiki/May_Telmissany" title="May Telmissany">May Telmissany</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Safez&#95;356-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Safez-356"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>350<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> This era also saw the rise of women writers, often called <i>kitabat al-banat</i> ("girls' writing"), with shorter, first-person narratives.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>351<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>352<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egyptians constitute the largest share of shortlisted authors for the <a href="/wiki/International_Prize_for_Arabic_Fiction" title="International Prize for Arabic Fiction">International Prize for Arabic Fiction</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Bahaa_Taher" title="Bahaa Taher">Bahaa Taher</a>'s <i>Sunset Oasis</i> winning the inaugural edition in 2008, followed the next year by <a href="/wiki/Youssef_Ziedan" title="Youssef Ziedan">Youssef Ziedan</a>'s <i>Azazeel</i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>353<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Other notable contemporary authors include <a href="/wiki/Radwa_Ashour" title="Radwa Ashour">Radwa Ashour</a>, acclaimed for the <i><a href="/wiki/Granada_(Trilogy)" class="mw-redirect" title="Granada (Trilogy)">Granada</a></i> trilogy; <a href="/wiki/Ahdaf_Soueif" title="Ahdaf Soueif">Ahdaf Soueif</a>, whose English-language novel <i>The Map of Love</i> was shortlisted for the <a href="/wiki/Booker_Prize" title="Booker Prize">Booker Prize</a> in 1999; <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Khaled_Tawfik" title="Ahmed Khaled Tawfik">Ahmed Khaled Tawfik</a>, who introduced horror and science fiction to Egyptian literature with his <i>Ma Waraa al-Tabiaa</i> series; and <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Mourad" title="Ahmed Mourad">Ahmed Mourad</a>, known for bestselling novels such as <i>Vertigo</i> and <i><a href="/wiki/The_Blue_Elephant_(novel)" title="The Blue Elephant (novel)">The Blue Elephant</a></i>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>354<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Feminist themes are explored by <a href="/wiki/Nawal_El_Saadawi" title="Nawal El Saadawi">Nawal El Saadawi</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alifa_Rifaat" title="Alifa Rifaat">Alifa Rifaat</a>, while vernacular poetry is represented by <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Fouad_Negm" title="Ahmed Fouad Negm">Ahmed Fouad Negm</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salah_Jaheen" class="mw-redirect" title="Salah Jaheen">Salah Jaheen</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Rahman_el-Abnudi" title="Abdel Rahman el-Abnudi">Abdel Rahman el-Abnudi</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>355<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Media">Media</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Egypt">Media of Egypt</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_radio_stations_in_Egypt" title="List of radio stations in Egypt">List of radio stations in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9.jpg/250px-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="301" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9.jpg/500px-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B5%D8%A7%D8%AF%D8%B1%D8%A9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%88%D9%84%D9%89_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%88%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B5%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A9.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1582" data-file-height="2072" /></a><figcaption>The first issue of <a href="/wiki/Al-Waqa%27i%27_al-Misriyya" title="Al-Waqa&#39;i&#39; al-Misriyya">Al-Waqa'i' al-Misriyya</a>, printed in 1828 by the <a href="/wiki/Bulaq_Press" title="Bulaq Press">Amiriya Press</a>. It and its predecessor <a href="/wiki/Jurnal_al-Khidiw" title="Jurnal al-Khidiw">Jurnal al-Khidiw</a> are the oldest Arabic-language newspapers.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt is a major regional media hub, with its press among the most influential in the Arab world. The <a href="/wiki/Printing_press" title="Printing press">printing press</a> was first introduced to Egypt by <a href="/wiki/Napoleon" title="Napoleon">Napoleon Bonaparte</a> during his <a href="/wiki/French_Campaign_in_Egypt_and_Syria" class="mw-redirect" title="French Campaign in Egypt and Syria">French Campaign in Egypt and Syria</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Cole&#95;2007&#95;148&#95;362-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Cole_2007_148-362"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>356<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a> was the centre of Egyptian journalism for much of the 1800s,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-kendallp339&#95;363-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kendallp339-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with many literary journals starting there before moving to <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>358<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> By the 1890s, Cairo had become dominant, hosting 65% of publications, while Alexandria accounted for 28%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-kendallp339&#95;363-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-kendallp339-363"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>357<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The written press in Egypt today is highly diverse, with more than 600 newspapers, journals, and magazines.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>359<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The three leading state-owned press institutions are <i><a href="/wiki/Al-Ahram" title="Al-Ahram">Al-Ahram</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Al-Akhbar_(Egypt)" title="Al-Akhbar (Egypt)"><i>Al-Akhbar</i></a> and <i>Dar Al-Tahrir,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-arabmediasoc&#95;366-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arabmediasoc-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></i> the latter being a major publishing house that issues a wide range of newspapers and magazines in different languages, including <i><a href="/wiki/Al_Gomhuria" title="Al Gomhuria">Al-Gomhuria</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Egyptian_Gazette" title="The Egyptian Gazette">The Egyptian Gazette</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Progr%C3%A8s_Egyptien" title="Le Progrès Egyptien">Le Progrès Egyptien</a>,</i> among others.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>361<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt was the first country in the region to introduce radio broadcasts to a wide population in 1926, initially through private short-wave stations with limited range, primarily located between <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ahram-radio&#95;368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahram-radio-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The official Egyptian radio service launched on 31 May 1934, with the first broadcast featuring <a href="/wiki/Muhammad_Rifat" title="Muhammad Rifat">Muhammad Rifat</a>, a Quran reciter.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-ahram-radio&#95;368-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ahram-radio-368"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>362<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Following the <a href="/wiki/1952_Egyptian_Revolution" class="mw-redirect" title="1952 Egyptian Revolution">1952 Egyptian Revolution</a>, radio became a central tool of state communication and regional influence. Under President <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Gamal Abdel Nasser</a>, Egypt developed the <a href="/wiki/Voice_of_the_Arabs" title="Voice of the Arabs">Voice of the Arabs</a> (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">صوت العرب</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic" title="Romanization of Arabic">romanised</a>:&#160;</small><span title="Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="ar-Latn">Sawt El Arab</i></span>) service, launched in the 1950s as one of the most prominent Arabic-language broadcasts of its time.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Boyd1975&#95;369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boyd1975-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Initially modest in size, Egypt's radio system was rapidly expanded by the revolutionary government. It was used to promote Arab unity, strengthen Egypt's leadership role in the region, often calling for solidarity and revolutionary action, particularly during the 1950s and 1960s.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Boyd1975&#95;369-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Boyd1975-369"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>363<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Contemporary radio in Egypt is largely operated by the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Radio_and_Television_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Radio and Television Union">Egyptian Radio and Television Union</a> (ERTU), established in 1970, which manages multiple national and local stations. Private FM stations also exist, but state radio remains the most widespread. Programming includes news, cultural content, educational programmes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-arabmediasoc&#95;366-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arabmediasoc-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Maspiro_building_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Maspiro_building_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Maspiro_building_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="193" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Maspiro_building_%28cropped%29.jpg/500px-Maspiro_building_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="2822" data-file-height="2365" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Maspero_television_building" title="Maspero television building">Maspero building</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>, headquarters of the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Radio_and_Television_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Radio and Television Union">Egyptian Radio and Television Union</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Egyptian television began in 1960 when Channel 1 launched with <a href="/wiki/Quran" title="Quran">Quran</a> readings and a speech by President <a href="/wiki/Gamal_Abdel_Nasser" title="Gamal Abdel Nasser">Nasser</a>, followed by Channel 2 in 1961 offering cultural, informational, and instructional programmes. Over the following decades, additional channels were launched regionally.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-arabmediasoc&#95;366-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arabmediasoc-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In the 21st century, Egypt's television and film industry continue to supply much of the region through Cairo's <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Media_Production_City" title="Egyptian Media Production City">Media Production City</a>. Television remains the most popular medium in the country, with <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Radio_and_Television_Union" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian Radio and Television Union">ERTU</a> operating two national terrestrial channels, six local terrestrial channels covering all 27 governorates, three satellite channels, and over ten specialised channels, including news, sport, culture, education, and entertainment.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-arabmediasoc&#95;366-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arabmediasoc-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  In addition, numerous private satellite television channels operate alongside the state networks.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-arabmediasoc&#95;366-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-arabmediasoc-366"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>360<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  Egypt is a major force in satellite broadcasting, being the first Arab country to launch its own satellite, <a href="/wiki/Nilesat" title="Nilesat">Nilesat</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cinema">Cinema</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Egypt" title="Cinema of Egypt">Cinema of Egypt</a></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1273380762/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" /><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:107px;max-width:107px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:143px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Suad_Husni.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Suad_Husni.jpg/120px-Suad_Husni.jpg" decoding="async" width="105" height="144" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b5/Suad_Husni.jpg/219px-Suad_Husni.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="219" data-file-height="300" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Soad_Hosny" title="Soad Hosny">Soad Hosny</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:111px;max-width:111px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:143px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Faten_Hamama_actress.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Faten_Hamama_actress.jpg/120px-Faten_Hamama_actress.jpg" decoding="async" width="109" height="144" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Faten_Hamama_actress.jpg/250px-Faten_Hamama_actress.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1058" data-file-height="1396" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Faten_Hamama" title="Faten Hamama">Faten Hamama</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:121px;max-width:121px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:143px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Omar_Sharif_1963.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Omar_Sharif_1963.JPG/120px-Omar_Sharif_1963.JPG" decoding="async" width="119" height="144" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Omar_Sharif_1963.JPG/250px-Omar_Sharif_1963.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="771" data-file-height="930" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Omar_Sharif" title="Omar Sharif">Omar Sharif</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:97px;max-width:97px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:143px;overflow:hidden"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Ahmed_Zaki_(1979).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Ahmed_Zaki_%281979%29.jpg/120px-Ahmed_Zaki_%281979%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="95" height="144" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Ahmed_Zaki_%281979%29.jpg/250px-Ahmed_Zaki_%281979%29.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1179" data-file-height="1788" /></a></span></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Zaki" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Ahmed Zaki">Ahmed Zaki</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Egyptian_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="Egyptian cinema">Egyptian cinema</a>, the oldest in Africa and the Arab world, began in 1896 with film screenings in <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cairo" title="Cairo">Cairo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Port_Said" title="Port Said">Port Said</a>. Early production started in 1907 with short documentaries, and the first feature films appeared in 1917, directed by <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Karim" title="Mohammed Karim">Mohammed Karim</a>. By the 1920s and 1930s, the country's film scene expanded with productions such as <a href="/wiki/Laila_(1927_film)" title="Laila (1927 film)">Layla</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sons_of_Aristocrats" title="Sons of Aristocrats">Sons of Aristocrats</a>, the first Egyptian talkie.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-chamber-cinema&#95;370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chamber-cinema-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 1936, <a href="/wiki/Studio_Misr" title="Studio Misr">Studio Misr</a>, financed by industrialist <a href="/wiki/Talaat_Pasha_Harb" class="mw-redirect" title="Talaat Pasha Harb">Talaat Harb</a>, emerged as the leading Egyptian studio, a role the company retained for three decades.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-371" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-371"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>365<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> For over 100 years, more than 4,000 films have been produced in Egypt, three quarters of the total Arab production.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>366<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>367<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The industry has been a dominant cultural force in the Arab world since its inception, earning the nickname "Arab Hollywood" and "Hollywood of the East".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-meer-cinema&#95;374-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-meer-cinema-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>369<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-chamber-cinema&#95;370-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-chamber-cinema-370"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>364<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Its golden age, spanning the 1940s to the 1960s, saw Egypt become the world's third-largest film producer, with hundreds of films across genres achieving widespread regional popularity.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-meer-cinema&#95;374-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-meer-cinema-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Iconic filmmakers such as <a href="/wiki/Youssef_Chahine" title="Youssef Chahine">Youssef Chahine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Barakat" title="Henry Barakat">Henry Barakat</a>, and celebrated actors including <a href="/wiki/Faten_Hamama" title="Faten Hamama">Faten Hamama</a>, helped establish Egyptian cinema as a major influence on Arab cultural identity. Today, Egyptian films continue to reach audiences across the Arab world and beyond, maintaining the country's historic role as a central hub for Arabic-language cinema.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-meer-cinema&#95;374-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-meer-cinema-374"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>368<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Egypt hosts several film festivals, which have become important platforms for both local and international filmmakers. The <a href="/wiki/Cairo_International_Film_Festival" title="Cairo International Film Festival">Cairo International Film Festival</a>, established in 1976, showcases a range of films from dramas to experimental works and attracts filmmakers and audiences from around the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-film-festivals&#95;376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-film-festivals-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is listed by the <a href="/wiki/FIAPF" title="FIAPF">International Federation of Film Producers' Associations</a> as one of the 11 competitive film festivals in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>371<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Luxor_African_Film_Festival" title="Luxor African Film Festival">Luxor African Film Festival</a> highlights African cinema, while the <a href="/wiki/El_Gouna_Film_Festival" title="El Gouna Film Festival">El Gouna Film Festival</a> presents Arabic and international films. Other notable events include the Ismailia International Film Festival, which focuses on social and environmental themes, and the Alexandria Short Film Festival, which features narrative, documentary, and animated short films.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-film-festivals&#95;376-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-film-festivals-376"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>370<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The number of cinemas increased with the emergence of <a href="/wiki/Talking_film" class="mw-redirect" title="Talking film">talking films</a>, and reached 395 in 1958. This number began to decline after the establishment of television in 1960 and the establishment of the public sector in cinemas in 1962. The cinema count fell to 297 in 1965, then to 141 in 1995, due to the circulation of films through video equipment though the boom of the film industry in this period. Due to laws and procedures that encouraged investment in the establishment of private cinemas, they increased again, especially in commercial centres. Their number reached 200 in 2001 and 400 in 2009.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>372<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>373<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Music">Music</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Egypt" title="Music of Egypt">Music of Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ancient_Egyptians_playing_music.png" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="Ancient Egyptians playing music" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Ancient_Egyptians_playing_music.png/250px-Ancient_Egyptians_playing_music.png" decoding="async" width="230" height="140" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Ancient_Egyptians_playing_music.png/500px-Ancient_Egyptians_playing_music.png 1.5x" data-file-width="549" data-file-height="334" /></a><figcaption>An ancient Egyptian mural of people playing music.</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Music_of_Egypt" title="Music of Egypt">Egyptian music</a> is a rich mixture of indigenous, Mediterranean, African and Western elements. It has been an integral part of <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_Egypt" title="Culture of Egypt">Egyptian culture</a> since antiquity. The ancient <a href="/wiki/Egyptians" title="Egyptians">Egyptians</a> credited one of their gods <a href="/wiki/Hathor" title="Hathor">Hathor</a> with the invention of music, which <a href="/wiki/Osiris" title="Osiris">Osiris</a> in turn used as part of his effort to civilise the world. Egyptians used music instruments since then.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>374<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Contemporary Egyptian music has its roots in the work of early artists such as <a href="/wiki/Abdu_al-Hamuli" title="Abdu al-Hamuli">Abdu al-Hamuli</a>, Almaz, and Mahmoud Osman, whose contributions shaped and inspired later generations. It was recorded as early as the 1910s, with a thriving classical tradition developing in Cairo by the 1930s, blending indigenous folk influences with Western elements and producing iconic 20th-century stars such as <a href="/wiki/Sayed_Darwish" title="Sayed Darwish">Sayed Darwish</a>, <a href="/wiki/Umm_Kulthum" title="Umm Kulthum">Umm Kulthum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mohammed_Abdel_Wahab" title="Mohammed Abdel Wahab">Mohammed Abdel Wahab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abdel_Halim_Hafez" title="Abdel Halim Hafez">Abdel Halim Hafez</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baligh_Hamdi" title="Baligh Hamdi">Baligh Hamdi</a>, many of whom became central to both popular culture and national identity.
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D8%A7%D9%85_%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%88%D9%85.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/%D8%A7%D9%85_%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%88%D9%85.jpg/250px-%D8%A7%D9%85_%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%88%D9%85.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="230" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8c/%D8%A7%D9%85_%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%88%D9%85.jpg/400px-%D8%A7%D9%85_%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%88%D9%85.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8c/%D8%A7%D9%85_%D9%83%D9%84%D8%AB%D9%88%D9%85.jpg 2x" data-file-width="400" data-file-height="400" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Umm_Kulthum" title="Umm Kulthum">Umm Kulthum</a>, an icon of Egyptian music, often referred to as "Egypt's <a href="/wiki/Giza_pyramid_complex" title="Giza pyramid complex">Fourth Pyramid</a>".<sup id="cite&#95;ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>375<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2023, <i><a href="/wiki/Rolling_Stone" title="Rolling Stone">Rolling Stone</a></i> ranked Umm Kulthum at number 61 on its list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>376<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>377<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></figcaption></figure>
<p>The music scene evolved from the golden age of mid-20th century <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Egypt#Modern_Egyptian_classical_and_pop_music" title="Music of Egypt">modern Egyptian classical</a> heavyweights, to the rise of <a href="/wiki/Arabic_pop" title="Arabic pop">Egyptian pop</a> in the 1980s–90s with artists such as <a href="/wiki/Amr_Diab" title="Amr Diab">Amr Diab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hisham_Abbas" title="Hisham Abbas">Hisham Abbas</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mostafa_Amar" class="mw-redirect" title="Mostafa Amar">Mostafa Amar</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-aravanis-music&#95;384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aravanis-music-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> At the same time, <a href="/wiki/Omar_Khairat" title="Omar Khairat">Omar Khairat</a> emerged as a leading composer and pianist, blending <a href="/wiki/Western_classical_music" class="mw-redirect" title="Western classical music">Western classical music</a> with distinctive Egyptian influences. He has written numerous acclaimed film scores and symphonic works which has made him one of Egypt's most internationally respected contemporary musicians.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>379<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, globalisation and the <a href="/wiki/2011_Egyptian_revolution" title="2011 Egyptian revolution">2011 revolution</a> spurred diverse underground movements, with musicians and bands like <a href="/wiki/Ramy_Essam" title="Ramy Essam">Ramy Essam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cairokee" title="Cairokee">Cairokee</a> addressing identity and political themes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-aravanis-music&#95;384-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aravanis-music-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Mahraganat" title="Mahraganat">Mahraganat</a> emerged from working-class communities to become mainstream, developing out of <a href="/wiki/Shaabi" title="Shaabi">shaabi</a> music, which has been part of Egyptian culture since the 1970s with pioneers such as <a href="/wiki/Ahmed_Adaweya" class="mw-redirect" title="Ahmed Adaweya">Ahmed Adaweya</a>. Meanwhile, Egyptian <a href="/wiki/Rap" class="mw-redirect" title="Rap">rap</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trap_music" title="Trap music">trap</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Techno" title="Techno">techno</a> gained prominence through artists like Abyusif, <a href="/wiki/Marwan_Pablo" title="Marwan Pablo">Marwan Pablo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wegz" title="Wegz">Wegz</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-aravanis-music&#95;384-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aravanis-music-384"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>378<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In recent years, Egypt's music scene has seen a generational shift, with new artists emerging as leading figures alongside established icons. According to <a href="/wiki/Spotify_Wrapped" title="Spotify Wrapped">Spotify Wrapped</a> 2024, seven of the ten most-streamed songs in Egypt came from newer performers experimenting with <a href="/wiki/Rap" class="mw-redirect" title="Rap">rap</a>, <a href="/wiki/R%26B" class="mw-redirect" title="R&amp;B">R&amp;B</a>, <a href="/wiki/Electronic_music" title="Electronic music">electronic fusions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Underground_music" title="Underground music">street music</a> alongside traditional influences. Rising artists such as Eslam Kabonga, Shehab, TUL8TE, Mahmoud El Leithy, and Essam Sasa gained significant popularity, while established acts like <a href="/wiki/Marwan_Pablo" title="Marwan Pablo">Marwan Pablo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sherine" title="Sherine">Sherine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cairokee" title="Cairokee">Cairokee</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tamer_Ashour" title="Tamer Ashour">Tamer Ashour</a> also remained highly streamed. The trend coincided with an 85 percent rise in local music consumption, underscoring the growing dominance of homegrown talent.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-386" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-386"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>380<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Egypt's music industry has seen rapid international growth through streaming platforms, with <a href="/wiki/Spotify" title="Spotify">Spotify</a> reporting a fivefold rise in royalties since 2022, over 90 percent of earnings going to independent artists, and more than 80 percent of revenue coming from listeners outside Egypt.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>381<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Dances">Dances</h3></div>
<p>Egypt has a rich tradition of folk dances that reflect the country's regional and cultural diversity. In <a href="/wiki/Lower_Egypt" title="Lower Egypt">Lower Egypt</a>, dances such as <i><a href="/wiki/Ghawazi" title="Ghawazi">ghawazi el sonbat</a></i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">غوازي سنباط</span></span>), <i>raqs el hagala</i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">رقص الحجلة</span></span>), and <i>welad el sayala</i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">أولاد السيالة</span></span>) incorporate colourful costumes and props to tell a story. For example, <i>welad el sayala</i>, performed in <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, uses pocket knives and chairs to represent the lives and celebrations of fishermen and their communities.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nadine-khaled&#95;388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nadine-khaled-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Upper_Egypt" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a>, dances include stick dances such as <i>raqs el assaya</i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">رقص العصا</span></span>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Tahtib" title="Tahtib">tahtib</a></i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">تحطيب</span></span>), which are traditionally performed by men at weddings and festive occasions. These dances often symbolise strength and skill, with tahtib in particular originating from ancient martial arts traditions.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nadine-khaled&#95;388-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nadine-khaled-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Nubian dance, originating in <a href="/wiki/Nubians" title="Nubians">Nubian communities</a> in Egypt's south, are characterised by rhythmic arm movements and upbeat tempos, often accompanied by the tambourine duff.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nadine-khaled&#95;388-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nadine-khaled-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Tanoura_Dancing.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Tanoura_Dancing.jpg/250px-Tanoura_Dancing.jpg" decoding="async" width="230" height="183" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0f/Tanoura_Dancing.jpg/500px-Tanoura_Dancing.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="1329" data-file-height="1058" /></a><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/Tanoura_(dance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tanoura (dance)">tanoura</a> dancer performing</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt is often considered the home of <a href="/wiki/Belly_dance" title="Belly dance">belly dance</a>. Egyptian <a href="/wiki/Belly_dance" title="Belly dance">belly dance</a> has two main styles: <i><a href="/wiki/Raqs_baladi" class="mw-redirect" title="Raqs baladi">raqs baladi</a></i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">رقص بلدي</span></span>) and <i><a href="/wiki/Raqs_sharqi" title="Raqs sharqi">raqs sharqi</a></i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">رقص شرقي</span></span>). There are also numerous folkloric and character dances that may be part of an Egyptian-style belly dancer's repertoire, as well as the modern <i>shaabi</i> dance (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">رقص شعبي</span></span>), which shares some elements with <a href="/wiki/Raqs_baladi" class="mw-redirect" title="Raqs baladi">raqs baladi</a>. Belly dancing emphasises fluid movements of the hips, belly, and arms, often performed to the rhythm of the tabla drum, and is closely associated with femininity and performance in cinema and theatre.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nadine-khaled&#95;388-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nadine-khaled-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Other prominent forms of Egyptian dance include Sufi <i><a href="/wiki/Tanoura_(dance)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tanoura (dance)">tanoura</a></i> (<span title="Egyptian Arabic-language text"><span lang="arz" dir="rtl">رقص التنورة</span></span>) dancing, which involves multilayered skirts and is performed both as a spiritual practice to achieve trance-like states and as a cultural performance at festivals and tourist sites.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-nadine-khaled&#95;388-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-nadine-khaled-388"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>382<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Museums">Museums</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Egypt" title="List of museums in Egypt">List of museums in Egypt</a></div>
<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egyptian_Museum_in_Cairo_in_May_2015.JPG" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Egyptian_Museum_in_Cairo_in_May_2015.JPG/250px-Egyptian_Museum_in_Cairo_in_May_2015.JPG" decoding="async" width="229" height="153" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Egyptian_Museum_in_Cairo_in_May_2015.JPG/500px-Egyptian_Museum_in_Cairo_in_May_2015.JPG 1.5x" data-file-width="6000" data-file-height="4000" /></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Museum" title="Egyptian Museum">Egyptian Museum</a> in Cairo</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt is home to one of the world's oldest civilisations. It has engaged with numerous cultures and nations throughout its history and has experienced a vast array of eras, from the prehistoric age to modern times, encompassing periods such as <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ptolemaic_Kingdom" title="Ptolemaic Kingdom">Ptolemaic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Egypt" title="Roman Egypt">Roman</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Egypt" class="mw-redirect" title="Medieval Egypt">Medieval</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Egypt" title="Ottoman Egypt">Ottoman</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/History_of_Egypt_under_the_Muhammad_Ali_dynasty" title="History of Egypt under the Muhammad Ali dynasty">Alawiyya dynasty</a>.
</p>
<figure class="mw-halign-left" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg/250px-CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg" decoding="async" width="169" height="212" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg/330px-CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg/500px-CairoEgMuseumTaaMaskMostlyPhotographed.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="2000" /></a><figcaption>Tutankhamun's burial mask is one of the major attractions of the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Museum" title="Egyptian Museum">Egyptian Museum</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Notable museums in Egypt include the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Museum" title="Egyptian Museum">Egyptian Museum</a> in Cairo, which houses over 120,000 items and is one of the world's largest museums as well as the first national museum in the Middle East, opened in 1902;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>383<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Egyptian_Civilization" title="National Museum of Egyptian Civilization">National Museum of Egyptian Civilization</a>, home to 50,000 artefacts from various eras and the resting place of 22 ancient Egyptian kings and queens relocated there in 2021 during the <a href="/wiki/Pharaohs%27_Golden_Parade" title="Pharaohs&#39; Golden Parade">Pharaohs' Golden Parade</a>; and the <a href="/wiki/Abdeen_Palace_Museum" class="mw-redirect" title="Abdeen Palace Museum">Abdeen Palace Museum</a>, one of Egypt's most famous royal palaces, which contains five museums showcasing arms, royal belongings, silverware, historical documents, and presidential gifts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>384<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Grand_Egyptian_Museum" title="Grand Egyptian Museum">Grand Egyptian Museum</a> is an under construction museum that will house the largest collection of ancient Egyptian artefacts in the world, it has been described as the world's largest archaeological museum.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>385<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The museum is sited on 50 hectares (120 acres) of land approximately two kilometres (1.2 miles) from the Giza Necropolis and is part of a new master plan for the plateau.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>386<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It features a six-storey atrium with the 82-ton <a href="/wiki/Statue_of_Ramesses_II" title="Statue of Ramesses II">Statue of Ramesses II</a> and a grand staircase, while its galleries display artefacts spanning ancient Egypt's history. The Tutankhamun exhibition will showcase 5,600 objects from his tomb, including his gold mask and royal regalia. It is arranged around three central themes, life, death, and the afterlife, and features two opposing pathways: a chronological journey through his life and reign, and a forensic exploration of his tomb and excavation. The museum is set to open on 1 November 2025.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>387<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Festivals">Festivals</h3></div>
