<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg/250px-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg" decoding="async" width="200" height="285" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg/330px-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b7/%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg/500px-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%84%D8%AF_%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%B9_%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B9%D8%B2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="673" data-file-height="960" /></a><figcaption>Moulid celebrations in <a href="/wiki/Muizz_Street" class="mw-redirect" title="Muizz Street">Muizz Street</a>, Cairo</figcaption></figure>
<p>Egypt observes several religious Muslim and Christian festivals as public holidays. These include <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Coptic Christmas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Fitr" title="Eid al-Fitr">Eid al-Fitr</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eid_al-Adha" title="Eid al-Adha">Eid al-Adha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Islamic_New_Year" title="Islamic New Year">Islamic New Year</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Day_of_Arafah" title="Day of Arafah">Day of Arafah</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mawlid" title="Mawlid">Moulid al-Nabawi</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>388<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><i><a href="/wiki/Sham_Ennessim" title="Sham Ennessim">Sham Ennessim</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span lang="ar" dir="rtl">شم النسيم</span></span>) is an annual <a href="/wiki/Festival" title="Festival">festival</a> in Egypt marking the beginning of spring, celebrated by Egyptians of all religions and recognised as an official <a href="/wiki/Public_holiday" title="Public holiday">public holiday</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-asante&#95;395-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-asante-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> It is observed on <a href="/wiki/Easter_Monday" title="Easter Monday">Easter Monday</a>, the day after <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:3-shamenessim&#95;396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-shamenessim-396"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>390<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> typically between the <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_calendar" title="Egyptian calendar">Egyptian months</a> of <a href="/wiki/Paremoude" class="mw-redirect" title="Paremoude">Paremoude</a> (April) and <a href="/wiki/Pashons" title="Pashons">Pashons</a> (May). The festival is traditionally celebrated outdoors, with picnics in public gardens, along the <a href="/wiki/Nile" title="Nile">Nile</a>, or at the zoo. Typical foods include <i><a href="/wiki/Fesikh" title="Fesikh">fesikh</a></i>, lettuce, <a href="/wiki/Scallion" title="Scallion">green onions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lupin_bean" title="Lupin bean">lupin beans</a>. Boiled eggs are often coloured and eaten or exchanged as gifts.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-asante&#95;395-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-asante-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  it is generally held that Sham Ennessim is a continuation of early forms of springtime festivities dating back over 4,500 years.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-asante&#95;395-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-asante-395"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>389<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Mawlid#Other_uses" title="Mawlid">Moulids</a>, or saint's festivals, are a long-standing tradition throughout Egypt, celebrating both Islamic and Christian saints. The majority are Islamic and typically feature <a href="/wiki/Dhikr" title="Dhikr">dhikr</a>, the ritual chanting and recitation of prayers, as well as performances by Sufi groups, including music and spiritual gatherings.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-googlearts-moulid&#95;397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-googlearts-moulid-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Christian moulids follow comparable festive patterns. These events blend religious devotion with communal celebration, often centring on a shrine or mosque where pilgrims seek blessings through prayer, recitation of religious texts, circumambulation, and other acts of veneration.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-googlearts-moulid&#95;397-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-googlearts-moulid-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  They are also social and cultural occasions, with food, games, rides, and temporary stalls set up in the surrounding streets.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-googlearts-moulid&#95;397-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-googlearts-moulid-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>  Major festivals, such as the <i><a href="/wiki/Abu_Haggag_Mosque#Mawlid_celebration" title="Abu Haggag Mosque">Moulid Abu El Haggag</a></i> (<span title="Arabic-language text"><span lang="ar" dir="rtl">مولد أبو الحجاج</span></span>) in <a href="/wiki/Luxor" title="Luxor">Luxor</a>, attract thousands of participants. It features boats and shrines paraded through the city in his honour, a tradition with origins dating back to <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Egypt" title="Ancient Egypt">ancient Egypt</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-googlearts-moulid&#95;397-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-googlearts-moulid-397"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>391<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The procession closely resembles the rituals of the <a href="/wiki/Opet_Festival" title="Opet Festival">Opet Festival</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>392<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cuisine">Cuisine</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_cuisine" title="Egyptian cuisine">Egyptian cuisine</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Egyptian_food_Koshary.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Egyptian_food_Koshary.jpg/250px-Egyptian_food_Koshary.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="173" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Egyptian_food_Koshary.jpg/500px-Egyptian_food_Koshary.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="3031" data-file-height="2101" /></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Koshary" title="Koshary">Koshary</a>, one of Egypt's national dishes</figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Egyptian_cuisine" title="Egyptian cuisine">Egyptian cuisine</a> is deeply rooted in the agricultural traditions of the <a href="/wiki/Nile_Valley" class="mw-redirect" title="Nile Valley">Nile Valley</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nile_Delta" title="Nile Delta">Delta</a>, making heavy use of poultry, legumes, vegetables, and fruits. Staple dishes include <i><a href="/wiki/Dolma" title="Dolma">mahshi</a></i>, rice-stuffed vegetables and grape leaves, <i><a href="/wiki/Falafel" title="Falafel">falafel</a></i>, mainly known locally as <i>ta'ameya</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Shawarma" title="Shawarma">shawarma</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kebab#Egypt" title="Kebab">kabab</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Koftet_el_hati" title="Koftet el hati">kofta</a></i>. Traditional Egyptian specialties include <i><a href="/wiki/Ful_medames" title="Ful medames">ful medames</a></i>, mashed fava beans; <i><a href="/wiki/Feteer" title="Feteer">feteer</a></i>, flaky, layered pie with various fillings;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Marzouk&#95;399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Marzouk-399"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>393<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Hawawshi" title="Hawawshi">hawawshi</a></i>, spiced minced meat baked inside bread;<sup id="cite&#95;ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>394<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Molokhiya" class="mw-redirect" title="Molokhiya">molokhiya</a></i>, a jute leaf stew; and <i><a href="/wiki/Koshary" title="Koshary">koshary</a></i>, a mix of lentils, rice, and pasta. Many Egyptian dishes are traditionally prepared hands on at home, often slow-cooked, based on the culinary practices of rural kitchens passed down through generations,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>395<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> including stews such as <i><a href="/wiki/Bamia" title="Bamia">bamia</a></i>, okra stew; <i><a href="/wiki/Qolqas" class="mw-redirect" title="Qolqas">qolqas</a></i>, taro root stew; and baked dishes, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Rozz_me%27ammar" title="Rozz me&#39;ammar">rozz me'ammar</a></i>, a baked rice dish made with milk, butter, and <a href="/wiki/Qeshta" class="mw-redirect" title="Qeshta">eshta</a>; as well as <i><a href="/wiki/Macarona_bil-bechamel" title="Macarona bil-bechamel">macarona bil-bechamel</a></i>, a pasta bake with <a href="/wiki/Penne" title="Penne">penne</a>, spiced meat sauce, and <a href="/wiki/Bechamel_sauce" class="mw-redirect" title="Bechamel sauce">béchamel</a>.
</p><p>Bread holds a central place in Egyptian cuisine and dining traditions, with more than 60 different types found across the country.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-rawigivinglife&#95;402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rawigivinglife-402"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>396<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Eish_baladi" title="Eish baladi">Eish baladi</a></i>, a round, whole-wheat flatbread, is a staple of nearly every meal and is commonly used as an edible utensil for dipping and scooping rather than simply accompanying dishes.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>397<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-Basan2007&#95;404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Basan2007-404"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>398<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Cheesemaking in Egypt dates back to the <a href="/wiki/First_Dynasty_of_Egypt" title="First Dynasty of Egypt">First Dynasty</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-LucasHarris2012&#95;405-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LucasHarris2012-405"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>399<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> with <i><a href="/wiki/Domiati_cheese" class="mw-redirect" title="Domiati cheese">Domiati cheese</a></i> being the most widely consumed today.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>400<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-RobinsonTamime1996&#95;407-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RobinsonTamime1996-407"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>401<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Meat plays an important role in Egyptian cuisine, with poultry such as <a href="/wiki/Squab" title="Squab">squab</a>,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-newly&#95;translated&#95;cookbook&#95;408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-newly_translated_cookbook-408"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>402<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> chicken, duck, <a href="/wiki/Quail" title="Quail">quail</a>, and goose being common, alongside lamb and beef for grilling and stews.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>403<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Cured meats such as <i><a href="/wiki/Bastirma" class="mw-redirect" title="Bastirma">bastirma</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Sogoq" class="mw-redirect" title="Sogoq">sogoq</a></i> are traditionally consumed. Egyptian <i>bastirma</i> is made from salted, spiced, and air-dried beef or water buffalo,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-gagaoua&#95;410-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-gagaoua-410"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>404<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>405<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> and <i>sogoq</i>, a spicy sausage of ground beef stuffed into thin casings and left to dry and ferment.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>406<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>407<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Fish, especially <a href="/wiki/Tilapia" title="Tilapia">tilapia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mullet_(fish)" title="Mullet (fish)">mullet</a>, are widely consumed, with seafood in general being particularly prevalent in coastal cities like <a href="/wiki/Alexandria" title="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Suez" title="Suez">Suez</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Port_Said" title="Port Said">Port Said</a>. A large portion of Egyptian cuisine is vegetarian due to limited grazing land, historical agricultural practices, and the religious customs of <a href="/wiki/Coptic_Christians" class="mw-redirect" title="Coptic Christians">Coptic Christians</a>, who periodically observe a <a href="/wiki/Lent" title="Lent">vegan diet</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>408<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The cuisine commonly features an assortment of spices and aromatics such as <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coriander" title="Coriander">coriander</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cardamom" title="Cardamom">cardamom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chili_pepper" title="Chili pepper">chilli</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aniseed" class="mw-redirect" title="Aniseed">aniseed</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bay_leaves" class="mw-redirect" title="Bay leaves">bay leaves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dill" title="Dill">dill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Parsley" title="Parsley">parsley</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garlic" title="Garlic">garlic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ginger" title="Ginger">ginger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cinnamon" title="Cinnamon">cinnamon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lamiaceae" title="Lamiaceae">mint</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Cloves" class="mw-redirect" title="Cloves">cloves</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Cumin" title="Cumin">cumin</a> being the most commonly used.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>409<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Popular desserts include <a href="/wiki/Baqlawa" class="mw-redirect" title="Baqlawa">baqlawa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basbousa" title="Basbousa">basbousa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kunafa" class="mw-redirect" title="Kunafa">kunafa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Qatayef" title="Qatayef">qatayef</a>, often featuring dates, honey, syrup, nuts and <a href="/wiki/Semolina" title="Semolina">semolina</a>. Tea is the national drink, while coffee is also common and is traditionally prepared in the <a href="/wiki/Turkish_coffee" title="Turkish coffee">Turkish style</a>. Other popular beverages in Egypt include <i><a href="/wiki/Karkadeh" title="Karkadeh">karkadeh</a></i>, hibiscus tea; <i><a href="/wiki/Sugarcane_juice" title="Sugarcane juice">'asir asab</a></i>, sugarcane juice; <i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">&#39;</span><a href="/wiki/Erq_sous" title="Erq sous">erq sous</a></i>, liquorice juice; <i><a href="/wiki/Kharob" title="Kharob">kharob</a></i>, carob juice; <i><a href="/wiki/Qamar_al-din" title="Qamar al-din">amar eddin</a></i>, apricot drink; and <i><a href="/wiki/Sobia" title="Sobia">sobia</a></i>, sweet coconut milk drink. <a href="/wiki/Beer_in_Egypt" title="Beer in Egypt">Beer</a> is the most popular alcoholic beverage,<sup id="cite&#95;ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>410<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> including traditional types like <i><a href="/wiki/Bouza_(beer)" title="Bouza (beer)">bouza</a></i>, made from <a href="/wiki/Barley" title="Barley">barley</a> and bread and consumed since the <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_Egypt" title="Prehistoric Egypt">Predynastic era</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>411<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Sports">Sports</h3></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1320445320" /><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Egypt" title="Sport in Egypt">Sport in Egypt</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Crowd_in_Cairo_Stadium.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Crowd_in_Cairo_Stadium.jpg/250px-Crowd_in_Cairo_Stadium.jpg" decoding="async" width="250" height="188" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Crowd_in_Cairo_Stadium.jpg/500px-Crowd_in_Cairo_Stadium.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/1e/Crowd_in_Cairo_Stadium.jpg 2x" data-file-width="500" data-file-height="375" /></a><figcaption>A crowd at Cairo Stadium watching the <a href="/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team" title="Egypt national football team">Egypt national football team</a></figcaption></figure>
<p><a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">Football</a> is the most popular <a href="/wiki/National_sport" title="National sport">national sport</a> of Egypt. The <a href="/wiki/Cairo_Derby" class="mw-redirect" title="Cairo Derby">Cairo Derby</a> is one of the fiercest derbies in Africa, and the BBC picked it as one of the 7 toughest derbies in the world.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>412<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Al_Ahly_SC" title="Al Ahly SC">Al Ahly</a> is the most successful club of the 20th century in the African continent according to CAF, closely followed by their rivals <a href="/wiki/Zamalek_SC" title="Zamalek SC">Zamalek SC</a>. They are known as the "<a href="/wiki/CAF_Clubs_of_the_20th_Century" class="mw-redirect" title="CAF Clubs of the 20th Century">African Club of the Century</a>". With twenty titles, Al Ahly is currently the world's most successful club in terms of international trophies, surpassing Italy's <a href="/wiki/A.C._Milan" class="mw-redirect" title="A.C. Milan">A.C. Milan</a> and Argentina's <a href="/wiki/Boca_Juniors" title="Boca Juniors">Boca Juniors</a>, both having eighteen.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>413<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Egypt_national_football_team" title="Egypt national football team">Egyptian national football team</a>, known as the Pharaohs, won the <a href="/wiki/African_Cup_of_Nations" class="mw-redirect" title="African Cup of Nations">African Cup of Nations</a> seven times, including three times in a row in 2006, 2008, and 2010. Considered the most successful African national team and one which has reached the top 10 of the FIFA world rankings, Egypt has qualified for the <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cup</a> three times. Two goals from star player <a href="/wiki/Mohamed_Salah" title="Mohamed Salah">Mohamed Salah</a> in their last qualifying game took Egypt through to the <a href="/wiki/2018_FIFA_World_Cup" title="2018 FIFA World Cup">2018 FIFA World Cup</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>414<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The Egyptian Youth National team Young Pharaohs won the Bronze Medal of the <a href="/wiki/2001_FIFA_World_Youth_Championship" title="2001 FIFA World Youth Championship">2001 FIFA youth world cup</a> in Argentina. Egypt was 4th place in the football tournament in the <a href="/wiki/1928_Summer_Olympics" title="1928 Summer Olympics">1928</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1964_Summer_Olympics" title="1964 Summer Olympics">1964</a> Olympics.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Squash_(sport)" title="Squash (sport)">Squash</a> and tennis are other popular sports in Egypt. The Egyptian squash team has been competitive in international championships since the 1930s. <a href="/wiki/Amr_Shabana" title="Amr Shabana">Amr Shabana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ali_Farag" title="Ali Farag">Ali Farag</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ramy_Ashour" title="Ramy Ashour">Ramy Ashour</a> are Egypt's best players and all were ranked the world's number one squash player. Egypt has won the Squash World Championships five times, with the last title being in <a href="/wiki/2019_Men%27s_World_Team_Squash_Championships" title="2019 Men&#39;s World Team Squash Championships">2019</a>.
</p><p>In 1999, Egypt <a href="/wiki/1999_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="1999 World Men&#39;s Handball Championship">hosted</a> the <a href="/wiki/IHF_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="IHF World Men&#39;s Handball Championship">IHF World Men's Handball Championship</a>, and hosted it again in <a href="/wiki/2021_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="2021 World Men&#39;s Handball Championship">2021</a>. In 2001, the <a href="/wiki/Egypt_men%27s_national_handball_team" title="Egypt men&#39;s national handball team">national handball team</a> achieved its best result in the tournament by reaching fourth place. Egypt has won in the <a href="/wiki/African_Men%27s_Handball_Championship" title="African Men&#39;s Handball Championship">African Men's Handball Championship</a> five times, being the best team in Africa. Egypt won the <a href="/wiki/Egypt_at_the_2013_Mediterranean_Games" title="Egypt at the 2013 Mediterranean Games">Mediterranean Games</a> in <a href="/wiki/Handball_at_the_2013_Mediterranean_Games" title="Handball at the 2013 Mediterranean Games">2013</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Beach_Handball_World_Championships" class="mw-redirect" title="Beach Handball World Championships">Beach Handball World Championships</a> in <a href="/wiki/2004_Beach_Handball_World_Championships" title="2004 Beach Handball World Championships">2004</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Egypt_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics" title="Egypt at the 2010 Summer Youth Olympics">Summer Youth Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Handball_at_the_2010_Summer_Youth_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Boys%27_tournament" title="Handball at the 2010 Summer Youth Olympics – Boys&#39; tournament">2010</a>. Among all African nations, the <a href="/wiki/Egypt_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Egypt national basketball team">Egypt national basketball team</a> holds the record for best performance at the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Basketball_World_Cup" title="FIBA Basketball World Cup">Basketball World Cup</a> and at the <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the Summer Olympics">Summer Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>415<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>416<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Further, the team has won a record number of 16 medals at the <a href="/wiki/FIBA_Africa_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA Africa Championship">African Championship</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Egypt_at_the_Olympics" title="Egypt at the Olympics">Egypt has taken part</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer Olympic Games</a> since 1912 and has hosted <a href="/wiki/Category:International_sports_competitions_hosted_by_Egypt" title="Category:International sports competitions hosted by Egypt">several other international competitions</a> including <a href="/wiki/1951_Mediterranean_Games" title="1951 Mediterranean Games">the first Mediterranean Games</a> in 1951, the <a href="/wiki/1991_All-Africa_Games" title="1991 All-Africa Games">1991 All-Africa Games</a>, the <a href="/wiki/2009_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2009 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1953_Pan_Arab_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="1953 Pan Arab Games">1953</a>, <a href="/wiki/1965_Pan_Arab_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="1965 Pan Arab Games">1965</a> and <a href="/wiki/2007_Pan_Arab_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="2007 Pan Arab Games">2007</a> editions of the <a href="/wiki/Pan_Arab_Games" class="mw-redirect" title="Pan Arab Games">Pan Arab Games</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="See_also">See also</h2></div>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_ancient_Egypt" title="Outline of ancient Egypt">Outline of ancient Egypt</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Egypt" title="Outline of Egypt">Outline of Egypt</a></li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Notes">Notes</h2></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1327269900">.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}body.skin-vector-2022 .mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:27em}body.skin-vector-2022 .mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:22.5em}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=upper-alpha]{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=upper-roman]{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-alpha]{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-greek]{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .references[data-mw-group=lower-roman]{list-style-type:lower-roman}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-upper-alpha .references{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-upper-roman .references{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-alpha .references{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-greek .references{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output div.reflist-liststyle-lower-roman .references{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div>
<div class="mw-references-wrap"><ol class="references" data-mw-group="lower-alpha">
<li id="cite&#95;note-lang-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-lang_3-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Modern_Standard_Arabic" title="Modern Standard Arabic">Literary Arabic</a> is the sole official language.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-Provisional&#95;Constitution&#95;2-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Provisional_Constitution-2"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Egyptian Arabic">Egyptian Arabic</a> is the <a href="/wiki/Spoken_language" title="Spoken language">spoken language</a>. Other <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Egypt" title="Languages of Egypt">dialects and minority languages</a> are spoken regionally.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-relig-7"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-relig_7-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">While <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> is the majority and official religion of the country, the size of the country's historic <a href="/wiki/Christianity_in_Egypt" title="Christianity in Egypt">Christian minority</a> is highly controversial and disputed by various entities and groups. Estimates range from as low as 5% to as high as 20%. Since 2006, religion has been omitted from censuses after widespread claims that the figures had been distorted.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-:0&#95;4-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-4"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-churches-deleg&#95;5-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-churches-deleg-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-UTCoff2-24"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UTCoff2_24-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Known locally as <a href="/wiki/Egypt_Standard_Time" title="Egypt Standard Time">Egypt Standard Time</a> (EGY) (<a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">توقيت مصر القياسي</span> <i>Tawqīt Miṣr al-qiyāsiyy</i>)</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-UTCoff-25"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-UTCoff_25-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">See <a href="/wiki/Daylight_saving_time_in_Egypt" title="Daylight saving time in Egypt">Daylight saving time in Egypt</a>.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="/wiki/Arabic_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Arabic language">Arabic</a>: <span lang="ar" dir="rtl">مصر</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Arabic" title="Romanization of Arabic">romanised</a>:&#160;</small><span title="Arabic-language romanisation"><i lang="ar-Latn">Miṣr</i></span>, <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1177148991" /><span class="IPA-label IPA-label-small">pronounced</span> <span class="IPA nowrap" lang="ar-Latn-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Arabic">&#91;mɪsˤr&#93;</a></span> <span class="ext-phonos"><span data-nosnippet="" id="ooui-php-1" class="noexcerpt ext-phonos-PhonosButton ext-phonos-PhonosButton-emptylabel oo-ui-widget oo-ui-widget-enabled oo-ui-buttonElement oo-ui-buttonElement-frameless oo-ui-iconElement oo-ui-buttonWidget" href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Egyptian_Arabic" title="Help:IPA/Egyptian Arabic">&#91;mɑsˤr&#93;</a></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-287"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-287">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The population of Egypt is estimated as being 90% Muslim, 9% Coptic Christian and 1% other Christian, though estimates vary.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup><sup id="cite&#95;ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> Microsoft Encarta Online similarly estimates the Sunni population at 90% of the total.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pew_Research_Center" title="Pew Research Center">Pew Forum on Religion and Public Life</a> gave a higher estimate of the Muslim population, at 94.6%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup> In 2017, the government-owned newspaper <i><a href="/wiki/Al_Ahram" class="mw-redirect" title="Al Ahram">Al Ahram</a></i> estimated the percentage of Christians at 10 to 15%.<sup id="cite&#95;ref-churches-deleg&#95;5-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-churches-deleg-5"><span class="cite-bracket">&#91;</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">&#93;</span></a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="References">References</h2></div>

<li id="cite&#95;note-goldschmidt&#95;oldest&#95;nation-14"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-goldschmidt_oldest_nation_14-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFGoldschmidt1988" class="citation book cs1">Goldschmidt, Arthur (1988). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=YmZyAAAAMAAJ&amp;q=nation-state"><i>Modern Egypt: The Formation of a Nation-State</i></a>. Boulder, CO: Westview Press. p.&#160;5. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-86531-182-4" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-86531-182-4"><bdi>978-0-86531-182-4</bdi></a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20201217150902/https://www.google.com/books/edition/Modern_Egypt/YmZyAAAAMAAJ?hl=en&amp;gbpv=1&amp;bsq=nation-state">Archived</a> from the original on 17 December 2020<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">20 June</span> 2015</span>. <q>Among the peoples of the ancient Near East, only the Egyptians have stayed where they were and remained what they were, although they have changed their language once and their religion twice. In a sense, they constitute the world's oldest nation. For most of their history, Egypt has been a state, but only in recent years has it been truly a nation-state, with a government claiming the allegiance of its subjects on the basis of a common identity.</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Modern+Egypt%3A+The+Formation+of+a+Nation-State&amp;rft.place=Boulder%2C+CO&amp;rft.pages=5&amp;rft.pub=Westview+Press&amp;rft.date=1988&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-86531-182-4&amp;rft.aulast=Goldschmidt&amp;rft.aufirst=Arthur&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3DYmZyAAAAMAAJ%26q%3Dnation-state&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-15"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-15">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://2009-2017.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/5309.htm">"Background Note: Egypt"</a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-16">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFCrabitès2013" class="citation book cs1">Crabitès, Pierre (2013) [1935]. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=1NbCRckI3EoC&amp;pg=PA1"><i>Ibrahim of Egypt</i></a>. Vol.&#160;8. Routledge. p.&#160;1. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.4324%2F9780203069387">10.4324/9780203069387</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-415-81121-7" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-415-81121-7"><bdi>978-0-415-81121-7</bdi></a>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130509064900/http://books.google.com/books?id=1NbCRckI3EoC&amp;pg=PA1">Archived</a> from the original on 9 May 2013<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">10 February</span> 2013</span>. <q>...&#160;on July 9, 1805, Constantinople conferred upon Muhammad Ali the pashalik of Cairo&#160;...</q></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Ibrahim+of+Egypt&amp;rft.pages=1&amp;rft.pub=Routledge&amp;rft.date=2013&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.4324%2F9780203069387&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-415-81121-7&amp;rft.aulast=Crabit%C3%A8s&amp;rft.aufirst=Pierre&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D1NbCRckI3EoC%26pg%3DPA1&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-17">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.capmas.gov.eg/Pages/StaticPages.aspx?page_id=5035">"Density By Governorate 1/7/2020 – Area km2 (Theme: Population – pg.14)"</a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-dictator-29"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-dictator_29-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Sources that categorise Sisi as a dictator:

<li id="cite&#95;note-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-37">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.chm.bris.ac.uk/webprojects2002/crabb/history.html">"A Brief History of Alchemy"</a>. University of Bristol School of Chemistry. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20081005180735/http://www.chm.bris.ac.uk/webprojects2002/crabb/history.html">Archived</a> from the original on 5 October 2008<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-48"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-48">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFZ.1928" class="citation journal cs1 cs1-prop-unfit cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source">Z., T. (1928). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20160417234107/http://melitensiawth.com/incoming/Index/Il-Malti/Il-Malti.%20004%281928%292/01.pdf">"Il-Belt (Valletta)"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i>Il-Malti</i> (in Maltese). <b>2</b> (1) (2&#160;ed.). Il-Ghaqda tal-Kittieba tal-Malti: 35. Archived from the original on 17 April 2016.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Il-Malti&amp;rft.atitle=Il-Belt+%28Valletta%29&amp;rft.volume=2&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=35&amp;rft.date=1928&amp;rft.aulast=Z.&amp;rft.aufirst=T.&amp;rft&#95;id=http%3A%2F%2Fmelitensiawth.com%2Fincoming%2FIndex%2FIl-Malti%2FIl-Malti.%2520004%281928%292%2F01.pdf&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-AncientCivils-49"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-AncientCivils_49-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-AncientCivils_49-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFDallmayrAkif&#95;KayapınarYaylacı2014" class="citation cs2">Dallmayr, Fred; Akif Kayapınar, M.; Yaylacı, İsmail (24 September 2014), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=5QeqBAAAQBAJ&amp;q=misr+means+civilization&amp;pg=PA87"><i>Civilizations and World Order</i></a>, Lexington Books, <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/9780739186077" title="Special:BookSources/9780739186077"><bdi>9780739186077</bdi></a><span class="reference-accessdate">, retrieved <span class="nowrap">31 July</span> 2024</span></cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Civilizations+and+World+Order&amp;rft.pub=Lexington+Books&amp;rft.date=2014-09-24&amp;rft.isbn=9780739186077&amp;rft.aulast=Dallmayr&amp;rft.aufirst=Fred&amp;rft.au=Akif+Kayap%C4%B1nar%2C+M.&amp;rft.au=Yaylac%C4%B1%2C+%C4%B0smail&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D5QeqBAAAQBAJ%26q%3Dmisr%2Bmeans%2Bcivilization%26pg%3DPA87&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-50"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-50">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The ending of the Hebrew form is either a <a href="/wiki/Dual_(grammatical_number)" title="Dual (grammatical number)">dual</a> or an ending identical to the dual in form (perhaps a <a href="/wiki/Locative" class="mw-redirect" title="Locative">locative</a>), and this has sometimes been taken as referring to the two kingdoms of Upper and Lower Egypt. However, the application of the (possibly) "dual" ending to some toponyms and other words, a development peculiar to Hebrew, does not in fact imply any "two-ness" about the place. The ending is found, for example, in the Hebrew words for such single entities as "water" ("מַיִם"), "noon" ("צָהֳרַיִם"), "sky/heaven" ("שָׁמַיִם"), and in the <i><a href="/wiki/Qere_and_Ketiv" title="Qere and Ketiv">qere</a></i> – but not the original "ketiv" – of "Jerusalem" ("ירושל[י]ם"). It should also be noted that the dual ending – which may or may not be what the <i>-áyim</i> in "Mitzráyim" actually represents – was available to other Semitic languages, such as Arabic, but was not applied to Egypt. See <i>inter alia</i> Aaron Demsky ("Hebrew Names in the Dual Form and the Toponym Yerushalayim" in Demsky (ed.) <i>These Are the Names: Studies in Jewish Onomastics</i>, Vol. 3 (Ramat Gan, 2002), pp. 11–20), <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=p1AMBAAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA128">Page 128</a> in <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFHurvitz2014" class="citation book cs1">Hurvitz, Avi (2014). "List of Abbreviations and Sigla". <i>A Concise Lexicon of Late Biblical Hebrew</i>. pp.&#160;<span class="nowrap">18–</span>243. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1163%2F9789004266438_004">10.1163/9789004266438_004</a>. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-90-04-26643-8" title="Special:BookSources/978-90-04-26643-8"><bdi>978-90-04-26643-8</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=bookitem&amp;rft.atitle=List+of+Abbreviations+and+Sigla&amp;rft.btitle=A+Concise+Lexicon+of+Late+Biblical+Hebrew&amp;rft.pages=18-243&amp;rft.date=2014&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1163%2F9789004266438&#95;004&amp;rft.isbn=978-90-04-26643-8&amp;rft.aulast=Hurvitz&amp;rft.aufirst=Avi&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span> and <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFNa&#39;aman2008" class="citation journal cs1">Na'aman, Nadav (31 December 2008). "Shaaraim – The Gateway To The Kingdom Of Judah". <i>The Journal of Hebrew Scriptures</i>. <b>8</b>. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.5508%2Fjhs.2008.v8.a24">10.5508/jhs.2008.v8.a24</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=The+Journal+of+Hebrew+Scriptures&amp;rft.atitle=Shaaraim+%E2%80%93+The+Gateway+To+The+Kingdom+Of+Judah&amp;rft.volume=8&amp;rft.date=2008-12-31&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.5508%2Fjhs.2008.v8.a24&amp;rft.aulast=Na%27aman&amp;rft.aufirst=Nadav&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFIzre&#39;el1984" class="citation journal cs1">Izre'el, Shlomo (1984). "On the So-Called Ventive Morpheme in the Akkadian Texts of Amurru". <i>Ugarit-Forschungen</i>. <b>16</b>: <span class="nowrap">83–</span>92.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Ugarit-Forschungen&amp;rft.atitle=On+the+So-Called+Ventive+Morpheme+in+the+Akkadian+Texts+of+Amurru&amp;rft.volume=16&amp;rft.pages=83-92&amp;rft.date=1984&amp;rft.aulast=Izre%27el&amp;rft.aufirst=Shlomo&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-akkadian-52"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-akkadian_52-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBlackGeorgePostgate2000" class="citation book cs1">Black, Jeremy A.; George, Andrew; Postgate, J.N. (2000). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=-qIuVCsRb98C&amp;pg=PA212"><i>A Concise Dictionary of Akkadian</i></a>. Otto Harrassowitz Verlag. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-3-447-04264-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-3-447-04264-2"><bdi>978-3-447-04264-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=A+Concise+Dictionary+of+Akkadian&amp;rft.pub=Otto+Harrassowitz+Verlag&amp;rft.date=2000&amp;rft.isbn=978-3-447-04264-2&amp;rft.aulast=Black&amp;rft.aufirst=Jeremy+A.&amp;rft.au=George%2C+Andrew&amp;rft.au=Postgate%2C+J.N.&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fbooks.google.com%2Fbooks%3Fid%3D-qIuVCsRb98C%26pg%3DPA212&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-53"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-53">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">As in inscriptions such as the <a href="/wiki/Rassam_cylinder" title="Rassam cylinder">Rassam cylinder</a> of <a href="/wiki/Ashurbanipal" title="Ashurbanipal">Ashurbanipal</a>. For transcription, the word being written Mu-s,ur <a rel="nofollow" class="external autonumber" href="https://cdli.ucla.edu/search/archival_view.php?ObjectID=P421807">[1]</a> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20200613113247/https://cdli.ucla.edu/search/archival_view.php?ObjectID=P421807">Archived</a> 13 June 2020 at the <a href="/wiki/Wayback_Machine" title="Wayback Machine">Wayback Machine</a></span>
</li>
<li id="cite&#95;note-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-54">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Midant-Reynes, Béatrix. <i>The Prehistory of Egypt: From the First Egyptians to the First Kings</i>. Oxford: Blackwell Publishers.</span>
</li>

<li id="cite&#95;note-Nejla&#95;M.&#95;Abu&#95;Izzeddin&#95;1973,&#95;p&#95;2-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Nejla_M._Abu_Izzeddin_1973,_p_2_71-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFIzzeddin1981" class="citation book cs1">Izzeddin, Nejla M. Third World Centre for Research and Publishing. p.&#160;2. <a href="/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="ISBN (identifier)">ISBN</a>&#160;<a href="/wiki/Special:BookSources/978-0-86199-012-2" title="Special:BookSources/978-0-86199-012-2"><bdi>978-0-86199-012-2</bdi></a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Abook&amp;rft.genre=book&amp;rft.btitle=Nasser+of+the+Arabs%3A+an+Arab+assessment&amp;rft.pages=2&amp;rft.pub=Third+World+Centre+for+Research+and+Publishing&amp;rft.date=1981&amp;rft.isbn=978-0-86199-012-2&amp;rft.aulast=Izzeddin&amp;rft.aufirst=Nejla+M.+Abu&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-CIA-military-155"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-CIA-military_155-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA-military_155-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA-military_155-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA-military_155-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-CIA-military_155-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.cia.gov/the-world-factbook/countries/egypt/#military-and-security">"Egypt - Military and Security"</a>. The World Factbook, CIA<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-BBC-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-BBC_171-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-BBC_171-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-BBC_171-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-BBC_171-3"><sup><i><b>d</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-BBC_171-4"><sup><i><b>e</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-BBC_171-5"><sup><i><b>f</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFBBC2014" class="citation news cs1">BBC (18 January 2014). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-25796110">"BBC News – Egypt referendum: '98% back new constitution'<span class="cs1-kern-right"></span>"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/BBC_Online" title="BBC Online">BBC Online</a></i>. <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140118203701/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-25796110">Archived</a> from the original on 18 January 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite&#95;note-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-172">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation web cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20130117012238/http://www.nchregypt.org/en/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=category&amp;layout=blog&amp;id=1&amp;Itemid=3">"Law No. 94 of 2003 Promulgating The National Council for Human Rights"</a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-276"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-276">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFSawe2016" class="citation web cs1">Sawe, Benjamin Elisha (23 September 2016). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.worldatlas.com/articles/languages-spoken-in-egypt.html">"Languages Spoken In Egypt"</a>. <i>WorldAtlas</i><span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">8 December</span> 2025</span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=WorldAtlas&amp;rft.atitle=Languages+Spoken+In+Egypt&amp;rft.date=2016-09-23&amp;rft.aulast=Sawe&amp;rft.aufirst=Benjamin+Elisha&amp;rft&#95;id=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.worldatlas.com%2Farticles%2Flanguages-spoken-in-egypt.html&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-extinct-277"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-extinct_277-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The language may have survived in isolated pockets in <a href="/wiki/Upper_Egypt" title="Upper Egypt">Upper Egypt</a> as late as the 19th century, according to <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFQuibell1901" class="citation news cs1 cs1-prop-foreign-lang-source">Quibell, J. E. (1901). "Wann starb das Kobtische aus?" &#91;When did Coptic become extinct?&#93; (in German). p.&#160;87. <a href="/wiki/Hdl_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Hdl (identifier)">hdl</a>:<span class="id-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://hdl.handle.net/2027%2Fhvd.32044098373418?urlappend=%3Bseq=107">2027/hvd.32044098373418</a></span>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.atitle=Wann+starb+das+Kobtische+aus%3F&amp;rft.pages=87&amp;rft.date=1901&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Ahdl%2F2027%2Fhvd.32044098373418%3Furlappend%3D%253Bseq%3D107&amp;rft.aulast=Quibell&amp;rft.aufirst=J.+E.&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span> in <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation journal cs1">"Miscellen". <i>Zeitschrift für Ägyptische Sprache und Altertumskunde</i>. <b>39</b>: <span class="nowrap">83–</span>88. 1901. <a href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" class="mw-redirect" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1524%2Fzaes.1901.39.jg.83">10.1524/zaes.1901.39.jg.83</a>.</cite><span title="ctx&#95;ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft&#95;val&#95;fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Zeitschrift+f%C3%BCr+%C3%84gyptische+Sprache+und+Altertumskunde&amp;rft.atitle=Miscellen&amp;rft.volume=39&amp;rft.pages=83-88&amp;rft.date=1901&amp;rft&#95;id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1524%2Fzaes.1901.39.jg.83&amp;rfr&#95;id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEgypt" class="Z3988"></span></span>

<li id="cite&#95;note-293"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-293">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMohammad&#95;Hassan&#95;Khalil2013" class="citation book cs1">Mohammad Hassan Khalil (2013). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=PmgkD3Hel5IC&amp;pg=PA297"><i>Between Heaven and Hell: Islam, Salvation, and the Fate of Others</i></a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-Meisami&#95;1998-345"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Meisami_1998_345-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMeisamiStarkey1998" class="citation book cs1">Meisami, Julie Scott; Starkey, Paul (1998). <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=sx1bqgibKhQC&amp;pg=PA305"><i>Encyclopedia of Arabic Literature</i></a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-358"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-358">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFMehrez2008" class="citation book cs1">Mehrez, Samia (2008). <span class="id-lock-limited" title="Free access subject to limited trial, subscription normally required"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/egyptsculturewar00mehr"><i>Egypt's Culture Wars: Politics and Practice</i></a></span>. <li id="cite&#95;note-406"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-406">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite class="citation book cs1"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://books.google.com/books?id=fRnGDQAAQBAJ&amp;pg=PA248"><i>The Oxford Companion to Cheese</i></a>. <li id="cite&#95;note-RobinsonTamime1996-407"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-RobinsonTamime1996_407-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333433106" /><cite id="CITEREFRobinson,&#95;R.&#95;K.Tamime,&#95;A.&#95;Y.1996" class="citation book cs1">Robinson, R. <div class="navbox-styles"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333133064" /><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1314944253" /></div><div role="navigation" class="navbox" aria-labelledby="Shanghai&#95;Cooperation&#95;Organisation&#95;(SCO)4635" style="padding:3px"><table class="nowraplinks mw-collapsible mw-collapsed navbox-inner" style="border-spacing:0;background:transparent;color:inherit"><tbody><tr><th scope="col" class="navbox-title" colspan="2"><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1333133064" /><link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1239400231" /><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Template:Shanghai Cooperation Organisation"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Template talk:Shanghai Cooperation Organisation"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a href="/wiki/Special:EditPage/Template:Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Special:EditPage/Template:Shanghai Cooperation Organisation"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div><div id="Shanghai&#95;Cooperation&#95;Organisation&#95;(SCO)4635" style="font-size:114%;margin:0 4em"><a href="/wiki/Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Shanghai Cooperation Organisation (SCO)</a></div></th></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%">Summits</th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-odd hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/2012_Beijing_SCO_summit" title="2012 Beijing SCO summit">Beijing 2012</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/2014_Dushanbe_SCO_summit" title="2014 Dushanbe SCO summit">Dushanbe 2014</a></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><th scope="row" class="navbox-group" style="width:1%"><a href="/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Shanghai_Cooperation_Organisation" title="Member states of the Shanghai Cooperation Organisation">Member states</a></th><td class="navbox-list-with-group navbox-list navbox-even hlist" style="width:100%;padding:0"><div style="padding:0 0.25em">
<ul><li><span class="flagicon"><span class="mw-image-border" typeof="mw:File"><span><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Flag_of_Belarus.svg/40px-Flag_of_Belarus.svg.png" decoding="async" width="23" height="12" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/85/Flag_of_Belarus.svg/60px-Flag_of_Belarus.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="600" /></span></span>&#160;</span><a href="/wiki/Belarus" title="Belarus">Belarus</a></li>
